TV ad impressions also showed slight dips, down 4.6%. iSpot also shares the most-seen retail brands on TV over the holiday weekend as well.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/11/copy-copy-copy-madhive-political-ctv-tvrev.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1000"" height=""508"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/11/copy-copy-copy-madhive-political-ctv-tvrev.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/11/copy-copy-copy-madhive-political-ctv-tvrev.jpeg 1000w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p>Some additional findings from the five-day kickoff to the holidays:</p><ul><li>Etsy was the most-seen DTC retail brand by a large margin, with 25.36% of those TV ad impressions (nearly seven points higher than No. 2 DTC brand, Wayfair).</li><li>NBC delivered the highest share of retail TV ad impressions during the holiday weekend, at 9.24%.</li><li>Of course, football played a big role for retail brands over Thanksgiving — the NFL accounted for 12.89% of TV ad impressions, while college football was No. 2 with 3.85%.</li></ul>",6387964e4802ed003d57643b,"The holiday shopping season has officially begun, and retailers made the most of big TV audiences during the “Turkey Five.” According to iSpot data, est. national TV ad spend for retail brands rose 6.4% year-over-year during the five-day holiday weekend. TV ad impressions also showed slight dips, down 4.6%. iSpot also shares the most-seen retail brands on TV over the holiday weekend as well.

Some additional findings from the five-day kickoff to the holidays:

 * Etsy was the most-seen DTC retail brand by a large margin, with 25.36% of those TV ad impressions (nearly seven points higher than No. 2 DTC brand, Wayfair).
 * NBC delivered the highest share of retail TV ad impressions during the holiday weekend, at 9.24%.
 * Of course, football played a big role for retail brands over Thanksgiving — the NFL accounted for 12.89% of TV ad impressions, while college football was No. 2 with 3.85%.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1561069934-eee225952461?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDl8fGJsYWNrJTIwZnJpZGF5fGVufDB8fHx8MTY2OTgzMDI2OQ&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-11-30T17:43:42.000Z,2022-12-01T03:25:09.000Z,2022-11-30T22:36:37.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,6387e1fa4802ed003d576470,be85768d-8ad6-47ff-ab58-9ba209341749,NFL Gobbles Up Turkey Day Watch Time,nfl-gobbles-up-turkey-day-watch-time,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/11/copy-inscapeworldcupkickoff.jpeg"",""width"":1000,""height"":509}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://inscape.tv/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""With three competitive games on Thanksgiving Day, the NFL dominated televisions, as shown by data from ""],[0,[0],1,""Inscape""],[0,[],0,"". The league accounted for over 26% of all minutes watched on Nov. 24, which was 4 times the total for the next most-watched program (NBC’s Macy’s Thanksgiving Day broadcast). Some other key data points based on Thanksgiving TV viewing behavior:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""The total for Thanksgiving 2022 was actually a year-over-year jump from 2021’s 24.34% share — despite the World Cup’s presence on TVs this year as well.""]],[[0,[],0,""Three of the top 13 most-watched shows on TV during Thanksgiving Day were football-related (including college), and seven of the top 13 were sports-related.""]],[[0,[],0,""A sports focus buoyed Big Four broadcast networks, which accounted for a combined 50.1% of watch-time (led by NBC at 17.15%).""]]]],[10,0]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>With three competitive games on Thanksgiving Day, the NFL dominated televisions, as shown by data from <a href=""http://inscape.tv/"">Inscape</a>. The league accounted for over 26% of all minutes watched on Nov. 24, which was 4 times the total for the next most-watched program (NBC’s Macy’s Thanksgiving Day broadcast). Some other key data points based on Thanksgiving TV viewing behavior:</p><ul><li>The total for Thanksgiving 2022 was actually a year-over-year jump from 2021’s 24.34% share — despite the World Cup’s presence on TVs this year as well.</li><li>Three of the top 13 most-watched shows on TV during Thanksgiving Day were football-related (including college), and seven of the top 13 were sports-related.</li><li>A sports focus buoyed Big Four broadcast networks, which accounted for a combined 50.1% of watch-time (led by NBC at 17.15%).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/11/copy-inscapeworldcupkickoff.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1000"" height=""509"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/11/copy-inscapeworldcupkickoff.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/11/copy-inscapeworldcupkickoff.jpeg 1000w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6387e1fa4802ed003d576470,"With three competitive games on Thanksgiving Day, the NFL dominated televisions, as shown by data from Inscape. The league accounted for over 26% of all minutes watched on Nov. 24, which was 4 times the total for the next most-watched program (NBC’s Macy’s Thanksgiving Day broadcast). Some other key data points based on Thanksgiving TV viewing behavior:

 * The total for Thanksgiving 2022 was actually a year-over-year jump from 2021’s 24.34% share — despite the World Cup’s presence on TVs this year as well.
 * Three of the top 13 most-watched shows on TV during Thanksgiving Day were football-related (including college), and seven of the top 13 were sports-related.
 * A sports focus buoyed Big Four broadcast networks, which accounted for a combined 50.1% of watch-time (led by NBC at 17.15%).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1629109017487-85bc4ff6e1e1?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDE4fHxhbWVyaWNhbiUyMGZvb3RiYWxsfGVufDB8fHx8MTY2OTg0OTY2Mg&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-11-30T23:06:34.000Z,2022-12-01T19:39:22.000Z,2022-12-01T19:39:22.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,6389293d4802ed003d5764bc,47475eb9-7637-42c2-a093-b5e42473a72e,Fox Nabs Nearly 10% Of TV Watch-Time From Nov. 21-27,fox-nabs-nearly-10-of-tv-watch-time-from-nov-21-27,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Inscape-Network-Rankings-Nov21-27.png"",""width"":1018,""height"":1219}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.nexttv.com/news/world-cup-group-stage-hits-the-mark-for-networks-advertisers-tv-by-the-numbers""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Inscape data ""],[0,[0],1,""shared with Broadcasting & Cable""],[0,[],0,"" reveals that Fox jumped to the most-watched network from Nov. 21-27, with 9.99% of all live linear watch-time. That's up from 5.22% the week before, as Fox benefited from major sporting events during the holiday weekend. Along with its usual Sunday NFL action, Fox also aired Saturday's huge Ohio State-Michigan college football game, the Thanksgiving Giants-Cowboys game, and ongoing World Cup matches.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Additional highlights around the week in TV:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Paramount Network's latest ""],[0,[1],1,""Yellowstone""],[0,[],0,"" marathon (plus the current season) propels it from No. 18 to No. 8 by watch-time week-over-week.""]],[[0,[],0,""Both Fox Sports 1 and Telemundo jump into the top 10 by watch-time on the strength of World Cup viewing.""]],[[0,[],0,""Hallmark Channel starts off the holiday season strong with 3.07% of minutes watched on the week, up from 2.92% the week before as its large collection of TV movie specials start rolling out.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""Read more on B&C""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Inscape data <a href=""https://www.nexttv.com/news/world-cup-group-stage-hits-the-mark-for-networks-advertisers-tv-by-the-numbers"">shared with Broadcasting &amp; Cable</a> reveals that Fox jumped to the most-watched network from Nov. 21-27, with 9.99% of all live linear watch-time. That's up from 5.22% the week before, as Fox benefited from major sporting events during the holiday weekend. Along with its usual Sunday NFL action, Fox also aired Saturday's huge Ohio State-Michigan college football game, the Thanksgiving Giants-Cowboys game, and ongoing World Cup matches.</p><p>Additional highlights around the week in TV:</p><ul><li>Paramount Network's latest <em>Yellowstone</em> marathon (plus the current season) propels it from No. 18 to No. 8 by watch-time week-over-week.</li><li>Both Fox Sports 1 and Telemundo jump into the top 10 by watch-time on the strength of World Cup viewing.</li><li>Hallmark Channel starts off the holiday season strong with 3.07% of minutes watched on the week, up from 2.92% the week before as its large collection of TV movie specials start rolling out.</li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.nexttv.com/news/world-cup-group-stage-hits-the-mark-for-networks-advertisers-tv-by-the-numbers"">Read more on B&amp;C</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Inscape-Network-Rankings-Nov21-27.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/Inscape-Network-Rankings-Nov21-27.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/Inscape-Network-Rankings-Nov21-27.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Inscape-Network-Rankings-Nov21-27.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6389293d4802ed003d5764bc,"Inscape data shared with Broadcasting & Cable reveals that Fox jumped to the most-watched network from Nov. 21-27, with 9.99% of all live linear watch-time. That's up from 5.22% the week before, as Fox benefited from major sporting events during the holiday weekend. Along with its usual Sunday NFL action, Fox also aired Saturday's huge Ohio State-Michigan college football game, the Thanksgiving Giants-Cowboys game, and ongoing World Cup matches.

Additional highlights around the week in TV:

 * Paramount Network's latest Yellowstone marathon (plus the current season) propels it from No. 18 to No. 8 by watch-time week-over-week.
 * Both Fox Sports 1 and Telemundo jump into the top 10 by watch-time on the strength of World Cup viewing.
 * Hallmark Channel starts off the holiday season strong with 3.07% of minutes watched on the week, up from 2.92% the week before as its large collection of TV movie specials start rolling out.

The brand's November spend climbed 24% year-over-year, as it leaned on the World Series – but also three times as many minutes of national TV advertising.</p><p>Additional notes from November's automotive ads on TV:</p><ul><li>Top 15 brands with the biggest year-over-year spend jump: BMW (+117.88%), Lexus (+72.86%), Jeep (+70.64%), Volkswagen (+34.71%) and Hyundai (+27.51%).</li><li>Top programs for automakers by TV ad impressions share of voice in November were the NFL (13.00%), College football (10.00%), Copa Mundial De la FIFA 2022 (2.28%), World Series (1.38%) and SportsCenter (1.18%).</li><li>For auto brands, est. national TV ad spend in November dipped 11.3% year-over-year, but TV ad impressions were up 12.3%.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://ispot.tv""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/vehicles-auto-makers_industry-overview_top-brands_11-01-2022_to_11-30-2022.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1800"" height=""900"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/vehicles-auto-makers_industry-overview_top-brands_11-01-2022_to_11-30-2022.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/vehicles-auto-makers_industry-overview_top-brands_11-01-2022_to_11-30-2022.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2022/12/vehicles-auto-makers_industry-overview_top-brands_11-01-2022_to_11-30-2022.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/vehicles-auto-makers_industry-overview_top-brands_11-01-2022_to_11-30-2022.png 1800w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",638e59a9514a55004d57fce3,"Chevrolet springs to the top of November's charts by automaker est. national TV ad spend, according to iSpot data shared with MediaPost. Additional notes from November's automotive ads on TV:

 * Top 15 brands with the biggest year-over-year spend jump: BMW (+117.88%), Lexus (+72.86%), Jeep (+70.64%), Volkswagen (+34.71%) and Hyundai (+27.51%).
 * Top programs for automakers by TV ad impressions share of voice in November were the NFL (13.00%), College football (10.00%), Copa Mundial De la FIFA 2022 (2.28%), World Series (1.38%) and SportsCenter (1.18%).
 * For auto brands, est. national TV ad spend in November dipped 11.3% year-over-year, but TV ad impressions were up 12.3%.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1604945417112-07c84e9a21fa?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDN8fGNoZXZyb2xldHxlbnwwfHx8fDE2NzAyNzM0MzY&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-05T20:50:49.000Z,2022-12-06T18:54:20.000Z,2022-12-05T20:58:14.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,638fa397ae6210003dcd7e36,67d9889b-9114-4f10-9f5e-3ea6d580dd58,Into The FAST Lane,into-the-fast-lane,,"{""root"":{""children"":[{""type"":""html"",""html"":""<script src=\""https://gumroad.com/js/gumroad-embed.js\""></script>\n<div class=\""gumroad-product-embed\""><a href=\""https://themeasure.gumroad.com/l/pqopo\"">Loading...</a></div>""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<!--kg-card-begin: html--><script src=""https://gumroad.com/js/gumroad-embed.js""></script>

Loading...",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/zype.jpeg,0,page,published,,public,all,2022-12-06T20:18:31.000Z,2023-11-09T19:23:44.000Z,2022-12-06T21:09:07.000Z,,,,,,,1,638fcd0dae6210003dcd7e72,6d97b0a6-d1ee-4399-8855-708868522600,79% Of NFL Viewers' TV Watch-Time Spent Watching Non-Sports Programs (Report),79-of-nfl-viewers-tv-watch-time-spent-watching-non-nfl-programs,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/advertising-to-football-fans-who-they-are-what-they-watch-and-how-to-reach-them""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://inscape.tv""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""While NFL games present a golden opportunity for advertisers to reach large audiences, those audiences also watch plenty of other programming... and much of it is cheaper to advertise against than NFL games.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""A new report from VIZIO""],[0,[],0,"" (using ""],[0,[1],1,""Inscape""],[0,[],0,"" ACR data) showcases how brands can find football audiences elsewhere as budgets potentially tighten in 2023. Some of the big takeaways around audience behaviors for both NFL and college football audiences, and how brands can adjust ad buys to reduce waste:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Among all NFL viewers, 21% of time is spent watching sports but 79% is spent watching non-sports programming (all of which is going to be cheaper than NFL inventory).""]],[[0,[],0,""While college football viewers spend slightly more time (22.4%) watching sports, that still leaves 77.6% of the time where other non-sports programming is on TV.""]],[[0,[],0,""Across all active VIZIO TVs, just 17.4% of watch-time is dedicated to sports, which leaves a staggering 82.6% of time on non-sports programs; yet most major advertisers are still hyper-focused on expensive live sports as a source of impressions.""]]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>While NFL games present a golden opportunity for advertisers to reach large audiences, those audiences also watch plenty of other programming... and much of it is cheaper to advertise against than NFL games.</p><p><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/advertising-to-football-fans-who-they-are-what-they-watch-and-how-to-reach-them"">A new report from VIZIO</a> (using <a href=""http://inscape.tv"">Inscape</a> ACR data) showcases how brands can find football audiences elsewhere as budgets potentially tighten in 2023. Some of the big takeaways around audience behaviors for both NFL and college football audiences, and how brands can adjust ad buys to reduce waste:</p><ul><li>Among all NFL viewers, 21% of time is spent watching sports but 79% is spent watching non-sports programming (all of which is going to be cheaper than NFL inventory).</li><li>While college football viewers spend slightly more time (22.4%) watching sports, that still leaves 77.6% of the time where other non-sports programming is on TV.</li><li>Across all active VIZIO TVs, just 17.4% of watch-time is dedicated to sports, which leaves a staggering 82.6% of time on non-sports programs; yet most major advertisers are still hyper-focused on expensive live sports as a source of impressions.</li></ul>",638fcd0dae6210003dcd7e72,"While NFL games present a golden opportunity for advertisers to reach large audiences, those audiences also watch plenty of other programming... and much of it is cheaper to advertise against than NFL games.

A new report from VIZIO (using Inscape ACR data) showcases how brands can find football audiences elsewhere as budgets potentially tighten in 2023. Some of the big takeaways around audience behaviors for both NFL and college football audiences, and how brands can adjust ad buys to reduce waste:

 * Among all NFL viewers, 21% of time is spent watching sports but 79% is spent watching non-sports programming (all of which is going to be cheaper than NFL inventory).
 * While college football viewers spend slightly more time (22.4%) watching sports, that still leaves 77.6% of the time where other non-sports programming is on TV.
 * Across all active VIZIO TVs, just 17.4% of watch-time is dedicated to sports, which leaves a staggering 82.6% of time on non-sports programs; yet most major advertisers are still hyper-focused on expensive live sports as a source of impressions.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/vizio-football-graphics--2-.png,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-06T23:15:25.000Z,2022-12-06T23:24:07.000Z,2022-12-06T23:24:07.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,638fcf34ae6210003dcd7ecd,bc212277-e6fc-425b-8a49-db4a3d0a36d8,"NFL, College Football Audience Overlap Minimizes Incremental Reach (Report)",nfl-college-football-audience-overlap-minimizes-incremental-reach,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/advertising-to-football-fans-who-they-are-what-they-watch-and-how-to-reach-them""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://inscape.tv""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""NFL and college football TV audiences aren't the separate islands that conventional wisdom has long suggested.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""A ""],[0,[0],1,""new report from VIZIO Ads""],[0,[],0,"" (using ""],[0,[1],1,""Inscape""],[0,[],0,"" ACR data) spotlights how these audiences overlap significantly, and how a very small portion of TV audiences ""],[0,[2],1,""exclusively""],[0,[],0,"" watch college football over the NFL. More highlights from the report's data on audience overlap below:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""While 35% of active VIZIO devices watch the NFL, 25.7% watch college football – and 22% watch both.""]],[[0,[],0,""Just 3.7% of TVs only watch college football, versus just 13.3% only watching the NFL.""]],[[0,[],0,""From an incremental reach standpoint, advertising during both sports actually provides little in the way of new audiences, suggesting that brands could get better ROI by simply advertising during one or the other.""]]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>NFL and college football TV audiences aren't the separate islands that conventional wisdom has long suggested.</p><p>A <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/advertising-to-football-fans-who-they-are-what-they-watch-and-how-to-reach-them"">new report from VIZIO Ads</a> (using <a href=""http://inscape.tv"">Inscape</a> ACR data) spotlights how these audiences overlap significantly, and how a very small portion of TV audiences <em>exclusively</em> watch college football over the NFL. More highlights from the report's data on audience overlap below:</p><ul><li>While 35% of active VIZIO devices watch the NFL, 25.7% watch college football – and 22% watch both.</li><li>Just 3.7% of TVs only watch college football, versus just 13.3% only watching the NFL.</li><li>From an incremental reach standpoint, advertising during both sports actually provides little in the way of new audiences, suggesting that brands could get better ROI by simply advertising during one or the other.</li></ul>",638fcf34ae6210003dcd7ecd,"NFL and college football TV audiences aren't the separate islands that conventional wisdom has long suggested.

A new report from VIZIO Ads (using Inscape ACR data) spotlights how these audiences overlap significantly, and how a very small portion of TV audiences exclusively watch college football over the NFL. More highlights from the report's data on audience overlap below:

 * While 35% of active VIZIO devices watch the NFL, 25.7% watch college football – and 22% watch both.
 * Just 3.7% of TVs only watch college football, versus just 13.3% only watching the NFL.
 * From an incremental reach standpoint, advertising during both sports actually provides little in the way of new audiences, suggesting that brands could get better ROI by simply advertising during one or the other.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/vizio-football-graphics.png,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-06T23:24:36.000Z,2022-12-06T23:29:59.000Z,2022-12-06T23:29:59.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,638fd1abae6210003dcd7f0d,51dd72dc-964f-4440-ad91-d017446a47a1,World Cup Keeps Scoring Audience Watch-Time,world-cup-keeps-scoring-audience-watch-time,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/inscapeworldcupkickoff--1-.jpg"",""width"":1500,""height"":763,""href"":""http://inscape.tv""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://inscape.tv""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The 2022 FIFA Men's World Cup keeps rolling into the knockout rounds. And despite the change from its usual place on the calendar, the games continue to draw a huge audience relative to the rest of TV.</p><p>Data from <a href=""http://inscape.tv"">Inscape</a> shows that from Nov. 20-Dec. 5, English- and Spanish-language World Cup game airings accounted for 3.30% of all live, linear minutes watched. And despite the change from its usual place on the calendar, the games continue to draw a huge audience relative to the rest of TV.

Data from Inscape shows that from Nov. 20-Dec. 5, English- and Spanish-language World Cup game airings accounted for 3.30% of all live, linear minutes watched. That would rank No. 3 in the timeframe behind just the NFL and college football.

 * Watch-time for Fox and FS1 English-language airings deliver 2.40% of watch-time, versus 0.90% for Spanish-language across Telemundo and Universo.

Notably, Black Friday and Cyber Monday brand-sponsored creator posts on Instagram were up 51.9% year-over-year.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""creatoriq.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/ciq-holiday-data.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1500"" height=""763"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/ciq-holiday-data.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/ciq-holiday-data.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/ciq-holiday-data.jpg 1500w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><ul><li>In total, Black Friday and Cyber Monday saw <strong><strong>57K</strong></strong> sponsored posts on Instagram, from <strong><strong>30K</strong></strong> influencers.</li><li>One of the top brands utilizing influencers was Amazon, which leveraged more than <strong><strong>460 creators</strong></strong> on Instagram including Awaz Darbar, Bretman Rock, Charlie D'Amelio, and Dixie D'Amelio.</li><li>Categorically, fashion brands dominated the Black Friday and Cyber Monday social content with <strong><strong>2.3K influencers</strong></strong>, making up <strong><strong>44%</strong></strong> of total activations. Beauty brands had the 2nd most activations (18% of total), with brands like Charlotte Tilbury and Sephora leading the pack.</li><li>In addition to the IG uptick, CreatorIQ also saw a <strong><strong>124.97% YoY increase</strong></strong> in brand-sponsored posts from creators on TikTok.</li></ul>",6390fc26da5c38004d12d3b1,"With the holiday shopping season in full swing, influencer marketing platform CreatorIQ did an analysis of brand-sponsored creator posts on Instagram, to understand the role that content creators are playing in advertising. Notably, Black Friday and Cyber Monday brand-sponsored creator posts on Instagram were up 51.9% year-over-year.

 * In total, Black Friday and Cyber Monday saw 57K sponsored posts on Instagram, from 30K influencers.
 * One of the top brands utilizing influencers was Amazon, which leveraged more than 460 creators on Instagram including Awaz Darbar, Bretman Rock, Charlie D'Amelio, and Dixie D'Amelio.
 * Categorically, fashion brands dominated the Black Friday and Cyber Monday social content with 2.3K influencers, making up 44% of total activations. Beauty brands had the 2nd most activations (18% of total), with brands like Charlotte Tilbury and Sephora leading the pack.
 * In addition to the IG uptick, CreatorIQ also saw a 124.97% YoY increase in brand-sponsored posts from creators on TikTok.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1483985988355-763728e1935b?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDJ8fHNob3BwaW5nfGVufDB8fHx8MTY3MDQ0NjI2OA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-07T20:48:38.000Z,2022-12-07T21:02:00.000Z,2022-12-07T20:52:41.000Z,"With the holiday shopping season in full swing, influencer marketing platform CreatorIQ did an analysis of brand-sponsored creator posts on Instagram...",,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,6392299c6648b7003d4af3b0,c1003a9d-cc26-40a1-87fc-44840690336b,It's this easy,its-this-easy,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{}],[""image"",{}]],""markups"":[],""sections"":[[10,0],[10,1],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,,6392299c6648b7003d4af3b0,,,0,post,draft,,public,all,2022-12-08T18:14:52.000Z,2022-12-08T18:16:43.000Z,,,,,,,,1,63922a0c6648b7003d4af3bc,b2665adb-d0e5-44b2-8b5c-f2a5420f2d32,You Want The Truth?,you-want-the-truth,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-10.29.48-AM.png"",""width"":1594,""height"":680,""href"":""https://www.truthset.io/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.nexttv.com/news/truthset-launches-collective-to-verify-quality-of-demo-data""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Everyone needs data today, but what good is that information if it’s inaccurate? ""],[0,[0],1,""Truthset’s new Data Collective""],[0,[],0,"" is addressing the data validation issue head-on, to help clear up issues like those spelled out below. Among the most glaring – indications around small business owners are accurate just 16% of the time, while voter affiliation is only accurate 67% of the time. Additional findings from across the Truthset Data Collective in Q3 2022:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Car manufacturer data is accurate for consumers just 48% of the time — which is actually a quarter-over-quarter improvement.""]],[[0,[],0,""DMA data is accurate 92% of the time… which still means that 8% of all spend based on metro area in the U.S. is completely wasted on people that don’t even live there anymore.""]],[[0,[],0,""Military status is accurate just 33% of the time — which is of particular interest to the many brands that use military service (past or present) as a qualifier for consumer communications.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Everyone needs data today, but what good is that information if it’s inaccurate? <a href=""https://www.nexttv.com/news/truthset-launches-collective-to-verify-quality-of-demo-data"">Truthset’s new Data Collective</a> is addressing the data validation issue head-on, to help clear up issues like those spelled out below. Among the most glaring – indications around small business owners are accurate just 16% of the time, while voter affiliation is only accurate 67% of the time. Additional findings from across the Truthset Data Collective in Q3 2022:</p><ul><li>Car manufacturer data is accurate for consumers just 48% of the time — which is actually a quarter-over-quarter improvement.</li><li>DMA data is accurate 92% of the time… which still means that 8% of all spend based on metro area in the U.S. is completely wasted on people that don’t even live there anymore.</li><li>Military status is accurate just 33% of the time — which is of particular interest to the many brands that use military service (past or present) as a qualifier for consumer communications.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.truthset.io/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-10.29.48-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1594"" height=""680"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-10.29.48-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-10.29.48-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-10.29.48-AM.png 1594w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",63922a0c6648b7003d4af3bc,"Everyone needs data today, but what good is that information if it’s inaccurate? Truthset’s new Data Collective is addressing the data validation issue head-on, to help clear up issues like those spelled out below. Among the most glaring – indications around small business owners are accurate just 16% of the time, while voter affiliation is only accurate 67% of the time. Additional findings from across the Truthset Data Collective in Q3 2022:

 * Car manufacturer data is accurate for consumers just 48% of the time — which is actually a quarter-over-quarter improvement.
 * DMA data is accurate 92% of the time… which still means that 8% of all spend based on metro area in the U.S. is completely wasted on people that don’t even live there anymore.
 * Military status is accurate just 33% of the time — which is of particular interest to the many brands that use military service (past or present) as a qualifier for consumer communications.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598363432303-fc8e1fb5a72d?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDV8fHRydXRofGVufDB8fHx8MTY3MDUyMzQxOQ&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-08T18:16:44.000Z,2022-12-08T18:18:12.000Z,2022-12-08T18:18:12.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63922a8b6648b7003d4af3ed,842a19df-167d-465c-b44e-1c053cca9412,Workwear Videos Win With Fashion Audiences,workwear-videos-win-with-fashion-audiences,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-9.52.59-AM.png"",""width"":1396,""height"":910,""href"":""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""After nearly three years of working from home, no one knows what to wear anymore – and they’re watching YouTube to figure it out. A ""],[0,[0],1,""new Tubular Labs infographic on fashion""],[0,[],0,"" shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the discovery that fashion audiences are watching a lot of videos on workwear – despite a relatively low supply compared to other videos in the category. Some additional findings from Tubular:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""YouTube views about fashion topics are up 32% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 21-22).""]],[[0,[],0,""Men account for 56% of YouTube fashion viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share.""]],[[0,[],0,""Those that watch fashion videos are also most likely to shop for products by brands like Nivea, Polaroid and Timberland (among others).""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>After nearly three years of working from home, no one knows what to wear anymore – and they’re watching YouTube to figure it out. A <a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/"">new Tubular Labs infographic on fashion</a> shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the discovery that fashion audiences are watching a lot of videos on workwear – despite a relatively low supply compared to other videos in the category. Some additional findings from Tubular:</p><ul><li>YouTube views about fashion topics are up 32% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 21-22).</li><li>Men account for 56% of YouTube fashion viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share.</li><li>Those that watch fashion videos are also most likely to shop for products by brands like Nivea, Polaroid and Timberland (among others).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-9.52.59-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1396"" height=""910"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-9.52.59-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-9.52.59-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-07-at-9.52.59-AM.png 1396w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",63922a8b6648b7003d4af3ed,"After nearly three years of working from home, no one knows what to wear anymore – and they’re watching YouTube to figure it out. A new Tubular Labs infographic on fashion shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the discovery that fashion audiences are watching a lot of videos on workwear – despite a relatively low supply compared to other videos in the category. Some additional findings from Tubular:

 * YouTube views about fashion topics are up 32% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 21-22).
 * Men account for 56% of YouTube fashion viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share.
 * Those that watch fashion videos are also most likely to shop for products by brands like Nivea, Polaroid and Timberland (among others).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1603252110481-7ba873bf42ab?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDN8fHdvcmt3ZWFyfGVufDB8fHx8MTY3MDUyMzU5Mw&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-08T18:18:51.000Z,2022-12-08T18:20:01.000Z,2022-12-08T18:20:01.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,6393d0086648b7003d4af420,0f58447a-901a-4b5e-a0ec-1b398fab9011,"It’s Just “Max” Now, RSNs Bumpy Road To Streaming",wir20221209,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""strong""],[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/news/special-report-fasts-are-the-new-cable""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.nexttv.com/news/why-nbcu-moving-its-rsns-to-peacock-could-turn-nbcus-struggling-dtc-game-around-wolk""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[]],[1,""h3"",[[0,[],0,""1. It’s Just “Max” Now""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Millions of “Disco Bros” fans are bound to be disappointed by news that the probable new name of the HBO Max/Discovery+ collab is going to be “Max.” (There’s a pesky bit of business about a pharma company that owns the rights to the Max URL that needs to be dealt with first.)""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Still no word on pricing, or what happens to all those Discovery+ subscribers who were happily paying $5/month for the ad-supported version. Will they be grandfathered into the new app, and if so for how long?""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""It seems there was also much debate on the wisdom of removing “HBO” from the app’s name, given that it is such an iconic brand.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""But I think that moving away from HBO is the right move, especially now.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""Why It Matters""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""HBO has been around for close to 40 years and the service has not changed dramatically since the early 00s when it became the home of “quality TV.”""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""And that’s the thing.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""People have had almost 20 years to decide whether HBO and its style of programming is for them. At its peak, the service had around 40 million subs—roughly 35 million via MVPDs and 5 million via its standalone HBO Now app.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Which means that all those other people had decided that HBO was not for them, and so having the name front and center is not going to help lure them in the way that having Discovery and similar less highbrow content will.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""As noted here previously, there are a whole lot of people who don’t really get why Bill Hader’s show ""],[0,[1],1,""Barry""],[0,[],0,"" is supposed to be funny. How much CNN (if any) makes it in, will there be any pickups from TBS and TNT—that sort of thing.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""I’ll also be looking to see if Discovery+’s linear channels make the migration over. Given the wide range of programming options you have on offer, you have a great argument that you are one of the only apps someone needs. Now sell it at a price point that doesn’t scare people off of that proposition.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Keep up with the bundling deals (e.g., Amazon) and specials that lock people in for a year or more. Your ad sales teams will thank you.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Remember that interface is key and that the number one issue people have with streaming apps is discovery (lower case “D”) —they can never find the shows they want. It’s Just “Max” Now</h3><p>Millions of “Disco Bros” fans are bound to be disappointed by news that the probable new name of the HBO Max/Discovery+ collab is going to be “Max.” (There’s a pesky bit of business about a pharma company that owns the rights to the Max URL that needs to be dealt with first.)</p><p>Still no word on pricing, or what happens to all those Discovery+ subscribers who were happily paying $5/month for the ad-supported version. Will they be grandfathered into the new app, and if so for how long?</p><p>It seems there was also much debate on the wisdom of removing “HBO” from the app’s name, given that it is such an iconic brand.</p><p>But I think that moving away from HBO is the right move, especially now.</p><p><strong>Why It Matters</strong></p><p>HBO has been around for close to 40 years and the service has not changed dramatically since the early 00s when it became the home of “quality TV.”</p><p>And that’s the thing.</p><p>People have had almost 20 years to decide whether HBO and its style of programming is for them. I mean he <em>kills</em> people, right?</p><p>In addition to there being a limited audience for that type of programming, there’s also a whole swath of other streaming services all cranking out HBO type shows. So that the audience has come to think of them as “streaming type shows” not “HBO type shows” which further dilutes the appeal of having HBO in the name.</p><p>Finally, there’s the fallout from the massive confusion AT&amp;T spawned when trying to roll out HBO Max, with multiple variations of HBO-branded apps scattered about—HBO Go, HBO Now, HBO-not-Max, HBO on your cable program guide…</p><p>So there will be real value in not having yet another HBO-named app.</p><p>From a content perspective, it will be interesting to see what is included. How much CNN (if any) makes it in, will there be any pickups from TBS and TNT—that sort of thing.</p><p>I’ll also be looking to see if Discovery+’s linear channels make the migration over. I strongly suspect that they will and that Max will have even more linear channels for its library content.</p><p>That’s a trend we first noted in our recent report <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/special-report-fasts-are-the-new-cable"">FASTs Are The New Cable</a>, and the consensus seems to be that all of the remaining big SVOD services will soon roll out linear channels too, joining Discovery+, Paramount+ and Peacock.</p><p>Consumers seem to like them, they are a great way to surface library content, and, if you are running advertising, they increase time spent on platform.</p><p>They also cut down on decision paralysis, or, to paraphrase something I’d heard from a number of executives, “Why would I make someone who likes watching <em>The Simpsons</em> pick an episode every time they turn on the TV when I can just give them a Simpsons channel?”</p><p>So there’s that too.</p><p><strong>What You Need To Do About It</strong></p><p>If you are WBD, the launch of the new app is a great time to pick up new subscribers and retain old ones.</p><p>Given that there aren’t that many Discovery+ subs, maybe grandfather them in for life at the OG price, provided they don’t give up the subscription.</p><p>As far as price, the key here is do no harm. Given the wide range of programming options you have on offer, you have a great argument that you are one of the only apps someone needs. Now sell it at a price point that doesn’t scare people off of that proposition.</p><p>Keep up with the bundling deals (e.g., Amazon) and specials that lock people in for a year or more. Your ad sales teams will thank you.</p><p>Remember that interface is key and that the number one issue people have with streaming apps is discovery (lower case “D”) —they can never find the shows they want. Solve that and you will have subscribers for life.</p><p>Get some live sports rights too. Nothing creates stickiness like live sports, plus all those ad-free subscribers have to watch ads during sporting events, so it increases your audience, something that is going to prove to be very important, especially if not all that many people switch over to the ad-supported version.</p><p>Finally, you’ve been on a roll with programming, keeping the HBO legacy alive. It’s Just “Max” Now

Millions of “Disco Bros” fans are bound to be disappointed by news that the probable new name of the HBO Max/Discovery+ collab is going to be “Max.” (There’s a pesky bit of business about a pharma company that owns the rights to the Max URL that needs to be dealt with first.)

Still no word on pricing, or what happens to all those Discovery+ subscribers who were happily paying $5/month for the ad-supported version. Will they be grandfathered into the new app, and if so for how long?

It seems there was also much debate on the wisdom of removing “HBO” from the app’s name, given that it is such an iconic brand.

But I think that moving away from HBO is the right move, especially now.

Why It Matters

HBO has been around for close to 40 years and the service has not changed dramatically since the early 00s when it became the home of “quality TV.”

And that’s the thing.

People have had almost 20 years to decide whether HBO and its style of programming is for them. At its peak, the service had around 40 million subs—roughly 35 million via MVPDs and 5 million via its standalone HBO Now app.

Which means that all those other people had decided that HBO was not for them, and so having the name front and center is not going to help lure them in the way that having Discovery and similar less highbrow content will.

As noted here previously, there are a whole lot of people who don’t really get why Bill Hader’s show Barry is supposed to be funny. I mean he kills people, right?

In addition to there being a limited audience for that type of programming, there’s also a whole swath of other streaming services all cranking out HBO type shows. So that the audience has come to think of them as “streaming type shows” not “HBO type shows” which further dilutes the appeal of having HBO in the name.

Finally, there’s the fallout from the massive confusion AT&T spawned when trying to roll out HBO Max, with multiple variations of HBO-branded apps scattered about—HBO Go, HBO Now, HBO-not-Max, HBO on your cable program guide…

So there will be real value in not having yet another HBO-named app.

From a content perspective, it will be interesting to see what is included. How much CNN (if any) makes it in, will there be any pickups from TBS and TNT—that sort of thing.

I’ll also be looking to see if Discovery+’s linear channels make the migration over. I strongly suspect that they will and that Max will have even more linear channels for its library content.

That’s a trend we first noted in our recent report FASTs Are The New Cable, and the consensus seems to be that all of the remaining big SVOD services will soon roll out linear channels too, joining Discovery+, Paramount+ and Peacock.

Consumers seem to like them, they are a great way to surface library content, and, if you are running advertising, they increase time spent on platform.

They also cut down on decision paralysis, or, to paraphrase something I’d heard from a number of executives, “Why would I make someone who likes watching The Simpsons pick an episode every time they turn on the TV when I can just give them a Simpsons channel?”

So there’s that too.

What You Need To Do About It

If you are WBD, the launch of the new app is a great time to pick up new subscribers and retain old ones.

Given that there aren’t that many Discovery+ subs, maybe grandfather them in for life at the OG price, provided they don’t give up the subscription.

As far as price, the key here is do no harm. Given the wide range of programming options you have on offer, you have a great argument that you are one of the only apps someone needs. Now sell it at a price point that doesn’t scare people off of that proposition.

Keep up with the bundling deals (e.g., Amazon) and specials that lock people in for a year or more. Your ad sales teams will thank you.

Remember that interface is key and that the number one issue people have with streaming apps is discovery (lower case “D”) —they can never find the shows they want. Solve that and you will have subscribers for life.

Get some live sports rights too. Nothing creates stickiness like live sports, plus all those ad-free subscribers have to watch ads during sporting events, so it increases your audience, something that is going to prove to be very important, especially if not all that many people switch over to the ad-supported version.

Finally, you’ve been on a roll with programming, keeping the HBO legacy alive. Keep that up—even if a big chunk of your potential audience doesn’t get why Barry is funny, buzzy shows like Succession and White Lotus gets you the sort of free marketing that builds empires.



2. RSNs Bumpy Move To Streaming

As has been noted here many times, in the grand scheme of things, regional sports networks (RSNs) are in many ways far more important to the survival of the TV industry than big deals like NFL rights.

Not that the latter is unimportant, it’s just that RSN fans tend to be hardcore.

They are fans of a particular pro baseball, basketball or hockey team and will gladly pay to watch every single game their team plays. This makes them a very valuable subscriber base, as they are highly unlikely to churn. At least not during the season anyway.

Which is why we’re watching two developments this week.

On the one hand, Diamond, the company that’s running Sinclair’s RSN’s and moving them all to streaming apps has been doing its best to disassociate itself with Sinclair and the $9.6 billion in debt it went into to acquire said RSNs.

On the other, NBCU seems ready to move its five RSNs onto Peacock and has been busily negotiating those deals.

Two steps forward, one step back.

Why It Matters

Let’s look at the two deals in question first.

It seems that MLB teams in particular are somewhat leery of Sinclair, given that they are so deep in the hole. The fear being that Sinclair will make irrational moves in order to guarantee profitability. Irrational to MLB owners, anyway.

While there is a new CEO at Diamond Sports, the company that runs the streaming partnership between Ballys and Sinclair, it’s unclear if that alone will result in happier MLB franchise owners. Yes, the new CEO, David Preschlack comes from NBC and is not beholden to Sinclair, but it’s sort of hard to ignore all that debt.

That said, if anyone needs to reach a new audience via streaming it is Major League Baseball, so perhaps turning a blind eye is a smart move after all, especially since the Bally RSNs are only $20/month, making them accessible to younger fans.

On a brighter note, NBCU is moving its five major market RSNs - two in Northern California, plus Boston, Philadelphia and Chicago—over to Peacock.

This is a great move for all parties involved (detailed explanation here).

The teams in question get a way to reach younger audiences who won’t need to pay over $100/month for cable just to get the RSN (Peacock will be just $10/month) while Peacock gets a whole bunch of new subscribers who are unlikely to churn and, like swallows to Capistrano, will return at the start of every season even if they do.

The RSNs are also good for NBCU’s ad sales team, because even though fans are subscribed to the ad-free version of Peacock, they will still see ads during the games.

So a win all around, unless, of course, you are one of the MVPDs who carry those RSNs, which, by all accounts, are the reason many of those fans still pay for cable.

What You Need To Do About It

If you are Major League Baseball you need to do everything you can to bring in younger fans. Baseball is increasingly viewed as old-school (and not in a good way) so you need to meet that younger audience where they live. Even if it means overlooking the potential impact of all those billions of Sinclairian debt.

If you are NBCU, well done. Not only for all the reasons noted above, but because RSNs are very much in keeping with NBCU’s brand.

If you are the remaining RSNs, streaming is where everything is going. If you don’t want to go the switchover alone, I suspect you will have no shortage of potential partners, including almost all the big SVOD services and FASTs. Just remember, the longer you wait the harder it gets.

Finally, if you do launch a streaming RSN, remember that there are a whole lot of cool things you can do that take advantage of the fact that streaming is digital and interactive.

User experience matters.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/WIR-2.png,0,post,draft,,public,all,2022-12-10T00:17:12.000Z,2022-12-10T00:29:34.000Z,,People have had almost 20 years to decide whether HBO and its style of programming is for them.,,,,,,1,6398cf842178a2003d2a87df,3c600e9a-868c-480d-8dfa-f6a3c3f524ec,NBCU Overhauls Its Creator Marketing Strategy With 76% YoY Increase In Creator Posts,nbcu-overhauls-its-creator-marketing-strategy-with,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/ciq-good-to-great.png"",""width"":1500,""height"":762}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/good-to-great-influencer-marketing-media-entertainment-agency-spotlights""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""As today’s audiences are inundated with more entertainment options than ever before, it’s imperative for them to cut through the noise and speak directly to their target audiences. Leveraging creator partnerships and campaigns can help them accomplish this. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""CreatorIQ's latest report""],[0,[],0,"" looks at how some of the top video streaming providers are faring with their creator marketing strategies, measuring the YoY increase they’ve seen with creator mentions, posts, and overall potential reach through the first three quarters of the year.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""NBCU saw the greatest increases, with over 60% growth in all categories.""]],[[0,[],0,""Despite minimal increase in creator mentions, Amazon had 36% growth in creator posts, year-over-year.""]],[[0,[],0,""Netflix had 0% growth in creator mentions, but still managed 12% increase in overall potential reach year-over-year.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>As today’s audiences are inundated with more entertainment options than ever before, it’s imperative for them to cut through the noise and speak directly to their target audiences. Leveraging creator partnerships and campaigns can help them accomplish this. </p><p><a href=""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/good-to-great-influencer-marketing-media-entertainment-agency-spotlights"">CreatorIQ's latest report</a> looks at how some of the top video streaming providers are faring with their creator marketing strategies, measuring the YoY increase they’ve seen with creator mentions, posts, and overall potential reach through the first three quarters of the year.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/ciq-good-to-great.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1500"" height=""762"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/ciq-good-to-great.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/ciq-good-to-great.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/ciq-good-to-great.png 1500w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p></p><ul><li>NBCU saw the greatest increases, with over 60% growth in all categories.</li><li>Despite minimal increase in creator mentions, Amazon had 36% growth in creator posts, year-over-year.</li><li>Netflix had 0% growth in creator mentions, but still managed 12% increase in overall potential reach year-over-year.</li></ul>",6398cf842178a2003d2a87df,"As today’s audiences are inundated with more entertainment options than ever before, it’s imperative for them to cut through the noise and speak directly to their target audiences. Leveraging creator partnerships and campaigns can help them accomplish this.

CreatorIQ's latest report looks at how some of the top video streaming providers are faring with their creator marketing strategies, measuring the YoY increase they’ve seen with creator mentions, posts, and overall potential reach through the first three quarters of the year.



 * NBCU saw the greatest increases, with over 60% growth in all categories.
 * Despite minimal increase in creator mentions, Amazon had 36% growth in creator posts, year-over-year.

In particular, what else those audiences are watching beyond electronics content. Some of the more surprising findings: Cuban cuisine (4.3x more likely than the norm), plus a focus on fast-moving things like retro-style cars (4.3x), comets &amp; meteoroids (4.2x) and racing cars (4.1x). Additional insights from Tubular’s electronics infographic:</p><ul><li>3D printing videos are getting a lot of views, but not a lot of uploads, creating an opportunity for 3D printer brands to get a lot of bang for their respective buck on social video.</li><li>Electronics viewers shop for electronics products, sure. Additional insights from Tubular’s electronics infographic:

 * 3D printing videos are getting a lot of views, but not a lot of uploads, creating an opportunity for 3D printer brands to get a lot of bang for their respective buck on social video.

A ""],[0,[0],1,""new Tubular Labs infographic on travel""],[0,[],0,"" shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the insight that travel audiences are watching a lot of videos about beaches and national parks – commanding a majority of supply compared to other videos in the category. ""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Some additional findings from Tubular:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""YouTube views about travel topics are up 29% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 2021-22).""]],[[0,[],0,""Men account for 69% of YouTube travel viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share at 21.7%.""]],[[0,[],0,""Those that watch travel videos also love to do their research – they are 4.5x more likely to watch Travel TV and 3.8x more likely to watch content on Landmarks.""]]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>In the last year, COVID restrictions on traveling have all but cleared up. People are getting back to vacationing like usual, and they’re watching YouTube to decide where to go. A <a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/"">new Tubular Labs infographic on travel</a> shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the insight that travel audiences are watching a lot of videos about beaches and national parks – commanding a majority of supply compared to other videos in the category. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/category-infographics/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-19-at-12.20.52-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1504"" height=""918"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-19-at-12.20.52-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-19-at-12.20.52-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2022/12/Screen-Shot-2022-12-19-at-12.20.52-PM.png 1504w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p>Some additional findings from Tubular:</p><ul><li>YouTube views about travel topics are up 29% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 2021-22).</li><li>Men account for 69% of YouTube travel viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share at 21.7%.</li><li>Those that watch travel videos also love to do their research – they are 4.5x more likely to watch Travel TV and 3.8x more likely to watch content on Landmarks.</li></ul>",63a0c4f974f174003df18828,"In the last year, COVID restrictions on traveling have all but cleared up. People are getting back to vacationing like usual, and they’re watching YouTube to decide where to go. A new Tubular Labs infographic on travel shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors, including the insight that travel audiences are watching a lot of videos about beaches and national parks – commanding a majority of supply compared to other videos in the category.

Some additional findings from Tubular:

 * YouTube views about travel topics are up 29% year-over-year (looking at Oct. 2020-21 vs. Oct. 2021-22).
 * Men account for 69% of YouTube travel viewing, with the 25-to-34 year-old bracket accounting for the largest share at 21.7%.
 * Those that watch travel videos also love to do their research – they are 4.5x more likely to watch Travel TV and 3.8x more likely to watch content on Landmarks.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1602088113235-229c19758e9f?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDl8fHZhY2F0aW9ufGVufDB8fHx8MTY3MTQ4MTQwNA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2022-12-19T20:09:29.000Z,2022-12-21T17:51:14.000Z,2022-12-21T17:51:14.000Z,"A new Tubular Labs infographic on travel shares trends around viewership and consumer behaviors...

The takeaways are fascinating:

6.2 million times an ad aired on TV Jan 1-Dec 15th– that's 17k promos running on TV a day, that's 739 running per hour, or 12 running every minute of every day.

13.7% of all impressions delivered from ads on TV were for networks driving to their properties– for those math nerds that want yo know, that means over 1 TRILLION ad impressions or moments in time Americans saw an ad for a show.

And unlike mobile ads, TV ads have a very high view rate if the viewer makes it past iSpot's 3 second rule to become an impression; 96% of the ad is viewed. That's a lot of time for promos.

None do this more in terms of airings than Discovery and Food Networks which ran 248k promos so far this year- or close to 700 per day! That's a lot of Ice Road Trucking ads!

This of course could go on, but it leads to another bigger question: how do streaming cousins of these networks find the same promo time? The answer can be found on the home screen of TVs.                 </div>
            </a>
        </div>
        ",63ae70e51ac00c003d9f226f,"Ever feel like social video investments win you a spike in viewership but tying results to conversions or brand preference is overwhelming? The vast, evolving universe of social can be difficult for marketers to harness and drive measurable results. Likewise, the end goal isn’t always surface-level success, such as likes & views. There are a variety of different results a marketer would want to drive within each unique phase of the marketing funnel.

Each stage of the funnel has unique objectives and key measurements to ensure an optimal funnel. We will dive into stage-specific goals and accompanying measurements for marketers to deploy.

        ",63ae723f1ac00c003d9f228f,"Brand marketers have to work harder every day to earn brand preference and customer loyalty by cutting through media clutter and creating authentic engagement opportunities.

While this can seem daunting, social video emerges as a channel where marketers can reach coveted audiences, and also learn about them. To create an environment where a customer chooses your brand or product over another—basing decisions on what consumers and audiences do provides a more valuable series of metrics than what people say. If a person says they like a brand, but don’t actually purchase from it, is that knowledge valuable?

 * As always, delicious food gets consumers interested — seven of the top 20 TV ads by likeability in 2022 were from QSR or casual dining brands.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1623387641168-d9803ddd3f35?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDN8fHBldHN8ZW58MHx8fHwxNjcyOTQzNzAw&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-01-05T18:34:28.000Z,2023-01-05T18:35:47.000Z,2023-01-05T18:35:47.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63b7189e1ac00c003d9f248c,416f6b97-da16-48ce-8893-6fd3b57c0038,Grey’s Anatomy Still The Hottest Show For Music Searches,greys-anatomy-still-the-hottest-show-for-music-searches,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/01/tvrev-tunefind--1-.jpeg"",""width"":1000,""height"":508,""href"":""http://songtradr.com/""}]],""markups"":[[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""http://tunefind.com/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.songtradr.com/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Say what you will about ""],[0,[0],1,""Grey’s Anatomy""],[0,[],0,"", but the show has its fans – and music searchers, as end-of-year data from ""],[0,[1],1,""Tunefind""],[0,[],0,"" (a ""],[0,[2],1,""Songtradr""],[0,[],0,"" company) recently revealed. ""],[0,[0],1,""Grey’s Anatomy""],[0,[],0,"" had 1% more music searches on Tunefind in 2022 than HBO hit ""],[0,[0],1,""Euphoria""],[0,[],0,"" to continue its hot streak as the top show on the platform. However, Euphoria’s searches came from a wider range of viewers – 44% more uniques than Grey’s.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Among new shows, ""],[0,[0],1,""Power Book IV: Force""],[0,[],0,"" (on Starz) actually takes the cake, followed by HBO’s ""],[0,[0],1,""Peacemaker""],[0,[],0,"".""]],[[0,[],0,""No single channel or streaming service is driving music searches more than others, with ABC, HBO, Netflix, Paramount Network, NBC, Hulu and Amazon Prime Video all appearing — though obviously ABC and HBO get substantial boosts from having the top two shows.""]],[[0,[],0,""Speaking of, Euphoria actually accounted for five of the top 10 individual TV songs on Tunefind in 2022, led by “I’m Tired” by Labrinth and Zendaya.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Say what you will about <em>Grey’s Anatomy</em>, but the show has its fans – and music searchers, as end-of-year data from <a href=""http://tunefind.com/"">Tunefind</a> (a <a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/"">Songtradr</a> company) recently revealed. <em>Grey’s Anatomy</em> had 1% more music searches on Tunefind in 2022 than HBO hit <em>Euphoria</em> to continue its hot streak as the top show on the platform. However, Euphoria’s searches came from a wider range of viewers – 44% more uniques than Grey’s.</p><ul><li>Among new shows, <em>Power Book IV: Force</em> (on Starz) actually takes the cake, followed by HBO’s <em>Peacemaker</em>.</li><li>No single channel or streaming service is driving music searches more than others, with ABC, HBO, Netflix, Paramount Network, NBC, Hulu and Amazon Prime Video all appearing — though obviously ABC and HBO get substantial boosts from having the top two shows.</li><li>Speaking of, Euphoria actually accounted for five of the top 10 individual TV songs on Tunefind in 2022, led by “I’m Tired” by Labrinth and Zendaya.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://songtradr.com/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/01/tvrev-tunefind--1-.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1000"" height=""508"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/01/tvrev-tunefind--1-.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/01/tvrev-tunefind--1-.jpeg 1000w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",63b7189e1ac00c003d9f248c,"Say what you will about Grey’s Anatomy, but the show has its fans – and music searchers, as end-of-year data from Tunefind (a Songtradr company) recently revealed. Grey’s Anatomy had 1% more music searches on Tunefind in 2022 than HBO hit Euphoria to continue its hot streak as the top show on the platform. However, Euphoria’s searches came from a wider range of viewers – 44% more uniques than Grey’s.

 * Among new shows, Power Book IV: Force (on Starz) actually takes the cake, followed by HBO’s Peacemaker.
 * No single channel or streaming service is driving music searches more than others, with ABC, HBO, Netflix, Paramount Network, NBC, Hulu and Amazon Prime Video all appearing — though obviously ABC and HBO get substantial boosts from having the top two shows.
 * Speaking of, Euphoria actually accounted for five of the top 10 individual TV songs on Tunefind in 2022, led by “I’m Tired” by Labrinth and Zendaya.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1458560871784-56d23406c091?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDd8fG11c2ljfGVufDB8fHx8MTY3Mjk0MzgwNA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-01-05T18:36:14.000Z,2023-01-05T18:37:33.000Z,2023-01-05T18:37:33.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63b8500a1ac00c003d9f24c8,b2786167-bd43-42d4-8ec4-9173a23e1d2a,Shorts Ruled 2022 On YouTube (Plus More Social Video Takeaways From Last Year),shorts-ruled-2022-on-youtube-plus-more-social-video-takeaways-from-last-year,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""embed"",{""url"":""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JfbnpYLe3Ms"",""html"":""<iframe width=\""200\"" height=\""113\"" src=\""https://www.youtube.com/embed/JfbnpYLe3Ms?feature=oembed\"" frameborder=\""0\"" allow=\""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\"" allowfullscreen title=\""If Cleaning Was a Timed Sport. According to its Consumer Insights product, over 20% of Ugg.com visitors watched holiday content on social video.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/blog/2022-social-video-rewind/"">To wrap up 2022</a>, Tubular Labs assembled a lengthy collection of insights from the year in social video trends, top videos, creators and more. It’s worth digging into the entire “rewind” piece on the company’s blog, but as social video continues to grow — and even rival TV in some age groups — we wanted to pull out some of the biggest takeaways from 2022 below.</p><p><strong><strong>Shorts Are Tall For YouTube Creators</strong></strong></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-embed-card""><iframe width=""200"" height=""113"" src=""https://www.youtube.com/embed/JfbnpYLe3Ms?feature=oembed"" frameborder=""0"" allow=""accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share"" allowfullscreen title=""If Cleaning Was a Timed Sport.
