Some of the most notable:</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/MrBeast-Overlap.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1378"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/02/MrBeast-Overlap.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/02/MrBeast-Overlap.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/MrBeast-Overlap.jpg 1378w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><ul><li>The NFL <a href=""https://twitter.com/NFL/status/1624905321096544256"">also activated MrBeast at the game</a>, clad in Chiefs gear, to speak to his younger-skewing fan base. While sports leagues and teams have been trying to find new ways to speak to younger audiences with social content, over 43% of MrBeast’s YouTube audience is in the 13-to-24 age range, and 67% are 34 or younger.</li><li>This approach with MrBeast highlights what’s next for leagues and networks as they evolve audience acquisition strategies to include the creator economy in a natural way.</li></ul>",63ee7a66398ebb004d0f8c35,"Among the surprises during this year’s Super Bowl was an appearance by MrBeast in the NFL’s “Run With It” ad.  * The NFL also activated MrBeast at the game, clad in Chiefs gear, to speak to his younger-skewing fan base. While sports leagues and teams have been trying to find new ways to speak to younger audiences with social content, over 43% of MrBeast’s YouTube audience is in the 13-to-24 age range, and 67% are 34 or younger.

 * The 2023 Daytona 500 zooms into seventh place for the week with 0.80% of watch-time, just slightly behind NBA basketball (0.81%).
 * Thanks to a weekend rerun marathon on Paramount Network, Yellowstone jumps into the ranking at No. 8, capturing 0.73% of all minutes watched during the week. The marathon helped Paramount Network jump up the network ranking, moving from No. 29 the previous week to No. 18, with 1.28% of network watch-time.

",,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63f50de17cb44c004dd0ac84,c75826ec-fd39-4962-ad9b-733151cc5443,Loyalty Programs Emerge As Key Recession-Fighting Tactic,loyalty-programs-emerge-as-key-recession-fighting-tactic,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/dw8RDXsl2ny9lI7B2HV40HS3FWZWzIvCwDwF1_NKJai2nXgd9I4Rn8b1fx4qug0pqkhIzKn-djQCeNcwFe2wDFTShgniJUhuOjJ1J2J4pQ515rJplCwA8yllHp7HtbKWLvns5kN5D1gZRuSgDM2gjfg"",""width"":603,""height"":330}]],""markups"":[[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://go.meetmarigold.com/consumer-trends-index-usa?utm_source=newswire&utm_medium=fabric&utm_content=press-release&utm_term=cti23&1-campaign-language=en&2-campaign-name=pr&3-campaign-year=2023&utm_campaign=newswire--press-releases""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""Marigold research shows loyalty program participation is on the rise right when consumers, and businesses, need them most.""]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0],[0,[],0,""Marigold released a U.S.-focused version of its 2023 Digital Consumer Trends Index report that showcased some important data for businesses hoping to keep consumers engaged amid the threat of a looming recession. ""],[1,[],0,1]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,2]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Additional findings include:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""72% of consumers are ready to pay more to buy from preferred brands (which is 31% higher than the global results), while 25% of consumers who abandoned a preferred brand in the past 12 months cited poor loyalty programs as the core problem.""]],[[0,[],0,""Most U.S. consumers want personalized content and offers from trusted brands and will share personal data to get it, with 75% of U.S. consumers comfortable sharing behavioral data in return for better service.""]],[[0,[],0,""Over half of U.S. consumers (55%) purchased a product directly as a result of an email they received in the last 12 months.""]],[[0,[],0,""Over half (57%) of U.S. consumers find retargeting ads to be creepy, and nearly a third (32%) are glad cookies are being withdrawn soon. ""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[1],1,""For more insights, download the full report""],[1,[],0,3]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><em>Marigold research shows loyalty program participation is on the rise right when consumers, and businesses, need them most.</em></p><p><br>Marigold released a U.S.-focused version of its 2023 Digital Consumer Trends Index report that showcased some important data for businesses hoping to keep consumers engaged amid the threat of a looming recession. </p><p>According to the report, 52% of U.S. consumers are more likely to engage in a loyalty program this year than last. That stat rose to 57% for Gen X consumers and 67% for Millennials. That’s good news for businesses who offer them because more than half (53%) of Millennials and Gen X respondents plan to rely on loyalty program benefits when making purchases. <br></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/dw8RDXsl2ny9lI7B2HV40HS3FWZWzIvCwDwF1_NKJai2nXgd9I4Rn8b1fx4qug0pqkhIzKn-djQCeNcwFe2wDFTShgniJUhuOjJ1J2J4pQ515rJplCwA8yllHp7HtbKWLvns5kN5D1gZRuSgDM2gjfg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""603"" height=""330""></figure><p><br></p><p>Additional findings include:</p><ul><li>72% of consumers are ready to pay more to buy from preferred brands (which is 31% higher than the global results), while 25% of consumers who abandoned a preferred brand in the past 12 months cited poor loyalty programs as the core problem.</li><li>Most U.S. consumers want personalized content and offers from trusted brands and will share personal data to get it, with 75% of U.S. consumers comfortable sharing behavioral data in return for better service.</li><li>Over half of U.S. consumers (55%) purchased a product directly as a result of an email they received in the last 12 months.</li><li>Over half (57%) of U.S. consumers find retargeting ads to be creepy, and nearly a third (32%) are glad cookies are being withdrawn soon. </li></ul><p><a href=""https://go.meetmarigold.com/consumer-trends-index-usa?utm_source=newswire&amp;utm_medium=fabric&amp;utm_content=press-release&amp;utm_term=cti23&amp;1-campaign-language=en&amp;2-campaign-name=pr&amp;3-campaign-year=2023&amp;utm_campaign=newswire--press-releases"">For more insights, download the full report</a><br></p>",63f50de17cb44c004dd0ac84,"Marigold research shows loyalty program participation is on the rise right when consumers, and businesses, need them most.


Marigold released a U.S.-focused version of its 2023 Digital Consumer Trends Index report that showcased some important data for businesses hoping to keep consumers engaged amid the threat of a looming recession.

According to the report, 52% of U.S. consumers are more likely to engage in a loyalty program this year than last. That stat rose to 57% for Gen X consumers and 67% for Millennials. That’s good news for businesses who offer them because more than half (53%) of Millennials and Gen X respondents plan to rely on loyalty program benefits when making purchases.





Additional findings include:

 * 72% of consumers are ready to pay more to buy from preferred brands (which is 31% higher than the global results), while 25% of consumers who abandoned a preferred brand in the past 12 months cited poor loyalty programs as the core problem.
 * Most U.S. consumers want personalized content and offers from trusted brands and will share personal data to get it, with 75% of U.S. consumers comfortable sharing behavioral data in return for better service.
 * Over half of U.S. consumers (55%) purchased a product directly as a result of an email they received in the last 12 months.
 * Over half (57%) of U.S. consumers find retargeting ads to be creepy, and nearly a third (32%) are glad cookies are being withdrawn soon.

For more insights, download the full report
",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/CTI-US-Measure.png,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-02-21T18:30:57.000Z,2023-02-22T19:45:05.000Z,2023-02-22T19:44:22.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63f617a57cb44c004dd0acaa,d5c13e33-d759-4816-ac78-b97f142cac53,Amazon Scores Big With Super Bowl Spot,amazon-scores-big-with-super-bowl-spot,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/Kyxg_aD8jeys43QjLCtIs-4v1N9_hY9LGthBOFp6jZhVddJH7W8tJhXfkk454RlVd0kDW8xU_6qyepELOQLzk6UBx5htW7b-bf9BHo0-xI2JlofWRGvfzMgkRS1thooSD9rHHwp9uE34ufiiyHKKDDs"",""width"":493,""height"":313}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-bueUljGJ2M&ab_channel=amazon""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/brands-and-creators-who-won-super-bowl""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""When it came to social impressions for brands advertising in Super Bowl LVII, Amazon dominated the playing field: According to CreatorIQ, it generated a hefty 1.3 billion impressions thanks to its heartfelt spot “""],[0,[0],1,""Saving Sawyer""],[0,[],0,"",” featuring a lovable pup. The tech giant received a notable amount of buzz among dog-loving fans, which helped drive 40K mentions. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Paramount+ was the runner-up for impressions, generating 105 million thanks to a commercial featuring Sylvester Stallone and signature characters from the streaming services including Dora the Explore and Beavis and Butt-Head.""]],[[0,[],0,""Stallone promoted the campaign on his personal Instagram account, resulting in 909K views and 132.4K engagements, per CreatorIQ.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""You can download CreatorIQ’s full ""],[0,[1],1,""Super Bowl report here""],[0,[],0,"".""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>When it came to social impressions for brands advertising in Super Bowl LVII, Amazon dominated the playing field: According to CreatorIQ, it generated a hefty 1.3 billion impressions thanks to its heartfelt spot “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-bueUljGJ2M&amp;ab_channel=amazon"">Saving Sawyer</a>,” featuring a lovable pup. The tech giant received a notable amount of buzz among dog-loving fans, which helped drive 40K mentions. </p><ul><li>Paramount+ was the runner-up for impressions, generating 105 million thanks to a commercial featuring Sylvester Stallone and signature characters from the streaming services including Dora the Explore and Beavis and Butt-Head.</li><li>Stallone promoted the campaign on his personal Instagram account, resulting in 909K views and 132.4K engagements, per CreatorIQ.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/Kyxg_aD8jeys43QjLCtIs-4v1N9_hY9LGthBOFp6jZhVddJH7W8tJhXfkk454RlVd0kDW8xU_6qyepELOQLzk6UBx5htW7b-bf9BHo0-xI2JlofWRGvfzMgkRS1thooSD9rHHwp9uE34ufiiyHKKDDs"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""493"" height=""313""></figure><p>You can download CreatorIQ’s full <a href=""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/brands-and-creators-who-won-super-bowl"">Super Bowl report here</a>.</p>",63f617a57cb44c004dd0acaa,"When it came to social impressions for brands advertising in Super Bowl LVII, Amazon dominated the playing field: According to CreatorIQ, it generated a hefty 1.3 billion impressions thanks to its heartfelt spot “Saving Sawyer,” featuring a lovable pup. The tech giant received a notable amount of buzz among dog-loving fans, which helped drive 40K mentions.

 * Paramount+ was the runner-up for impressions, generating 105 million thanks to a commercial featuring Sylvester Stallone and signature characters from the streaming services including Dora the Explore and Beavis and Butt-Head.
 * Stallone promoted the campaign on his personal Instagram account, resulting in 909K views and 132.4K engagements, per CreatorIQ.

A second recipe face-off video, “""],[0,[16],1,""I Made AI Cookies""],[0,[],0,"",” which he posted on Jan. 6, has 19K views. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Of course, this is just the beginning. As more people experiment with ChatGPT — and more companies and brands start to harness the power of AI — we’re sure to see even more growth within the landscape…for better or worse.""],[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>OpenAI’s ChatGPT has brought Artificial Intelligence (AI) – often relegated to the science and technology set  – into the forefront of coffee table consciousness. In short, a chatbot that can do everything from penning a 6th grader’s report on Alexander Hamilton to writing concertos, is having its cultural moment.</p><p>According to research from <a href=""http://creatoriq.com"">CreatorIQ</a>, the largest end-to-end influencer platform, Instagram, TikTok and YouTube posts with hashtags such as #ChatGPT, #OpenAI, #AI and/or #ArtificialIntelligence have accumulated a massive 83M engagements and 732M video views over the last 14 months, with things really heating up upon the launch of OpenAI’s ChatGPT in November 2022. </p><p>In total, there have been 30.3K posts across 14.3K social accounts mentioning these hashtags since January 2022. All in all, creators posting such content have an aggregate total of 3.6 billion followers across those channels — a massive reach that has surely helped elevate ChatGPT into mainstream consciousness.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/qh0NZYqfOfpedmDwzolx6CaChpfFCSZFn8z3Dp8VyixveOH2KGgUUUESHCE9oggxgHEahLUbDmdt_MoGdUV1AcwEjpvZX6CUS3Vu2uBOi9vp4FgMATq8XlSoPzqYPeBJu9HsmqC6hDxSF8hp_KY3nQw"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""624"" height=""384""></figure><p>Brands are getting into the Chat game too. Of the 14.3K social accounts talking about this, 102 were brands. In the last six months alone, big names like <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cn6aHW_I1uv/"">BMW</a>, <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/reel/CmXYrZlDRzC/"">Urban Decay</a>, <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/@tripadvisor/video/7177055029549976874"">Trip Advisor</a>, <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cn2WNlGM38j/"">Cricket Wireless</a>, <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/p/CoENX5bNkte/"">Gartner</a>, and <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ftVj2pMKU10"">WebMD</a> have posted about AI/ChatGPT. More recently, Coke has launched “<a href=""https://adage.com/article/marketing-news-strategy/coke-wants-fans-use-chatgpt-and-dall-e-create-brand-artwork-coke-invites-fans-create-brand-artwork/2480386"">Create Real Magic</a>,” a campaign that invites people to create digital art using AI tools DALL-E and ChatGPT with some of the brand’s iconic logos and visuals.</p><p>In terms of specific creators, the AI groundswell has been a boon for those looking to expand their audiences.</p><p><a href=""https://www.youtube.com/c/AdrianTwarog"">Adrian Twarog</a> has been sharing web design and development tips on YouTube since 2020, and jumped on the ChatGPT bandwagon on Dec. 10, 2022, posting “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=40Kp_fa8vIw"">What is ChatGPT and How You Can Use It</a>.”</p><p>Eight of the ten videos Twarog has posted since Dec. 10 have been ChatGPT-related, with “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JTxsNm9IdYU"">ChatGPT Tutorial - A Crash Course on Chat GPT for Beginners</a>” as his most-viewed video ever, with over 4.8 million views. According to <a href=""http://www.tubularlabs.com"">Tubular Labs</a>, with 1.6 million views occurring in the first 30 days per Tubular V30 rating.</p><p>Twarog’s overall audience has grown significantly: According to CreatorIQ, he’s had a 60% growth in YouTube subscribers since November, and an astounding 794% increase in monthly views.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><img src=""https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/QCWZWM5dhDXfKkAZ65n-tuLaWR63ZaqrdmvPk9km5Bk84L_59LLEr3yoPmUpLCxVetHGMDA8tsSvbtMd7SJAS2WPcIuix-S6P4_8gC3u2kourEZ6Vui5xbpmH5oWnD0hMGXmVJ2pUwr0MDNYr9bCpPI"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""624"" height=""229""><figcaption>Via CreatorIQ</figcaption></figure><p>YouTuber<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/c/NickWhite""> Nick White</a>, who shares videos about coding, also benefited from a ChatGPT bump: His “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ng438SIXyW4"">How I Coded an Entire Website Using ChatGPT</a>” published in early January led to a huge spike in monthly views, with his January view total 332.3% higher than the average of the five previous months per CreatorIQ.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><img src=""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/CpURerf44zgd5bVWCOpYAuUpvXlgowd3mmLpZN2Sqx3Dn9LFsYB3XzsecU7tBP5WQAG3UpI05_0xbM73F0y89G2uNXiJLvhO-hUV3rLv2R-Z7z96LRDLlugfkGV6zUGfUB7mdK8DsVu6xYdprCtME2E"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""624"" height=""229""><figcaption>Via CreatorIQ</figcaption></figure><p>It’s not all tutorials - creators are having fun with AI too, like food influencer Patrick Zeinali, whose “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2xrz3O0nINo"">Robot Vs Human Bake Off</a>” has generated over 38 million views since it was posted on Dec. 12, 18.4 million of which occurred in the first 30 days per Tubular’s V30 rating. <em>Spoiler alert: Don’t let ChatGPT make your Thanksgiving dinner. </em>This video is Zeinali’s fourth most-watched video. A second recipe face-off video, “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7XtzYSt6X4Q"">I Made AI Cookies</a>,” which he posted on Jan. 6, has 19K views. </p><p>Of course, this is just the beginning. As more people experiment with ChatGPT — and more companies and brands start to harness the power of AI — we’re sure to see even more growth within the landscape…for better or worse.<br></p>",63f781377cb44c004dd0ad40,"OpenAI’s ChatGPT has brought Artificial Intelligence (AI) – often relegated to the science and technology set  – into the forefront of coffee table consciousness. In short, a chatbot that can do everything from penning a 6th grader’s report on Alexander Hamilton to writing concertos, is having its cultural moment.

According to research from CreatorIQ, the largest end-to-end influencer platform, Instagram, TikTok and YouTube posts with hashtags such as #ChatGPT, #OpenAI, #AI and/or #ArtificialIntelligence have accumulated a massive 83M engagements and 732M video views over the last 14 months, with things really heating up upon the launch of OpenAI’s ChatGPT in November 2022.

In total, there have been 30.3K posts across 14.3K social accounts mentioning these hashtags since January 2022. All in all, creators posting such content have an aggregate total of 3.6 billion followers across those channels — a massive reach that has surely helped elevate ChatGPT into mainstream consciousness.

Brands are getting into the Chat game too. Of the 14.3K social accounts talking about this, 102 were brands. In the last six months alone, big names like BMW, Urban Decay, Trip Advisor, Cricket Wireless, Gartner, and WebMD have posted about AI/ChatGPT. More recently, Coke has launched “Create Real Magic,” a campaign that invites people to create digital art using AI tools DALL-E and ChatGPT with some of the brand’s iconic logos and visuals.

In terms of specific creators, the AI groundswell has been a boon for those looking to expand their audiences.

Adrian Twarog has been sharing web design and development tips on YouTube since 2020, and jumped on the ChatGPT bandwagon on Dec. 10, 2022, posting “What is ChatGPT and How You Can Use It.”

Eight of the ten videos Twarog has posted since Dec. 10 have been ChatGPT-related, with “ChatGPT Tutorial - A Crash Course on Chat GPT for Beginners” as his most-viewed video ever, with over 4.8 million views. According to Tubular Labs, with 1.6 million views occurring in the first 30 days per Tubular V30 rating.

Twarog’s overall audience has grown significantly: According to CreatorIQ, he’s had a 60% growth in YouTube subscribers since November, and an astounding 794% increase in monthly views.

YouTuber Nick White, who shares videos about coding, also benefited from a ChatGPT bump: His “How I Coded an Entire Website Using ChatGPT” published in early January led to a huge spike in monthly views, with his January view total 332.3% higher than the average of the five previous months per CreatorIQ.

It’s not all tutorials - creators are having fun with AI too, like food influencer Patrick Zeinali, whose “Robot Vs Human Bake Off” has generated over 38 million views since it was posted on Dec. 12, 18.4 million of which occurred in the first 30 days per Tubular’s V30 rating. Spoiler alert: Don’t let ChatGPT make your Thanksgiving dinner. This video is Zeinali’s fourth most-watched video. A second recipe face-off video, “I Made AI Cookies,” which he posted on Jan. 6, has 19K views.

Of course, this is just the beginning. As more people experiment with ChatGPT — and more companies and brands start to harness the power of AI — we’re sure to see even more growth within the landscape…for better or worse.
",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1675557009875-436f71457475?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDZ8fGNoYXRncHR8ZW58MHx8fHwxNjc3MTY1MzQw&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-02-23T15:07:35.000Z,2023-04-24T14:10:05.000Z,2023-04-24T14:10:05.000Z,Creators and brands are harnessing the cultural moment that ChatGPT is having to capture new audiences. ,,,,,,1,63f7b8b37cb44c004dd0ad7a,e0b709eb-b33c-40de-8b61-0c8e50d16339,Capital One Finds Perfect Match With Taylor Swift Fandom,capital-one-finds-perfect-match-with-taylor-swift-fandom,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/copy-copy-copy-ispot-syndicated-shows.jpeg"",""width"":1378,""height"":767}]],""markups"":[[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/2S2s/capital-one-venture-x-card-multiple-taylors-featuring-taylor-swift-spanish""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://ispot.tv/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://songtradr.com/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Taylor Swift’s ""],[0,[0],1,""Midnights""],[0,[],0,"" was released on Oct. 21, and Capital One wasted no time using the star and hit song “Anti-Hero” in its TV advertising. And the continued play for the single surely sparks thoughts of Capital One as well.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The brand’s music selection approach was a strategic one here. While Capital One certainly paid a premium to both have Swift appear and license “Anti-Hero,” there are few artists that are as sure of a bet to stay relevant over the course of an extended ad campaign. Songtradr data shows the song has been above the 90th percentile by Spotify popularity nearly every day since its release, and that consistency won’t let up until another Swift song makes the rounds as one of the platform’s top singles again.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Taylor Swift’s <em>Midnights</em> was released on Oct. 21, and Capital One wasted no time using the star and hit song “Anti-Hero” in its TV advertising. The brand’s “<a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/2S2s/capital-one-venture-x-card-multiple-taylors-featuring-taylor-swift-spanish"">Multiple Taylors</a>” spot burst onto the scene on Nov. 1, and in the time since, it’s the second-most-seen credit card ad on TV, according to <a href=""http://ispot.tv/"">iSpot</a>.</p><p>Banking on “Anti-Hero’s” long tail popularity appears to be paying off for Capital One as well for the brand to build affinity with Swift’s rabid fan base (and others as well). Data from <a href=""http://songtradr.com/"">Songtradr</a> shows the song is still No. 15 in the U.S. on Spotify over 17 weeks after its release. And the continued play for the single surely sparks thoughts of Capital One as well.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/copy-copy-copy-ispot-syndicated-shows.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1378"" height=""767"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/02/copy-copy-copy-ispot-syndicated-shows.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/02/copy-copy-copy-ispot-syndicated-shows.jpeg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/copy-copy-copy-ispot-syndicated-shows.jpeg 1378w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p>The brand’s music selection approach was a strategic one here. The brand’s “Multiple Taylors” spot burst onto the scene on Nov. 1, and in the time since, it’s the second-most-seen credit card ad on TV, according to iSpot.

Banking on “Anti-Hero’s” long tail popularity appears to be paying off for Capital One as well for the brand to build affinity with Swift’s rabid fan base (and others as well). Data from Songtradr shows the song is still No. 15 in the U.S. on Spotify over 17 weeks after its release. And the continued play for the single surely sparks thoughts of Capital One as well.

The brand’s music selection approach was a strategic one here. While Capital One certainly paid a premium to both have Swift appear and license “Anti-Hero,” there are few artists that are as sure of a bet to stay relevant over the course of an extended ad campaign. Songtradr data shows the song has been above the 90th percentile by Spotify popularity nearly every day since its release, and that consistency won’t let up until another Swift song makes the rounds as one of the platform’s top singles again.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/capital-one-venture-x-card-multiple-taylors-featuring-taylor-swift-spanish-large-5.jpeg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-02-23T19:04:19.000Z,2023-02-23T19:07:11.000Z,2023-02-22T19:05:00.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,63fce9e27cb44c004dd0adef,62e8c7a6-e832-46b9-8f0f-a6062e00126c,K18 Leveraged the Power of #HairTok to Generate $32.9 Million in Earned Media Value,k18-leveraged-the-power-of-hairtok-to-generate-32-8-million-in-earned-media-value,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}],[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/UMWiWqSUc9y5KFMljifKbjWZt4EXh4q475-Pfttl8tUpt7OyTEInVHlYX5Du-J8OQG-L-XAn3WTpsplM4zAWffHpgaJAIuUBx8bp6_-E8GFyjjIwFKaRCw49mWYHv9GlvlcZjOowINs0vkzR1vPQp3c"",""width"":624,""height"":485,""caption"":""Via CreatorIQ""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.creatoriq.com/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tiktok.com/@alixearle""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""According to a new report from ""],[0,[0],1,""CreatorIQ""],[0,[],0,"", K18 Hair was January’s top haircare brand in the US based on earned media value* (EMV), with an astounding $32.9 million — 4X the EMV total of any other haircare brand for the month. That represented a 430% month-over-month growth and a 488% year-over-year increase in EMV. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The brand’s success was propelled by #HairTok, with its No. 1 hashtag #K18Results fueling an impressive $27.1M EMV. Also helping drive K18’s impressive results was the brand’s decision to send select creators a sample of their products, along with a pamphlet, and it also partnered with TikTok star creator ""],[0,[1],1,""Alix Earle""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""More from the report:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""MielleOrganics was one month-over-month ranking newcomer, landing at No. 8 with $3.1 million EMV. K18Hair had the most — 3,694, over twice that of Olaplex and Redken.""]],[[0,[],0,""The top five tools, wigs & extensions brands were Dyson Haircare ($12.6 million EMV), Framar ($4.7 million), ghd ($4 million), Bellami ($2 million) and BaByliss ($1.8 million).""],[1,[],0,0]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[2],1,""*Earned media value (EMV) quantifies the estimated value of consumer engagement with digital earned media and can be used to evaluate the earned performance of individual marketing campaigns and benchmark brands within the competitive landscape.""]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,1]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>According to a new report from <a href=""https://www.creatoriq.com/"">CreatorIQ</a>, K18 Hair was January’s top haircare brand in the US based on earned media value* (EMV), with an astounding $32.9 million — 4X the EMV total of any other haircare brand for the month. That represented a 430% month-over-month growth and a 488% year-over-year increase in EMV. </p><p>The brand’s success was propelled by #HairTok, with its No. 1 hashtag #K18Results fueling an impressive $27.1M EMV. Also helping drive K18’s impressive results was the brand’s decision to send select creators a sample of their products, along with a pamphlet, and it also partnered with TikTok star creator <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/@alixearle"">Alix Earle</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><img src=""https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/UMWiWqSUc9y5KFMljifKbjWZt4EXh4q475-Pfttl8tUpt7OyTEInVHlYX5Du-J8OQG-L-XAn3WTpsplM4zAWffHpgaJAIuUBx8bp6_-E8GFyjjIwFKaRCw49mWYHv9GlvlcZjOowINs0vkzR1vPQp3c"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""624"" height=""485""><figcaption>Via CreatorIQ</figcaption></figure><p>More from the report:</p><ul><li>MielleOrganics was one month-over-month ranking newcomer, landing at No. 8 with $3.1 million EMV. The brand benefited from buzz around its acquisition by P&amp;G, inspiring its 486 new creators to power $2.6M EMV – 82% of the brand’s January total.</li><li>K18 Hair, Olaplex and Redken were the only three brands out of the top ten that had over 1,000 ambassadors. K18Hair had the most — 3,694, over twice that of Olaplex and Redken.</li><li>The top five tools, wigs &amp; extensions brands were Dyson Haircare ($12.6 million EMV), Framar ($4.7 million), ghd ($4 million), Bellami ($2 million) and BaByliss ($1.8 million).<br></li></ul><p><em>*Earned media value (EMV) quantifies the estimated value of consumer engagement with digital earned media and can be used to evaluate the earned performance of individual marketing campaigns and benchmark brands within the competitive landscape.</em></p>",63fce9e27cb44c004dd0adef,"According to a new report from CreatorIQ, K18 Hair was January’s top haircare brand in the US based on earned media value* (EMV), with an astounding $32.9 million — 4X the EMV total of any other haircare brand for the month. That represented a 430% month-over-month growth and a 488% year-over-year increase in EMV.

The brand’s success was propelled by #HairTok, with its No. 1 hashtag #K18Results fueling an impressive $27.1M EMV. Also helping drive K18’s impressive results was the brand’s decision to send select creators a sample of their products, along with a pamphlet, and it also partnered with TikTok star creator Alix Earle.

More from the report:

 * MielleOrganics was one month-over-month ranking newcomer, landing at No. 8 with $3.1 million EMV. The brand benefited from buzz around its acquisition by P&G, inspiring its 486 new creators to power $2.6M EMV – 82% of the brand’s January total.
 * K18 Hair, Olaplex and Redken were the only three brands out of the top ten that had over 1,000 ambassadors. K18Hair had the most — 3,694, over twice that of Olaplex and Redken.
 * The top five tools, wigs & extensions brands were Dyson Haircare ($12.6 million EMV), Framar ($4.7 million), ghd ($4 million), Bellami ($2 million) and BaByliss ($1.8 million).

For the week of Feb. 20-26, men's college basketball took first place with 2.37% of watch-time, followed by NBA basketball (1.38%).  </p><ul><li>Two shows in the <em>Chicago</em> franchise make notable jumps up the chart: <em>Chicago Fire</em> moves into ninth place from No. 9 previously with 0.63% of minutes watched, while <em>Chicago P.D.</em> jumps from No. 25 to No. 12 (0.57%).</li><li><em>Homestead Rescue </em>makes an appearance at No. 21, capturing 0.43% of all minutes watched thanks to two rerun marathons on Discovery Channel. The show, which hasn’t aired new episodes since 2021, has its season ten premiere on Feb. 28.</li><li>Looking at the network ranking, ABC scores first place with nearly 7% of minutes watched, up from No. 2 the previous week. </li></ul><p>Get more insights and see the <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/basketball-scores-for-watch-time-tv-by-the-numbers"">full rankings at TVREV.com</a>. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/InscapeTopShowsFeb20-26.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/02/InscapeTopShowsFeb20-26.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/02/InscapeTopShowsFeb20-26.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/02/InscapeTopShowsFeb20-26.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",63fe21ccbccee0003d672cc2,"Each week, Inscape's TV By the Numbers rankings reveal the most-watched shows and networks based on live, linear minutes watched. ",,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,640269a4f784d9003d1efb25,fbc69aae-3474-478d-878c-a5e5bbbb2af0,Paul vs. Fury: How Influencer Boxers Can Punch Up Fight Viewership,paul-vs-fury-how-influencer-boxers-can-punch-up-fight-viewership,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/FuryIG--1-.png"",""width"":1500,""height"":391,""caption"":""<em>Instagram stats for Tommy Fury as of Feb. 28, via CreatorIQ</em>"",""href"":""http://creatoriq.com/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://twitter.com/WBCBoxing/status/1628870500356132864""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://twitter.com/WBCBoxing/status/1629992031186501632""]],[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.sportingnews.com/us/boxing/news/jake-paul-vs-tommy-fury-timeline-rivalry-youtuber-boxer/g7f5bmcp12996v86nim1c0qm""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://creatoriq.com/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://twitter.com/jakepaul/status/1628431499233042432""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://twitter.com/BTSportBoxing/status/1628068603642761216""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The Feb. 26 boxing match between Tommy Fury and Jake Paul is one of the best examples yet of how social media clout can turn into real-world results. The fight, which took place in Saudi Arabia and was available to watch via pay-per-view, drew a global audience — and you can be sure the people watching weren’t just boxing enthusiasts. One reason it was so hotly anticipated is due to the influencer status Fury and Paul both hold, something the World Boxing Council ""],[0,[0],1,""publicly recognized before""],[0,[],0,"" as well as ""],[0,[1],1,""after the fight""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Paul made a name for himself as a YouTube star years ago, while Fury has been boxing professionally since 2018 and was a contestant on season five of ""],[0,[2],1,""Love Island UK""],[0,[],0,"". And not only that, their rivalry ""],[0,[3],1,""has been going on for years""],[0,[],0,"", with two previously scheduled fights having been canceled for various reasons only fueling the fire.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Fury may have a bit more experience under his belt, but Paul is punching higher when it comes to social audiences: According to ""],[0,[4],1,""CreatorIQ""],[0,[],0,"", he has 70.1 million followers across social media platforms, compared to Fury’s 5.5 million. The highly publicized fight spurred social audience growth for both: Paul saw a modest increase of 0.43% in followers compared to the week before the bout, while Fury saw a notable 10% growth.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Instagram is the most popular platform for both, and while Paul boasts 22.3 million followers there compared to Fury’s 4.9 million, Fury has him beat for engagement, with an engagement rate of 7.26%, which CreatorIQ considers “excellent,” compared to Paul’s “good” 1.48%.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Both used their social followings to promote the match and drive tune-in, with Paul in particular not pulling any punches: Mere days before the fight, he escalated the rivalry, ""],[0,[5],1,""posting a video to Twitter""],[0,[],0,"" and Instagram utterly ripping into Fury, proclaiming “This is it, you’re going to be retired from boxing after this.”""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""And earlier in the week ""],[0,[6],1,""during an interview""],[0,[],0,"", Paul referred to Fury’s girlfriend Molly-Mae Hague as the “breadwinner” in their relationship. Well, from a social angle he’s not wrong: Hague, an influencer herself, has 12.3 million followers across social platforms, and an “excellent” Instagram engagement rate of 11.5%, per CreatorIQ — far beyond either Fury or Paul.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Of course, in the end Fury emerged victorious with a split-decision win after eight rounds. But that’s certainly not the last of it: There was a rematch clause in the contract, and Paul already said he intends to make it happen.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>The Feb. 26 boxing match between Tommy Fury and Jake Paul is one of the best examples yet of how social media clout can turn into real-world results. The fight, which took place in Saudi Arabia and was available to watch via pay-per-view, drew a global audience — and you can be sure the people watching weren’t just boxing enthusiasts. One reason it was so hotly anticipated is due to the influencer status Fury and Paul both hold, something the World Boxing Council <a href=""https://twitter.com/WBCBoxing/status/1628870500356132864"">publicly recognized before</a> as well as <a href=""https://twitter.com/WBCBoxing/status/1629992031186501632"">after the fight</a>.</p><p>Paul made a name for himself as a YouTube star years ago, while Fury has been boxing professionally since 2018 and was a contestant on season five of <em>Love Island UK</em>. And not only that, their rivalry <a href=""https://www.sportingnews.com/us/boxing/news/jake-paul-vs-tommy-fury-timeline-rivalry-youtuber-boxer/g7f5bmcp12996v86nim1c0qm"">has been going on for years</a>, with two previously scheduled fights having been canceled for various reasons only fueling the fire.</p><p>Fury may have a bit more experience under his belt, but Paul is punching higher when it comes to social audiences: According to <a href=""http://creatoriq.com/"">CreatorIQ</a>, he has 70.1 million followers across social media platforms, compared to Fury’s 5.5 million. The highly publicized fight spurred social audience growth for both: Paul saw a modest increase of 0.43% in followers compared to the week before the bout, while Fury saw a notable 10% growth.</p><p>Instagram is the most popular platform for both, and while Paul boasts 22.3 million followers there compared to Fury’s 4.9 million, Fury has him beat for engagement, with an engagement rate of 7.26%, which CreatorIQ considers “excellent,” compared to Paul’s “good” 1.48%.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><a href=""http://creatoriq.com/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/FuryIG--1-.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1500"" height=""391"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/FuryIG--1-.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/FuryIG--1-.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/FuryIG--1-.png 1500w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a><figcaption><em>Instagram stats for Tommy Fury as of Feb. 28, via CreatorIQ</em></figcaption></figure><p>Both used their social followings to promote the match and drive tune-in, with Paul in particular not pulling any punches: Mere days before the fight, he escalated the rivalry, <a href=""https://twitter.com/jakepaul/status/1628431499233042432"">posting a video to Twitter</a> and Instagram utterly ripping into Fury, proclaiming “This is it, you’re going to be retired from boxing after this.”</p><p>And earlier in the week <a href=""https://twitter.com/BTSportBoxing/status/1628068603642761216"">during an interview</a>, Paul referred to Fury’s girlfriend Molly-Mae Hague as the “breadwinner” in their relationship. Well, from a social angle he’s not wrong: Hague, an influencer herself, has 12.3 million followers across social platforms, and an “excellent” Instagram engagement rate of 11.5%, per CreatorIQ — far beyond either Fury or Paul.</p><p>Of course, in the end Fury emerged victorious with a split-decision win after eight rounds. But that’s certainly not the last of it: There was a rematch clause in the contract, and Paul already said he intends to make it happen.</p>",640269a4f784d9003d1efb25,"The Feb. 26 boxing match between Tommy Fury and Jake Paul is one of the best examples yet of how social media clout can turn into real-world results. The fight, which took place in Saudi Arabia and was available to watch via pay-per-view, drew a global audience — and you can be sure the people watching weren’t just boxing enthusiasts. One reason it was so hotly anticipated is due to the influencer status Fury and Paul both hold, something the World Boxing Council publicly recognized before as well as after the fight.

Paul made a name for himself as a YouTube star years ago, while Fury has been boxing professionally since 2018 and was a contestant on season five of Love Island UK. And not only that, their rivalry has been going on for years, with two previously scheduled fights having been canceled for various reasons only fueling the fire.

Fury may have a bit more experience under his belt, but Paul is punching higher when it comes to social audiences: According to CreatorIQ, he has 70.1 million followers across social media platforms, compared to Fury’s 5.5 million. The highly publicized fight spurred social audience growth for both: Paul saw a modest increase of 0.43% in followers compared to the week before the bout, while Fury saw a notable 10% growth.

Instagram is the most popular platform for both, and while Paul boasts 22.3 million followers there compared to Fury’s 4.9 million, Fury has him beat for engagement, with an engagement rate of 7.26%, which CreatorIQ considers “excellent,” compared to Paul’s “good” 1.48%.

Both used their social followings to promote the match and drive tune-in, with Paul in particular not pulling any punches: Mere days before the fight, he escalated the rivalry, posting a video to Twitter and Instagram utterly ripping into Fury, proclaiming “This is it, you’re going to be retired from boxing after this.”

And earlier in the week during an interview, Paul referred to Fury’s girlfriend Molly-Mae Hague as the “breadwinner” in their relationship. Well, from a social angle he’s not wrong: Hague, an influencer herself, has 12.3 million followers across social platforms, and an “excellent” Instagram engagement rate of 11.5%, per CreatorIQ — far beyond either Fury or Paul.

Of course, in the end Fury emerged victorious with a split-decision win after eight rounds. But that’s certainly not the last of it: There was a rematch clause in the contract, and Paul already said he intends to make it happen.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552072092-7f9b8d63efcb?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDF8fGJveGluZ3xlbnwwfHx8fDE2Nzc4Nzk3OTg&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-03-03T21:41:56.000Z,2023-03-03T21:45:06.000Z,2023-03-01T21:43:00.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,64026a79f784d9003d1efb80,10cb20cc-10d2-4c0f-a5e6-00bcdcb7d161,Applebee's Starts Year Rolling With The Stones,applebees-starts-year-rolling-with-the-stones,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-01-at-10.49.19-AM.png"",""width"":1500,""height"":557,""href"":""http://songtradr.com/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://songtradr.com/""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""One way brands can get audience attention? It spent about $25.6 million on TV ads, a $12 million decrease from January's outlay of $37.7 million. </p><p>Some additional insights around TV ads from the top pharma brands in February:</p><ul><li>In total, the top ten brands spent about $151.6 million, a nearly 27% decrease from January's $207.4 million. </li><li>Rinvoq, which was the top-spending Rx brand in January, took second place in February with an estimated national TV ad spend of $24.8 million, down from its January outlay of $41.3 million. </li><li>Brands that did not make the top ten in January but did in February include Sotyktu, Paxlovid and Caplyta</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/ispotfeb2023pharma.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""829"" height=""494"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/ispotfeb2023pharma.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/ispotfeb2023pharma.png 829w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6408a211bdb462003da79e97,"Skyrizi, an AbbVie immunology drug, was the No. 1 prescription pharmaceutical brand when it came to estimated national TV ad spend in February, according to iSpot.tv data shared with FiercePharma. Some additional insights around TV ads from the top pharma brands in February:

 * In total, the top ten brands spent about $151.6 million, a nearly 27% decrease from January's $207.4 million.
 * Rinvoq, which was the top-spending Rx brand in January, took second place in February with an estimated national TV ad spend of $24.8 million, down from its January outlay of $41.3 million.

",,,,,,1,640a5e5bbdb462003da79ed8,293516a8-187c-4f81-84a3-a6427c2ffbd6,Which Beer Brands Won With Music In 2022?,which-beer-brands-won-with-music-in-2022,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg"",""width"":1920,""height"":1080,""href"":""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beer""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beer""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Songtradr’s new ""],[0,[0],1,""Music of Beer report""],[0,[],0,"" pours out plenty of insights around the most effective music choices for beer ads, Super Bowl success and which brands picked right in 2022. The data shows Heineken was the most strategic in its sonic decision-making, while Guinness… may be unfit to drive (at least when it comes to picking tunes for its TV ads).""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""As Songtradr points out, Heineken’s video ad strategy included re-recordings of recognizable songs, allowing it to resonate with a larger audience and see the highest consumer engagement in the category. Doing so was a smart differentiator in an industry that can approach advertising pretty similarly.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Success with music is not just about creating an idea of sonic likeability either. Songtradr cites research from Les Binet that using music can increase an ad campaign’s effectiveness by 20-25%. Since Guinness used more stock music and voiceovers, it didn’t fare as well as its peers who may have utilized more recognizable (and thus, more effective) tracks.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Importantly, Songtradr’s research shows (in the graph below), that thoughtful, consistent music placement in branding and advertising content accounted for over 33% of overall business performance for beer brands in the U.S. in 2022. Heineken was able to exceed the norm by way of both music and business performance, while Corona was one of the only other beer brands to find a good mix.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Songtradr’s new <a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beer"">Music of Beer report</a> pours out plenty of insights around the most effective music choices for beer ads, Super Bowl success and which brands picked right in 2022. The data shows Heineken was the most strategic in its sonic decision-making, while Guinness… may be unfit to drive (at least when it comes to picking tunes for its TV ads).</p><p>As Songtradr points out, Heineken’s video ad strategy included re-recordings of recognizable songs, allowing it to resonate with a larger audience and see the highest consumer engagement in the category. Doing so was a smart differentiator in an industry that can approach advertising pretty similarly.</p><p>Success with music is not just about creating an idea of sonic likeability either. Songtradr cites research from Les Binet that using music can increase an ad campaign’s effectiveness by 20-25%. Since Guinness used more stock music and voiceovers, it didn’t fare as well as its peers who may have utilized more recognizable (and thus, more effective) tracks.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beer""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1920"" height=""1080"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/IMG_2894.jpg 1920w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p>Importantly, Songtradr’s research shows (in the graph below), that thoughtful, consistent music placement in branding and advertising content accounted for over 33% of overall business performance for beer brands in the U.S. in 2022. Heineken was able to exceed the norm by way of both music and business performance, while Corona was one of the only other beer brands to find a good mix.</p>",640a5e5bbdb462003da79ed8,"Songtradr’s new Music of Beer report pours out plenty of insights around the most effective music choices for beer ads, Super Bowl success and which brands picked right in 2022. The data shows Heineken was the most strategic in its sonic decision-making, while Guinness… may be unfit to drive (at least when it comes to picking tunes for its TV ads).

As Songtradr points out, Heineken’s video ad strategy included re-recordings of recognizable songs, allowing it to resonate with a larger audience and see the highest consumer engagement in the category. Doing so was a smart differentiator in an industry that can approach advertising pretty similarly.

Success with music is not just about creating an idea of sonic likeability either. Songtradr cites research from Les Binet that using music can increase an ad campaign’s effectiveness by 20-25%. Since Guinness used more stock music and voiceovers, it didn’t fare as well as its peers who may have utilized more recognizable (and thus, more effective) tracks.

Importantly, Songtradr’s research shows (in the graph below), that thoughtful, consistent music placement in branding and advertising content accounted for over 33% of overall business performance for beer brands in the U.S. in 2022. Heineken was able to exceed the norm by way of both music and business performance, while Corona was one of the only other beer brands to find a good mix.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-07-at-1.56.46-PM-1.png,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-03-09T22:31:55.000Z,2023-03-09T22:35:57.000Z,2023-03-09T22:34:40.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,640a6362bdb462003da79f1a,0bd294a8-e0a3-4e73-9822-5c2a18456138,Tax Brands’ New Early-Year TV Ad Strategy,tax-brands-new-early-year-tv-ad-strategy,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/tax-brands-ispot--1-.jpeg"",""width"":1402,""height"":787,""href"":""http://ispot.tv/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://ispot.tv/""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Data from ""],[0,[0],1,""iSpot""],[0,[],0,"" shows that tax filing services are accounting for a progressively smaller share of household TV ad impressions in January and February for five years running now. Year-over-year, tax brands are also less likely to have ad impressions delivered in primetime – with 28.0% in Jan. and Feb. of 2022, versus 25.4% this year.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""The NFL delivered 11.5% of tax filing service brands’ TV ad impressions in the first two months of 2022, compared to 8.6% in 2023.""]],[[0,[],0,""Syndicated shows like ""],[0,[1],1,""Friends""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[1],1,""NCIS""],[0,[],0,"" accounted for a smaller share of TV ad impressions for tax brands year-over-year, despite the absence of the Olympics in 2023 (was 2.3% of Jan. & Feb. impressions last year).""]]]],[10,0]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Data from <a href=""http://ispot.tv/"">iSpot</a> shows that tax filing services are accounting for a progressively smaller share of household TV ad impressions in January and February for five years running now. Year-over-year, tax brands are also less likely to have ad impressions delivered in primetime – with 28.0% in Jan. and Feb. of 2022, versus 25.4% this year.</p><ul><li>The NFL delivered 11.5% of tax filing service brands’ TV ad impressions in the first two months of 2022, compared to 8.6% in 2023.</li><li>Syndicated shows like <em>Friends</em> and <em>NCIS</em> accounted for a smaller share of TV ad impressions for tax brands year-over-year, despite the absence of the Olympics in 2023 (was 2.3% of Jan. &amp; Feb. impressions last year).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://ispot.tv/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/tax-brands-ispot--1-.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1402"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/tax-brands-ispot--1-.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/tax-brands-ispot--1-.jpeg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/tax-brands-ispot--1-.jpeg 1402w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",640a6362bdb462003da79f1a,"Data from iSpot shows that tax filing services are accounting for a progressively smaller share of household TV ad impressions in January and February for five years running now. Year-over-year, tax brands are also less likely to have ad impressions delivered in primetime – with 28.0% in Jan. and Feb. of 2022, versus 25.4% this year.

 * The NFL delivered 11.5% of tax filing service brands’ TV ad impressions in the first two months of 2022, compared to 8.6% in 2023.

""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Cough and cold medicine Vicks was the most seen over-the-counter or prescription pharmaceutical brand on TV in February, according to <a href=""https://www.mmm-online.com/home/channel/vicks-reclaims-top-spot-for-ad-impressions-among-rx-and-otc-brands-in-february/"">iSpot.tv data recently shared with MM+M.</a> It had a 4.30% impressions share of voice (SOV) with an estimated national TV ad spend of $8.5 million during the month. </p><p>Some additional insights around the most seen OTC/Rx brands for February: </p><ul><li>Dupixent was a close second place, with ads for its prescription eczema and asthma drugs receiving a 4.25% impression SOV — but it had a notably higher spend than Vicks, $21.4 million. </li><li>Prescription brands Skyrizi (3.74% SOV), Rinvoq (3.12%) and OTC brand Mucinex (2.76%) round out the top five by impressions SOV. </li><li>Broadcast networks delivered top impressions shares for all of the top ten brands, led by ABC which was the No. 1 network by SOV for seven of the ten. </li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/top-otc-and-rx-pharma-feb.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""706"" height=""437"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/top-otc-and-rx-pharma-feb.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/top-otc-and-rx-pharma-feb.png 706w""></figure>",640b36ffbdb462003da79f55,"Cough and cold medicine Vicks was the most seen over-the-counter or prescription pharmaceutical brand on TV in February, according to iSpot.tv data recently shared with MM+M. Some additional insights around the most seen OTC/Rx brands for February:

 * Dupixent was a close second place, with ads for its prescription eczema and asthma drugs receiving a 4.25% impression SOV — but it had a notably higher spend than Vicks, $21.4 million.
 * Prescription brands Skyrizi (3.74% SOV), Rinvoq (3.12%) and OTC brand Mucinex (2.76%) round out the top five by impressions SOV.

With major artists like Rihanna (""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mx_OexsUI2M"">Lift Me Up</a>"") and Lady Gaga (""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O2CIAKVTOrc"">Hold My Hand</a>"") up for the award as well, those songs have by far had the most Spotify streams of any nominated original song this year – though it still didn't mean any hardware for the popular singles.</p><ul><li>""Naatu Naatu"" has been an international hit, even if it has fewer listens than the aforementioned tracks more geared to a U.S. audience; the song is the most-listened to track on Spotify for all three collaborators (M. M. Keeravani, Rahul Sipligunj and Kala Bhairava).</li><li>""Lift Me Up"" has failed to lose much steam on Spotify since it debuted around the release of <em>Black Panther: Wakanda Forever</em> last November. Songtradr data shows the song has been between the 83rd and 90th percentile on Spotify for more than four months now.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://songtradr.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/copy-what-are-beyonce-audiences-shopping-for-1.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1402"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/copy-what-are-beyonce-audiences-shopping-for-1.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/copy-what-are-beyonce-audiences-shopping-for-1.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/copy-what-are-beyonce-audiences-shopping-for-1.jpg 1402w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",640fa88dbdb462003da79f94,"""Naatu Naatu"" from Rrr took home the Oscar for Best Original Song this year, but in the lead-up to the big night, Spotify popularity painted a different picture, according to data from Songtradr.  * ""Naatu Naatu"" has been an international hit, even if it has fewer listens than the aforementioned tracks more geared to a U.S. audience; the song is the most-listened to track on Spotify for all three collaborators (M. M. Keeravani, Rahul Sipligunj and Kala Bhairava).
 * ""Lift Me Up"" has failed to lose much steam on Spotify since it debuted around the release of Black Panther: Wakanda Forever last November. According to data from <a href=""http://inscape.tv"">Inscape</a>, the Oscars telecast captured 5.67% of all live, linear minutes watched on Mar. 12, making it the most-watched program for the entire day. </p><ul><li>All combined, Oscars-related programming accounted for 7.52% of watch-time (nearly double the day’s second most-watched program, the Players’ Championship).</li><li>Men’s college basketball games and the live NCAA Tournament Selection Show combined for 4.30% of minutes watched on Sunday.</li><li>Thanks in large part to Oscars coverage, ABC was the most-watched network on Sunday, with 10.18% of minutes watched.</li><li>Across both Saturday and Sunday, ABC was also No. 1, with 7.81% of minutes watched.</li></ul><p>Read more about Oscars viewership with <a href=""https://www.nexttv.com/news/oscars-on-ac-draw-187-million-viewers-up-12-per-nielsen"">data from Inscape in this Broadcasting &amp; Cable article</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Inscape2023Oscars.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1365"" height=""763"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/Inscape2023Oscars.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/Inscape2023Oscars.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Inscape2023Oscars.png 1365w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6410608abdb462003da7a007,"For all the talk of award show viewership being in the gutter, ABC still snagged a win with the 95th Academy Awards on Sunday, despite stiff competition from NCAA’s Selection Sunday programming, NASCAR and the PGA Players’ Championship tournament. According to data from Inscape, the Oscars telecast captured 5.67% of all live, linear minutes watched on Mar. 12, making it the most-watched program for the entire day.

 * All combined, Oscars-related programming accounted for 7.52% of watch-time (nearly double the day’s second most-watched program, the Players’ Championship).
 * Men’s college basketball games and the live NCAA Tournament Selection Show combined for 4.30% of minutes watched on Sunday.
 * Thanks in large part to Oscars coverage, ABC was the most-watched network on Sunday, with 10.18% of minutes watched.
 * Across both Saturday and Sunday, ABC was also No. 1, with 7.81% of minutes watched.

href=""__GHOST_URL__/oscars-viewership-beats-out-sunday-sports/"">most-watched program on TV for Sunday, Mar. 12</a>, it couldn't make the steal from men's college basketball when it came to the weekly ranking: Games accounted for 4.16% of minutes watched Mar. 6-12, up from 2.28% of watch-time the previous week. </p><ul><li>The 2023 PGA Players Championship swings into second place with 1.48% of minutes watched, while the Oscars take fourth (0.91%).</li><li>Aside from the week-over-week ranking newcomers, only two programs increased their chart positions compared to the previous week: <em>SportsCenter</em>, which moved into ninth from No. 15 and <em>Tucker Carlson Tonight</em> (up to No. 20 from No. 24).</li><li>Looking at the network ranking, there was a single week-over-week chart newcomer: ESPN2, at No. 24 with 0.99% of minutes watched.</li></ul><p>Read more and <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/basketball-bounces-up-oscars-still-slaps-tv-by-the-numbers"">see the full network ranking at TVREV.com</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/InscapeTopShowsMar6-12.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" watch-time the previous week.

 * The 2023 PGA Players Championship swings into second place with 1.48% of minutes watched, while the Oscars take fourth (0.91%).
 * Aside from the week-over-week ranking newcomers, only two programs increased their chart positions compared to the previous week: SportsCenter, which moved into ninth from No. 15 and Tucker Carlson Tonight (up to No. 20 from No. 24).
 * Looking at the network ranking, there was a single week-over-week chart newcomer: ESPN2, at No. 24 with 0.99% of minutes watched.

Those ads amounted to 2.40% of all TV ad impressions (live programming only) from Nov. 7, 2022-Mar. 12, 2023 – No. 3 overall in that stretch, trailing only the NFL and college football.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Women’s games, however, had just under 31K airings and 0.17% of TV ad impressions. No, the math doesn’t create parity between the two sports, even if you extrapolate women’s college basketball airings to be equal to the men. But part of that also comes from when these games are taking place. For instance, iSpot can shed light on days of the week and dayparts where games (and ad airings) appear.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[3],1,""Men's games""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[3],1,""Women's games""]]],[10,1],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The major differences here should be clear: 39% of ad airings during women’s college basketball games appear on weekend afternoons, and 38% appear on Sundays. For most of the season, it’s running up against TV’s biggest tentpole property, the NFL. Of course women’s basketball games can’t deliver more impressions in those timeslots – no program on TV can, because the NFL has attention locked down already.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Meanwhile, 37% of men’s college basketball ad airings are in primetime, and 32% are on Saturdays (which get much clearer from an attention standpoint once college football’s regular season wraps up). So the games are getting more optimal windows with minimal competition.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><em>[the following is an excerpt from <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/tv-data-shows-how-womens-basketball-still-gets-deprioritized"">TVREV</a>, where you can read the full piece]</em></p><p>Looking at <a href=""http://ispot.tv/"">iSpot</a> data for the 2022-23 college basketball regular season, first-airing men’s college basketball games delivered more ads across national linear TV and RSNs than any other program (over 123K). Those ads amounted to 2.40% of all TV ad impressions (live programming only) from Nov. 7, 2022-Mar. 12, 2023 – No. 3 overall in that stretch, trailing only the NFL and college football.</p><p>Women’s games, however, had just under 31K airings and 0.17% of TV ad impressions. No, the math doesn’t create parity between the two sports, even if you extrapolate women’s college basketball airings to be equal to the men. But part of that also comes from when these games are taking place. For instance, iSpot can shed light on days of the week and dayparts where games (and ad airings) appear.</p><p><strong>Men's games</strong></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/tv-data-shows-how-womens-basketball-still-gets-deprioritized""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.46.06-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""634"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.46.06-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.46.06-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.46.06-AM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.46.06-AM.png 2120w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p><strong>Women's games</strong></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/tv-data-shows-how-womens-basketball-still-gets-deprioritized""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.48.09-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""615"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.48.09-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.48.09-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.48.09-AM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/Screen-Shot-2023-03-14-at-9.48.09-AM.png 2114w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p>The major differences here should be clear: 39% of ad airings during women’s college basketball games appear on weekend afternoons, and 38% appear on Sundays. For most of the season, it’s running up against TV’s biggest tentpole property, the NFL. Of course women’s basketball games can’t deliver more impressions in those timeslots – no program on TV can, because the NFL has attention locked down already.</p><p>Meanwhile, 37% of men’s college basketball ad airings are in primetime, and 32% are on Saturdays (which get much clearer from an attention standpoint once college football’s regular season wraps up). So the games are getting more optimal windows with minimal competition.</p>",6412136ffe2a1f003d4ad4c2,"[the following is an excerpt from TVREV, where you can read the full piece]

Looking at iSpot data for the 2022-23 college basketball regular season, first-airing men’s college basketball games delivered more ads across national linear TV and RSNs than any other program (over 123K). Those ads amounted to 2.40% of all TV ad impressions (live programming only) from Nov. 7, 2022-Mar. 12, 2023 – No. 3 overall in that stretch, trailing only the NFL and college football.

Women’s games, however, had just under 31K airings and 0.17% of TV ad impressions. No, the math doesn’t create parity between the two sports, even if you extrapolate women’s college basketball airings to be equal to the men. But part of that also comes from when these games are taking place. For instance, iSpot can shed light on days of the week and dayparts where games (and ad airings) appear.

Men's games

Women's games

The major differences here should be clear: 39% of ad airings during women’s college basketball games appear on weekend afternoons, and 38% appear on Sundays. For most of the season, it’s running up against TV’s biggest tentpole property, the NFL. Of course women’s basketball games can’t deliver more impressions in those timeslots – no program on TV can, because the NFL has attention locked down already.

Meanwhile, 37% of men’s college basketball ad airings are in primetime, and 32% are on Saturdays (which get much clearer from an attention standpoint once college football’s regular season wraps up). So the games are getting more optimal windows with minimal competition.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1518989229647-6377f907a0b2?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDF8fG5jYWElMjBiYXNrZXRiYWxsfGVufDB8fHx8MTY3ODkwNjIzMA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-03-15T18:50:23.000Z,2023-03-15T18:54:19.000Z,2023-03-15T18:54:19.000Z,,,,,,6359c410975d780031398a07,1,641333a4fe2a1f003d4ad51d,bd21e0bf-ce58-4813-b9e1-78523c7e27b0,Why Effective Marketing Must Be Creator-Led,why-effective-marketing-must-be-creator-led,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png"",""width"":2475,""height"":2152}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://creatoriq.com""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.instagram.com/p/CiA2zoajZ0T/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.instagram.com/p/CjQPUr1JUMa/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/effective-creator-marketing-roi""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Gone are the days when influencer marketing was merely a wish list line item in a budget — it’s now a foundational necessity for maximizing efforts. Creator-led marketing helps brands produce content at scale by outsourcing the work to influential experts with both the passion and the following to connect deeply with consumers. Assets that feature creators perform better than traditional digital advertising, with greater ROI and improved engagement. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Brands are acknowledging this and pivoting appropriately: According to a new report from ""],[0,[0],1,""CreatorIQ""],[0,[],0,"", 69% of brands increased their influencer marketing investment over the past year, and 86% suggested that creator marketing has been either somewhat or very effective at driving awareness for their brand or clients. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""One example of how effective creator-led marketing can be comes from Tiffany & Co. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""All in all, the campaign generated:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""197.5 million impressions""]],[[0,[],0,""4.8 million likes""]],[[0,[],0,""An estimated social media value of $9 million""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Get more insights from Tiffany & Co., Crocs, and Foodie Tribe, as well as data-backed stories from Doritos and Moët & Chandon, by ""],[0,[3],1,""downloading the full Effective Marketing Report for free.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Gone are the days when influencer marketing was merely a wish list line item in a budget — it’s now a foundational necessity for maximizing efforts. Creator-led marketing helps brands produce content at scale by outsourcing the work to influential experts with both the passion and the following to connect deeply with consumers. Assets that feature creators perform better than traditional digital advertising, with greater ROI and improved engagement. </p><p>Brands are acknowledging this and pivoting appropriately: According to a new report from <a href=""http://creatoriq.com"">CreatorIQ</a>, 69% of brands increased their influencer marketing investment over the past year, and 86% suggested that creator marketing has been either somewhat or very effective at driving awareness for their brand or clients. </p><p>One example of how effective creator-led marketing can be comes from Tiffany &amp; Co. As a global company, vibrant, synchronized postings are critical for drawing attention to its collections — as is working with a creator known worldwide. </p><p>To that end, Tiffany teamed up with superstar Beyoncé for the Lose Yourself In Love Campaign. Queen Bey’s 296 million Instagram followers were treated to a <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/p/CiA2zoajZ0T/"">showcase</a> of the Tiffany HardWear collection, while Tiffany <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/p/CjQPUr1JUMa/"">released a video</a> accompaniment to Beyoncé’s latest album set to the track “Summer Renaissance.” Both shared the video across their respective social channels. </p><p>All in all, the campaign generated:</p><ul><li>197.5 million impressions</li><li>4.8 million likes</li><li>An estimated social media value of $9 million</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""1739"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w2400/2023/03/CIQTiffanyBey.png 2400w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p>Get more insights from Tiffany &amp; Co., Crocs, and Foodie Tribe, as well as data-backed stories from Doritos and Moët &amp; Chandon, by <a href=""https://www.creatoriq.com/white-papers/effective-creator-marketing-roi"">downloading the full Effective Marketing Report for free.</a></p>",641333a4fe2a1f003d4ad51d,"Gone are the days when influencer marketing was merely a wish list line item in a budget — it’s now a foundational necessity for maximizing efforts. Creator-led marketing helps brands produce content at scale by outsourcing the work to influential experts with both the passion and the following to connect deeply with consumers. Assets that feature creators perform better than traditional digital advertising, with greater ROI and improved engagement.

Brands are acknowledging this and pivoting appropriately: According to a new report from CreatorIQ, 69% of brands increased their influencer marketing investment over the past year, and 86% suggested that creator marketing has been either somewhat or very effective at driving awareness for their brand or clients.

One example of how effective creator-led marketing can be comes from Tiffany & Co. As a global company, vibrant, synchronized postings are critical for drawing attention to its collections — as is working with a creator known worldwide.

To that end, Tiffany teamed up with superstar Beyoncé for the Lose Yourself In Love Campaign. Queen Bey’s 296 million Instagram followers were treated to a showcase of the Tiffany HardWear collection, while Tiffany released a video accompaniment to Beyoncé’s latest album set to the track “Summer Renaissance.” Both shared the video across their respective social channels.

All in all, the campaign generated:

 * 197.5 million impressions
 * 4.8 million likes
 * An estimated social media value of $9 million

Get more insights from Tiffany & Co., Crocs, and Foodie Tribe, as well as data-backed stories from Doritos and Moët & Chandon, by downloading the full Effective Marketing Report for free.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556764900-fa065610b0e4?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=MnwxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDF8fGluZmx1ZW5jZXJ8ZW58MHx8fHwxNjc4OTgwNTk3&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-03-16T15:20:04.000Z,2023-03-17T12:52:52.000Z,2023-03-17T12:52:52.000Z,"According to a new report from CreatorIQ, 69% of brands increased their influencer marketing investment over the past year, and 86% suggested that creator marketing has been either somewhat or very effective at driving awareness for their brand or clients. And that's likely to climb in 2023.</p><!--kg-card-begin: html--><blockquote class=""twitter-tweet""><p lang=""en"" dir=""ltr"">MARCH MADNESS 🔥🏀 TREND ALERT: In the last 30 days, TikTok videos using &quot;<a href=""https://twitter.com/CBS?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"">@CBS</a> College Sports theme&quot; sound have generated 4M+ views. <br><br>In 2022, the sound had 16.2M views &amp; we expect to see it to grow this year as fans &amp; teams join in on the excitement. <a href=""https://twitter.com/hashtag/marchmadness?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"">#marchmadness</a> <a href=""https://twitter.com/hashtag/socialvideo?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"">#socialvideo</a> <a href=""https://t.co/URjtKl5R2u"">pic.twitter.com/URjtKl5R2u</a></p>&mdash; Tubular Labs (@TubularLabs) <a href=""https://twitter.com/TubularLabs/status/1636384625357656069?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw"">March 16, 2023</a></blockquote> <script async src=""https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js"" charset=""utf-8""></script><!--kg-card-end: html-->",6414d680fe2a1f003d4ad542,"The next time you open up TikTok, there's a storng likelihood you'll hear the iconic CBS Sports college theme (long associated with both the NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament and SEC football).

Tubular Labs data found that the sound is already one of the most-heard on TikTok over the last 30 days, and videos using it already have over 4 million views.

For reference, videos using the sound had 16.2 million views during March Madness last year. And that's likely to climb in 2023.

Three brands from different industries used VIZIO Home Screen activations to stand out and connect with audiences to drive real results: a pizza restaurant, an auto brand and an insurance company. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""One big highlight: Leveraging the VIZIO Home Screen helped the auto brand’s campaign generate a +34% lift in incremental auto sales — over $7 million. ""],[1,[],0,0]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Read more and see additional results from the case study ""],[0,[0],1,""on VIZIO’s blog""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,1]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>A new <a href=""https://platformplus.vizio.com/insights/vizio-home-screen-brings-brands-front-and-center"">case study from VIZIO</a> highlights the merits of advertising on the TV home screen. Three brands from different industries used VIZIO Home Screen activations to stand out and connect with audiences to drive real results: a pizza restaurant, an auto brand and an insurance company. </p><p>One big highlight: Leveraging the VIZIO Home Screen helped the auto brand’s campaign generate a +34% lift in incremental auto sales — over $7 million. <br></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><img src=""https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/9Fl6UUnZCV3Pe-gCNs-97wra__mVH3kmV1k0EoLgxmYKEqGitbK08ehxDXtH4dpolf5HB90prDLWfWAbDSPuMGh0eOvpliF1nDwqVDG_sxU0DtAYmCd-wHZxXR9K05T_JxWAQY3UgJHTMOp40B9t-ho"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""533"" height=""399""><figcaption>Via VIZIO Ads</figcaption></figure><p>Read more and see additional results from the case study <a href=""https://platformplus.vizio.com/insights/vizio-home-screen-brings-brands-front-and-center"">on VIZIO’s blog</a>.</p>",641863bbfe2a1f003d4ad5aa,"A new case study from VIZIO highlights the merits of advertising on the TV home screen. One big trend: Consumers are savvy and are looking for personalized communication and high-quality customer service. For example:

 * 49% of global consumers are frustrated with irrelevant content from brands.
 * 42% felt frustration about messages from brands that don’t reflect their wants or needs.
 * 25% of shoppers discontinued their relationship with a brand because of poor customer service, a 9% increase since 2022.
