ABC moves from second to first place week-over-week, capturing 6.19% of minutes watched. Programs driving viewership included Good Morning America, ABC World News Tonight With David Muir and The View.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from July 24-30:

 * CBS takes second place (up from third) with 6.17% of watch-time, fueled in part by PGA Tour golf. NBC slips from first to third week-over-week (5.97%).
 * Thanks to Shark Week programming, Discovery jumps from No. 20 to No. 11, capturing a 1.73% viewership share.
 * Networks that maintain their chart positions but increased watch-time compared to the previous week include Fox News, Fox and TBS.

Moreso, this just pushes the overall payout higher via more inventory and the potential addition of a bigger draw in Utah. The distance between the Big 12 and Big Ten/SEC remains quite large.</p><p>What will also be interesting for the Big 12 is what happens to those figures without the larger TV draws like Texas (No. 8) and Oklahoma (No. 23). They’re not the only factors propping up those rankings, but obviously since both draw a lot of viewers, that counts for opponents as well. You could see a scenario where the average Big 12 audience is more in line with the ACC’s starting in 2024.</p><p>That’s not a knock on the Big 12, though. Any expansion move from a non-Big Ten or SEC league was never going to close the media revenue gap (Big Ten and SEC members are basically making double what the Big 12 and ACC are, respectively, each year). Every conference remains part of a college football television product that’s the No. 2 program on TV each year according to <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2022-tv-advertising-year-in-review/"">ad impressions data from iSpot</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2022-tv-advertising-year-in-review/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-01-at-12.49.00-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""982"" height=""648"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-01-at-12.49.00-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-01-at-12.49.00-PM.png 982w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/big-12-expansion-tv-needle-realignment-pac-12"">Read more at TVREV</a>.</p>",64c96a0a3d8c4d0001de4eb2,"Realistically, it’s hard to see how adding Colorado, (and hypothetically) Arizona, Arizona State and Utah does much more for the conference in terms of increasing per-team value for media rights. Moreso, this just pushes the overall payout higher via more inventory and the potential addition of a bigger draw in Utah. The distance between the Big 12 and Big Ten/SEC remains quite large.

What will also be interesting for the Big 12 is what happens to those figures without the larger TV draws like Texas (No. 8) and Oklahoma (No. 23). They’re not the only factors propping up those rankings, but obviously since both draw a lot of viewers, that counts for opponents as well. You could see a scenario where the average Big 12 audience is more in line with the ACC’s starting in 2024.

That’s not a knock on the Big 12, though. Any expansion move from a non-Big Ten or SEC league was never going to close the media revenue gap (Big Ten and SEC members are basically making double what the Big 12 and ACC are, respectively, each year). Every conference remains part of a college football television product that’s the No. 2 program on TV each year according to ad impressions data from iSpot.

""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Before the round of 16 kicks off this weekend, Inscape shared some viewership trends around the second part of the group stage. Notably, Honolulu and Kansas City were not in the top five markets for the first part of the group stage.""]]],[10,1],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""For viewers that didn't tune into the U.S. vs. Netherlands match on July 26, these were the top programs by watch-time: ""],[0,[1],1,""Hannity, Chicago Fire""],[0,[],0,"", ""],[0,[1],1,""Blue Bloods""],[0,[],0,"", ""],[0,[1],1,""Chicago PD""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[1],1,""Gutfeld!""],[0,[],0,"".""],[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>The group stage of the FIFA Women's World Cup 2023 provided plenty of excitement and more than a couple of surprises (Brazil and Germany have both been eliminated, while underdogs Morocco and Jamaica have advanced). </p><p>Before the round of 16 kicks off this weekend, Inscape shared some viewership trends around the second part of the group stage. (You can get <a href=""__GHOST_URL__/womens-world-cup-group-1-watch-time-insights/"">insights around part one of the group stage here.</a>) </p><p>From July 26 through August 1, the Women’s World Cup (English + Spanish broadcasts) captured 0.92% of all live, linear minutes watched on TV across all dayparts/episode types, putting it at No. 4 on Inscape’s program ranking behind <em>Law &amp; Order: SVU</em> (1.18%), MLB games (1.10%) and <em>Good Morning America</em> (1.00%). </p><p>The two USWNT matches during this time period accounted for over half of all total game minutes watched, with the bulk (43.3%) coming from the U.S. vs. Netherlands match on July 26 — which makes sense, given that their next match against Portugal began at 3am ET on Aug. 1, a time when most U.S. viewers are sleeping. But even that game had a larger share than the No. 3 match, Panama vs. Jamaica, which occurred the morning of July 29 eastern time.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/inscape-wwc-second-group-1.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1375"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/inscape-wwc-second-group-1.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/inscape-wwc-second-group-1.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/inscape-wwc-second-group-1.png 1375w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p>Looking at the local area markets, Milwaukee, Honolulu, Cincinnati, San Francisco-Oak-San Jose and Kansas City had the highest reach. Notably, Honolulu and Kansas City were not in the top five markets for the first part of the group stage.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/WWC2023_7_26_to_8_1.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1833"" height=""1252"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/WWC2023_7_26_to_8_1.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/WWC2023_7_26_to_8_1.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/08/WWC2023_7_26_to_8_1.jpg 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/WWC2023_7_26_to_8_1.jpg 1833w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p>For viewers that didn't tune into the U.S. vs. Netherlands match on July 26, these were the top programs by watch-time: <em>Hannity, Chicago Fire</em>, <em>Blue Bloods</em>, <em>Chicago PD</em> and <em>Gutfeld!</em>.<br></p>",64ccf76a09c13a0001893a99,"The group stage of the FIFA Women's World Cup 2023 provided plenty of excitement and more than a couple of surprises (Brazil and Germany have both been eliminated, while underdogs Morocco and Jamaica have advanced).

Before the round of 16 kicks off this weekend, Inscape shared some viewership trends around the second part of the group stage. (You can get insights around part one of the group stage here.)

From July 26 through August 1, the Women’s World Cup (English + Spanish broadcasts) captured 0.92% of all live, linear minutes watched on TV across all dayparts/episode types, putting it at No. 4 on Inscape’s program ranking behind Law & Order: SVU (1.18%), MLB games (1.10%) and Good Morning America (1.00%).

The two USWNT matches during this time period accounted for over half of all total game minutes watched, with the bulk (43.3%) coming from the U.S. vs. Netherlands match on July 26 — which makes sense, given that their next match against Portugal began at 3am ET on Aug. 1, a time when most U.S. viewers are sleeping. But even that game had a larger share than the No. 3 match, Panama vs. Jamaica, which occurred the morning of July 29 eastern time.

Looking at the local area markets, Milwaukee, Honolulu, Cincinnati, San Francisco-Oak-San Jose and Kansas City had the highest reach. Notably, Honolulu and Kansas City were not in the top five markets for the first part of the group stage.

For viewers that didn't tune into the U.S. vs. Netherlands match on July 26, these were the top programs by watch-time: Hannity, Chicago Fire, Blue Bloods, Chicago PD and Gutfeld!.

                    <!--kg-card-end: html-->",64ccffb109c13a0001893b0b,"The top auto TV commercial by national TV ad impressions for July 24-30 was Chevrolet's ""Stay Connected, Safe and Charged,"" promoting the '24 Trax. Its 346.6 million impressions constituted a 59.6% week-over-week increase, according to iSpot data shared recently shared with WardsAuto. Chevrolet also owned the No. 2 ad, a Barbie movie tie-in featuring the Blazer EV that received 218.8 million national TV ad impressions.

 * Ram Trucks takes third place with a summer sales event promotion that had 200.6 million TV ad impressions.
 * The fourth-place commercial (197.8 million impressions) belongs to Alfa Romeo. Per iSpot’s Creative Assessment, 31% of surveyed viewers found the visual scenes to be the best thing about the ad.
 * Kia's ""Bird's Eye View"" finishes out the ranking with 168.7 million TV ad impressions, 61% of which came from primetime ad airings.

 * In total, the top ten brands spent an estimated $126.3 million, notably lower than what the top ten brands spent in June ($163.2 million).

Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for July 31 through August 6 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and insights about the top shows by watch-time.

NBC moves from third to first place week-over-week, with its 6.61% viewership share getting a bump from the 2023 Hall of Fame game that kicked off the NFL preseason. Other programs driving viewership on the network included Today, NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt and America’s Got Talent.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from July 31 through August 6:

 * CBS retains its second-place position but increased watch-time week-over-week, up to 6.28% from 6.17% previously.
 * CNN has the largest week-over-week ranking increase, jumping from No. 15 to No. 9 with 1.95% of minutes watched.
 * Bravo moves up to No. 21 from No. 25 previously, with its 1.10% viewership share fueled in large part by the Below Deck and Real Housewives franchises.
 * Univision was the only network to retain its ranking position but increase watch-time week-over-week, capturing 1.62% vs. 1.61% previously.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583962366888-5cbf27a9e7db?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDl8fG5iY3xlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTE1MDQ2ODZ8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-08T14:03:37.000Z,2023-08-08T14:26:11.000Z,2023-08-08T14:26:11.000Z,The network had a 6.61% viewership share for July 31 through August 6. ,,,,,,1,64d2a05500da3e000166762d,81da50c9-8f87-4263-8a25-09328e65b403,Jellysmack Videos Jump In Summer,jellysmack-jumps-in-summer-tubular-video-audience-ratings,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-08-at-1.07.57-PM.png"",""width"":1562,""height"":694,""href"":""http://tubularlabs.com""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://tubularlabs.com""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Summer months can create a slowdown for traditional media companies – and even more so when both the WGA and SAG are on strike. To its credit, Jellysmack has been taking advantage of an opening for more video attention in the U.S. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[0],1,""Tubular Audience Ratings""],[0,[],0,"" data for June show the top properties by U.S. minutes watched across Facebook and YouTube, and Jellysmack has seen minutes watched soar by 146% month-over-month. ""]],[[0,[],0,""The sources of the increase? MrBeast, Beauty Studio and a healthy diet of shorts (among other things). Jellysmack even posted 4% fewer videos on the platforms month-over-month, which means viewers watched videos for longer on average in June.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Summer months can create a slowdown for traditional media companies – and even more so when both the WGA and SAG are on strike. To its credit, Jellysmack has been taking advantage of an opening for more video attention in the U.S. </p><ul><li><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com"">Tubular Audience Ratings</a> data for June show the top properties by U.S. minutes watched across Facebook and YouTube, and Jellysmack has seen minutes watched soar by 146% month-over-month. </li><li>The sources of the increase? MrBeast, Beauty Studio and a healthy diet of shorts (among other things). Jellysmack even posted 4% fewer videos on the platforms month-over-month, which means viewers watched videos for longer on average in June.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-08-at-1.07.57-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1562"" height=""694"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-08-at-1.07.57-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-08-at-1.07.57-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-08-at-1.07.57-PM.png 1562w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",64d2a05500da3e000166762d,"Summer months can create a slowdown for traditional media companies – and even more so when both the WGA and SAG are on strike.  * Tubular Audience Ratings data for June show the top properties by U.S. minutes watched across Facebook and YouTube, and Jellysmack has seen minutes watched soar by 146% month-over-month.
 * The sources of the increase? MrBeast, Beauty Studio and a healthy diet of shorts (among other things).  * Ms. Rachel videos emphasize lengthier videos over volume, leading to a high number of minutes watched per unique viewers. Interestingly, unique viewers for the account grew by 20% vs. May 2023, making Ms. Rachel a top-20 creator account by that measure as well.

""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""In total, auto brands spent an estimated $90.2 million during the month, ""],[0,[2],1,""led by Subaru which had an estimated outlay of $11.6 million.""],[0,[],0,"" While spend may have been down, national TV ad impressions were up 14.5% compared to July 2022, totaling 27 billion across all automakers. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""After Subaru, the top automakers by spend in July were Chevrolet ($9.8 million), Kia ($7.7 million), Ram Trucks ($6.7 million) and Lexus ($6.5 million). ""]],[[0,[],0,""July top five brands by share of automaker household TV ad impressions were Chevrolet (11.20%), Subaru (7.93%), Toyota, (7.81%), Lexus (6.65%) and  Nissan (6.53%).""]],[[0,[],0,""Alfa Romeo, which didn't advertise in June or July 2022, spent about $4 million on an ad for the Tonale model. ""]],[[0,[3],1,""House Hunters""],[0,[],0,"" was a big player, delivering 314.3% more TV ad impressions for automakers this July vs. July 2022. ""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[2],1,""Get more automotive insights from iSpot in this MediaPost article.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>There was a 3.8% year-over-year decrease in what the automotive industry spent on national TV ads in July, continuing the downward trend of spend this summer (<a href=""__GHOST_URL__/leads-for-automakers-tv-ad-spend-in-may/"">June saw an 18.1% year-over-year decline compared to 2022</a>), according to <a href=""ispot.tv"">iSpot.tv</a>. </p><p>In total, auto brands spent an estimated $90.2 million during the month, <a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/387961/automotive-tv-spending-down-38-in-july.html"">led by Subaru which had an estimated outlay of $11.6 million.</a> While spend may have been down, national TV ad impressions were up 14.5% compared to July 2022, totaling 27 billion across all automakers. </p><ul><li>After Subaru, the top automakers by spend in July were Chevrolet ($9.8 million), Kia ($7.7 million), Ram Trucks ($6.7 million) and Lexus ($6.5 million). </li><li>July top five brands by share of automaker household TV ad impressions were Chevrolet (11.20%), Subaru (7.93%), Toyota, (7.81%), Lexus (6.65%) and  Nissan (6.53%).</li><li>Alfa Romeo, which didn't advertise in June or July 2022, spent about $4 million on an ad for the Tonale model. Meanwhile, Acura upped its spend year-over-year by +983.9%, with a focus on <em>SportsCenter</em> and reality programming. </li><li><em>House Hunters</em> was a big player, delivering 314.3% more TV ad impressions for automakers this July vs. July 2022. </li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/387961/automotive-tv-spending-down-38-in-july.html"">Get more automotive insights from iSpot in this MediaPost article.</a></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/ispot-autos-july-2023.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1646"" height=""900"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/ispot-autos-july-2023.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/ispot-autos-july-2023.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/08/ispot-autos-july-2023.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/ispot-autos-july-2023.png 1646w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",64d3956a00da3e00016676d9,"There was a 3.8% year-over-year decrease in what the automotive industry spent on national TV ads in July, continuing the downward trend of spend this summer (June saw an 18.1% year-over-year decline compared to 2022), according to iSpot.tv.

In total, auto brands spent an estimated $90.2 million during the month, led by Subaru which had an estimated outlay of $11.6 million. While spend may have been down, national TV ad impressions were up 14.5% compared to July 2022, totaling 27 billion across all automakers.

 * After Subaru, the top automakers by spend in July were Chevrolet ($9.8 million), Kia ($7.7 million), Ram Trucks ($6.7 million) and Lexus ($6.5 million).
 * July top five brands by share of automaker household TV ad impressions were Chevrolet (11.20%), Subaru (7.93%), Toyota, (7.81%), Lexus (6.65%) and  Nissan (6.53%).
 * Alfa Romeo, which didn't advertise in June or July 2022, spent about $4 million on an ad for the Tonale model. Meanwhile, Acura upped its spend year-over-year by +983.9%, with a focus on SportsCenter and reality programming.
 * House Hunters was a big player, delivering 314.3% more TV ad impressions for automakers this July vs. July 2022.

Get more automotive insights from iSpot in this MediaPost article.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/joshua-fuller-2aN5HTtHxJc-unsplash.jpg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-09T13:32:26.000Z,2023-08-09T13:43:31.000Z,2023-08-09T13:43:31.000Z,The industry spent an estimated $90.2 million on national TV ads during the month. ,,,,,,1,64d39be500da3e0001667722,87355050-1383-497c-b128-c9c7259f4e8a,Dupixent Dominates Pharma TV Ad Impressions SOV in July,dupixent-dominates-tv-ad-impressions-sov-in-july,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/julytop-otc-and-rx-pharma-1.png"",""width"":706,""height"":437}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.mmm-online.com/home/channel/dupixent-tops-rx-otc-pharma-brands-for-third-consecutive-month/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""For the third month in a row, Dupixent led for TV ad impressions SOV within the prescription and over-the-counter pharma industry. It spent an estimated $20 million on national TV ads, resulting in 2.6 billion impressions and an impressions SOV of 5.07%, ""],[0,[0],1,""according to iSpot.tv data recently shared with MM+M Online.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Some additional insights around the most-seen OTC/Rx brands for July:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Skyrizi remains in second place month-over-month, with an impressions SOV of 4.26% and 2.2 billion national TV ad impressions. The brand spent about $23.2 million on TV commercials in July. ""]],[[0,[],0,""The only OTC drug in the top five was Claritin, with an impressions SOV of 2.40% and an estimated TV ad spend of $4.2 million. ""]],[[0,[],0,""Talk shows and news programming played a large part in delivering impressions across the board, but some brands are also exploring popular syndicated sitcoms this summer. ""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""More ""],[0,[0],1,""pharma advertising insights here""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,"" ""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>For the third month in a row, Dupixent led for TV ad impressions SOV within the prescription and over-the-counter pharma industry. It spent an estimated $20 million on national TV ads, resulting in 2.6 billion impressions and an impressions SOV of 5.07%, <a href=""https://www.mmm-online.com/home/channel/dupixent-tops-rx-otc-pharma-brands-for-third-consecutive-month/"">according to iSpot.tv data recently shared with MM+M Online.</a></p><p>Some additional insights around the most-seen OTC/Rx brands for July:</p><ul><li>Skyrizi remains in second place month-over-month, with an impressions SOV of 4.26% and 2.2 billion national TV ad impressions. The brand spent about $23.2 million on TV commercials in July. </li><li>The only OTC drug in the top five was Claritin, with an impressions SOV of 2.40% and an estimated TV ad spend of $4.2 million. </li><li>Talk shows and news programming played a large part in delivering impressions across the board, but some brands are also exploring popular syndicated sitcoms this summer. </li></ul><p>More <a href=""https://www.mmm-online.com/home/channel/dupixent-tops-rx-otc-pharma-brands-for-third-consecutive-month/"">pharma advertising insights here</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/julytop-otc-and-rx-pharma-1.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""706"" height=""437"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/julytop-otc-and-rx-pharma-1.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/julytop-otc-and-rx-pharma-1.png 706w""></figure><p> </p>",64d39be500da3e0001667722,"For the third month in a row, Dupixent led for TV ad impressions SOV within the prescription and over-the-counter pharma industry. It spent an estimated $20 million on national TV ads, resulting in 2.6 billion impressions and an impressions SOV of 5.07%, according to iSpot.tv data recently shared with MM+M Online.

Some additional insights around the most-seen OTC/Rx brands for July:

 * Skyrizi remains in second place month-over-month, with an impressions SOV of 4.26% and 2.2 billion national TV ad impressions. The brand spent about $23.2 million on TV commercials in July.
 * The only OTC drug in the top five was Claritin, with an impressions SOV of 2.40% and an estimated TV ad spend of $4.2 million.
 * Talk shows and news programming played a large part in delivering impressions across the board, but some brands are also exploring popular syndicated sitcoms this summer.

More pharma advertising insights here.

When looking at the global average and peak demand of the previous three Narnia films over the last 12 months, per Parrot Analytics, we largely see diminishing returns that suggests the franchise has not exactly been the most enduring property.

 * This tracks with the general reception of the trilogy, which saw its IMDb ratings drop with each successive release from 2005-2010, and its box office performance, which never managed to match the highs of the original’s $720 million worldwide.
 * Netflix is hoping Greta Gerwig’s magical touch can re-elevate the IP from its relatively dormant status, though doing so doesn’t appear to be the easiest of paths.

""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""According to the report:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Since TikTok launched longer video formats last year, Tubular data uncovered the optimal video length to drive growth is 61-180 seconds to earn the highest growth rates per the number of uploads on TikTok.""]],[[0,[],0,""While 1-60s videos still win the most views, growth rates for this time frame are in decline. Where short-form video has become a dominating format to drive engagement, Tubular data shows longer cuts of content can go the distance. </p><p>According to the report:</p><ul><li>Since TikTok launched longer video formats last year, Tubular data uncovered the optimal video length to drive growth is 61-180 seconds to earn the highest growth rates per the number of uploads on TikTok.</li><li>While 1-60s videos still win the most views, growth rates for this time frame are in decline. Meanwhile, 61-180s and 181-600s show a positive growth in views. Factoring in fewer uploads for 61-180s, Tubular found this time frame presents the best whitespace opportunity.</li></ul>",64d3f29700da3e0001667788,"Diving into the latest trends from the first half of the year, Tubular Labs researched what ingredients for social video can help creators and brands generate growth on platforms. Where short-form video has become a dominating format to drive engagement, Tubular data shows longer cuts of content can go the distance.

According to the report:

 * Since TikTok launched longer video formats last year, Tubular data uncovered the optimal video length to drive growth is 61-180 seconds to earn the highest growth rates per the number of uploads on TikTok.
 * While 1-60s videos still win the most views, growth rates for this time frame are in decline. Meanwhile, 61-180s and 181-600s show a positive growth in views. What’s more, beauty brands represent 25% of all influencer marketing activity.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[1],1,""Among the results:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""""],[0,[],0,""Lancôme achieved the highest MusicIQ score at 61%, ranking first in consistency and distinctiveness by implementing a cohesive music strategy across various marketing channels.""]],[[0,[],0,""L’Oréal excelled in sourcing music, with over 80% of their music sourced from custom or licensed sources, contributing to their second-place overall ranking with a score of 54%.""]],[[0,[],0,""Shiseido demonstrated the highest engagement levels, with engagement rates almost double the category average, earning them a score of 43% and highlighting the positive correlation between music choice and brand performance.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0,1],2,""Check out the full white paper from Songtradr, here.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>In the latest installment of its ongoing Music of Business series, Songtradr applied its <a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beauty-whitepaper"">MusicIQ</a> analysis to the UK beauty industry, measuring the effectiveness of the music choices among the top 10 brands in the category.</p><p>This analysis is particularly important for the beauty industry, given how much it relies on user-generated content from fans, influencers, and celebrity partners. Among the top 200 beauty videos on YouTube, only 14% were uploaded by the brands themselves (the other 86% were uploaded by individual content creators). What’s more, beauty brands represent 25% of all influencer marketing activity.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beauty-whitepaper""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-09-at-3.31.34-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""848"" height=""628"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-09-at-3.31.34-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-09-at-3.31.34-PM.png 848w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure><p><strong>Among the results:</strong></p><ul><li>Lancôme achieved the highest MusicIQ score at 61%, ranking first in consistency and distinctiveness by implementing a cohesive music strategy across various marketing channels.</li><li>L’Oréal excelled in sourcing music, with over 80% of their music sourced from custom or licensed sources, contributing to their second-place overall ranking with a score of 54%.</li><li>Shiseido demonstrated the highest engagement levels, with engagement rates almost double the category average, earning them a score of 43% and highlighting the positive correlation between music choice and brand performance.</li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/music-of-beauty-whitepaper""><strong>Check out the full white paper from Songtradr, here.</strong></a></p>",64d412ac00da3e00016677a1,"In the latest installment of its ongoing Music of Business series, Songtradr applied its MusicIQ analysis to the UK beauty industry, measuring the effectiveness of the music choices among the top 10 brands in the category.

This analysis is particularly important for the beauty industry, given how much it relies on user-generated content from fans, influencers, and celebrity partners. Among the top 200 beauty videos on YouTube, only 14% were uploaded by the brands themselves (the other 86% were uploaded by individual content creators). What’s more, beauty brands represent 25% of all influencer marketing activity.

Among the results:

 * Lancôme achieved the highest MusicIQ score at 61%, ranking first in consistency and distinctiveness by implementing a cohesive music strategy across various marketing channels.
 * L’Oréal excelled in sourcing music, with over 80% of their music sourced from custom or licensed sources, contributing to their second-place overall ranking with a score of 54%.
 * Shiseido demonstrated the highest engagement levels, with engagement rates almost double the category average, earning them a score of 43% and highlighting the positive correlation between music choice and brand performance.

A central theme in their advertising strategy is the infusion of energetic music to engage and excite consumers. You can see this play out in many TJX ads that have aired on TV over the last few months – whether they’re new spots or ones that are being recirculated from recent years.

 * TJ Maxx's ""Get Everything You Want"", featuring Demi Lovato's ""Confident,"" has aired since August, leveraging the song's frequent media presence, including seven TV episodes since 2020, driven by its traits like Energy and Danceability, with rising Spotify popularity since early 2023.
 * Similarly, other TJX ads like Marshalls' ""Born to Hustle"" and ""Far And Wide,"" featuring Jain's ""Makeba,"" capitalize on the song's Danceability and Energy attributes. The brand benefits further from recent usage in shows like The Company You Keep and Extraordinary, resulted in a 12-percentage-point Spotify popularity increase since late February.
 * HomeGoods' ""Finding Is A Feeling: Garden"" employs Tom Tom Club's ""Genius of Love,"" rated even higher for Danceability (90 out of 100) and Energy (64 out of 100) according to Songtradr. The song capitalizes on its growing TikTok popularity, with video usage more than doubling since late 2022.
   ",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/tj-maxx-get-everything-you-want-song-by-demi-lovato-large-9.jpg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-09T22:34:58.000Z,2023-08-10T19:27:47.000Z,2023-06-21T22:34:00.000Z,Songtradr data shows how TJX pulls its brands together by creating sonic similarities.,,,,,,1,64d4171400da3e00016677e7,7f88a17f-92b1-414a-b16a-9cb858a8254d,Kraft-ing A Commercial Identity With Music,kraft-ing-a-commercial-identity-with-music,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1rhY/kraft-cheeses-find-a-way-back-home-song-by-andy-grammer""]],[""a"",[""href"",""songtradr.com""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The Kraft Heinz Company is a CPG giant, and a major TV advertiser. But in a sea of ads for food items, in particular, how can any brand stand out?""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""One way: Opting for the right music to fit the brand and the way it wants customers to feel while using (or in Kraft’s case, eating) the product.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Across its various brands, Kraft emphasizes energy and excitement about the product – but importantly, also hits on a youthful approach – especially when it comes to brands that children may express an affinity for.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Kraft Cheese employs Andy Grammer's \""Back Home\"" in their recent \""""],[0,[0],1,""Find a Way Back Home""],[0,[],0,""\"" ad. The song effectively conveys energy (84 out of 100), danceability (62), and valence/reactiveness (62), as revealed by ""],[0,[1],1,""Songtradr""],[0,[],0,"" data. Notably, the song's exclusivity in Kraft's marketing contributes to its affinity. Since its March debut, the ad has boosted the song's Spotify popularity from 56 to 63, with nearly 2.4 million streams during this period.""]],[[0,[],0,""Philadelphia Cream Cheese's ad features Irma Thomas's \""Take a Look\"" for an energetic dream sequence, while Heinz Ketchup's newer spot uses Chris Knox's \""It's Love\"" for playful fun. \""It's Love,\"" exclusively chosen for the Heinz ad, boosts its Spotify popularity from 15 to 25, benefiting both artist and brand affinity.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Kraft's choice of energetic and distinctive songs, exclusive to their ads, establishes brand affinity and drives Spotify popularity, showcasing their effective selection process.""]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>The Kraft Heinz Company is a CPG giant, and a major TV advertiser. But in a sea of ads for food items, in particular, how can any brand stand out?</p><p>One way: Opting for the right music to fit the brand and the way it wants customers to feel while using (or in Kraft’s case, eating) the product.</p><p>Across its various brands, Kraft emphasizes energy and excitement about the product – but importantly, also hits on a youthful approach – especially when it comes to brands that children may express an affinity for.</p><ul><li>Kraft Cheese employs Andy Grammer's ""Back Home"" in their recent ""<a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1rhY/kraft-cheeses-find-a-way-back-home-song-by-andy-grammer"">Find a Way Back Home</a>"" ad. The song effectively conveys energy (84 out of 100), danceability (62), and valence/reactiveness (62), as revealed by <a href=""songtradr.com"">Songtradr</a> data. Notably, the song's exclusivity in Kraft's marketing contributes to its affinity. Since its March debut, the ad has boosted the song's Spotify popularity from 56 to 63, with nearly 2.4 million streams during this period.</li><li>Philadelphia Cream Cheese's ad features Irma Thomas's ""Take a Look"" for an energetic dream sequence, while Heinz Ketchup's newer spot uses Chris Knox's ""It's Love"" for playful fun. ""It's Love,"" exclusively chosen for the Heinz ad, boosts its Spotify popularity from 15 to 25, benefiting both artist and brand affinity.</li></ul><p>Kraft's choice of energetic and distinctive songs, exclusive to their ads, establishes brand affinity and drives Spotify popularity, showcasing their effective selection process.</p>",64d4171400da3e00016677e7,"The Kraft Heinz Company is a CPG giant, and a major TV advertiser. But in a sea of ads for food items, in particular, how can any brand stand out?

One way: Opting for the right music to fit the brand and the way it wants customers to feel while using (or in Kraft’s case, eating) the product.

Across its various brands, Kraft emphasizes energy and excitement about the product – but importantly, also hits on a youthful approach – especially when it comes to brands that children may express an affinity for.

 * Kraft Cheese employs Andy Grammer's ""Back Home"" in their recent ""Find a Way Back Home"" ad. The song effectively conveys energy (84 out of 100), danceability (62), and valence/reactiveness (62), as revealed by Songtradr data. Notably, the song's exclusivity in Kraft's marketing contributes to its affinity. Since its March debut, the ad has boosted the song's Spotify popularity from 56 to 63, with nearly 2.4 million streams during this period.
 * Philadelphia Cream Cheese's ad features Irma Thomas's ""Take a Look"" for an energetic dream sequence, while Heinz Ketchup's newer spot uses Chris Knox's ""It's Love"" for playful fun. ""It's Love,"" exclusively chosen for the Heinz ad, boosts its Spotify popularity from 15 to 25, benefiting both artist and brand affinity.

So Songtradr makes a point to highlight those gaining traction now, that feature songs any brand can leverage to jump on the bandwagon.

These are three of the more notable trends that bubbled to the surface in March, and the music they used.

 1. Track: “Make Your Own Kind of Music” by Mama Cass
    Trend: “The Pedro Pascal Car” Trend
    Pedro Pascal is everywhere these days, so why not on TikTok as well? This trend has users posting videos accompanied by text, depicting another person as confused or apprehensive, and then cutting to Pedro – all to the sound of the Mama Cass classic.
 2. Track: “Happy With You”
    Trend: “Just Wanted To Let You Know” Trend
    Posting mundane updates about your life that has no real significance, shared as a joke, using this track created in TikTok’s Official Sound Studio and using the glittery CapCut template.
 3. Track: “Ceilings” by Lizzy McAlpine
    Trend: Ceilings Trend

Notably, two of the three tracks highlighted feature variations of songs by Taylor Swift, who’s currently on tour.

 1. Track: Olivia Rodrigo- Vampire
    Trend: She’s Doing What?
    The emerging trend highlights personal development and overcoming challenges. Users juxtapose past moments with sassy captions targeting doubters, followed by clips showcasing their current achievements.
 2. Track: Original Sound- sp33dsongsx
    Trend: Text Your Ex/Crush Challenge
    The engaging trend features a fast-paced rendition of Taylor Swift's ""We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together,"" using a spinning clown face to select participants who then send messages to exes or crushes. Caution is advised due to potential music rights issues, as the song is listed as 'original sound' on TikTok, but is actually a Taylor Swift track.
 3. Track: Fearless (the sped-up sound version) r & m <33
    Trend: The “My Red Flags” trend
    In this trend, creators utilize a sped-up Taylor Swift track and the My Red Flags filter to share their unique ""red flags,"" which are quirky traits that serve as potential ""warning signs."" These selections construct a sonic profile that resonates with Chevrolet's target audience and conveys the desired emotions.<br></p>",64d52e1800da3e0001667887,"Rival Sons' track ""Pressure and Time,"" despite being over a decade old, has experienced a resurgence in popularity after being featured in Chevrolet's ""Adventure is Everywhere"" Silverado advertisement.

According to Songtradr:

 * Since being featured in the spot, ""Pressure and Time"" has garnered over 12 million streams on Spotify, and earned it's highest popularity on the platform within the past year.
 * TikTok streams of the track have more than doubled since April 2022, and experienced a 53% increase since the TV ad's premiere.

Further, Chevy's strategic choice of songs like Fleetwood Mac's ""Everywhere"" and Tedeschi Trucks Band's ""Anyhow"" exude high scores in ""danceability,"" ""energy,"" and ""liveliness,"" according to Songtradr. These selections construct a sonic profile that resonates with Chevrolet's target audience and conveys the desired emotions.

In 2023, the company relies on Lainey Wilson's ""Heart Like A Truck"" and Greta Van Fleet's ""Meeting The Master"" in their ads, capitalizing on their energy and danceability to resonate with viewers and cultivate brand affinity for Ram.

 * ""Heart Like A Truck"" and ""Meeting The Master"" are standout choices with above-average danceability scores of 59/100 and 67/100 respectively, according to Songtradr data.

<!--kg-card-end: html-->",64d6344b00da3e00016679d2,"According to iSpot data shared with WardsAuto, Chevrolet once again tops the ranking of most-seen auto ads on TV. ""Build,"" highlighting the Silverado model, received 295.5 million national TV ad impressions from July 31 through August 6. The top impressions-driving program was House Hunters (9.8 million impressions), while CNN led for network impression delivery (29.4 million).

 * Ram Trucks owns the No. 2 ad, which received 230.3 million national TV ad impressions. It was the only commercial on the ranking that aired during the 2023 NFL Hall of Fame game on Aug. 3
 * Subaru was the most-seen brand on the ranking, with two spots (No. 3 and No. 5) that ran up a combined 323.6 million TV ad impressions. The fifth-place ad for the Forester featured a father and his deaf son, a pair that resonated with audiences: According to iSpot's Creative Assessment, 19% of surveyed viewers found the characters to be the best thing about the commercial.
 * Over 60% of the 163 million national TV ad impressions received by Kia's fourth-place spot came from primetime ad airings.

""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Tubular found that:  ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""In 1H 2023, news related videos posted from 10 p.m.-Midnight ET on YouTube saw the most views within the first 24 hours. While breaking news can happen at any time of day, packaging up evergreen content that stretches beyond the news cycle can be best served when many are night scrolling before bed.""]],[[0,[],0,""Speaking of evergreen content, Tubular found that news topics on education and entertainment can live well-beyond their initial go-live date. During 1H, Insider Edition leveraged thrilling law enforcement videos that continue to compound viewership & ROI over time. The publisher received nearly 3x more views on YouTube videos originally posted 1-2 years prior than all the other creators combined.""]]]],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>As part of its<a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/h2-2023-social-video-trends/""> H2 2023 Social Video Trends Report</a>, Tubular Labs is taking a closer look into what’s keeping the attention of viewers on social media. Particularly for news creators, it can be challenging to push past the 24-hour news cycle, but digging into trends from the first half of the year reveal opportunities for news publishers looking to expand their reach on social media. </p><p>Tubular found that:  </p><ul><li>In 1H 2023, news related videos posted from 10 p.m.-Midnight ET on YouTube saw the most views within the first 24 hours. While breaking news can happen at any time of day, packaging up evergreen content that stretches beyond the news cycle can be best served when many are night scrolling before bed.</li><li>Speaking of evergreen content, Tubular found that news topics on education and entertainment can live well-beyond their initial go-live date. During 1H, Insider Edition leveraged thrilling law enforcement videos that continue to compound viewership &amp; ROI over time. The publisher received nearly 3x more views on YouTube videos originally posted 1-2 years prior than all the other creators combined.</li></ul>",64d679e500da3e0001667a19,"As part of its H2 2023 Social Video Trends Report, Tubular Labs is taking a closer look into what’s keeping the attention of viewers on social media. Particularly for news creators, it can be challenging to push past the 24-hour news cycle, but digging into trends from the first half of the year reveal opportunities for news publishers looking to expand their reach on social media.

Tubular found that:  

 * In 1H 2023, news related videos posted from 10 p.m.-Midnight ET on YouTube saw the most views within the first 24 hours. While breaking news can happen at any time of day, packaging up evergreen content that stretches beyond the news cycle can be best served when many are night scrolling before bed.
 * Speaking of evergreen content, Tubular found that news topics on education and entertainment can live well-beyond their initial go-live date. During 1H, Insider Edition leveraged thrilling law enforcement videos that continue to compound viewership & ROI over time. ""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""See which ""],[0,[1],1,""programs dominated TV watch-time here""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><em>Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for August 7-13 — head over to <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/nfl-takes-its-place-atop-inscapes-most-watched-program-rankingnbsp"">TVREV to see the program ranking and insights about the top shows by watch-time</a>.</em></p><p>CBS leads for network watch-time, capturing a 6.57% viewership share fueled in part by <em>The Price Is Right</em>, <em>CBS Mornings</em> and PGA Tour golf. NBC slips from first to second place week-over-week with 6.30% of minutes watched, while ABC holds steady in third (6.13% of watch-time).</p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from August 7-13:</p><ul><li>NFL Network — the only network that will broadcast the entire slate of preseason games — jumps into the top ten with a 2.01% viewership share.</li><li>Oxygen is the only additional week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 25 with 1.01% of watch-time driven largely by <em>Dateline: Secrets Uncovered</em> and <em>Killer Relationship With Faith Jenkins</em>.</li><li>All of the networks that maintain their ranking positions week-over-week saw a decrease in watch-time, while each of the networks that move up the chart had an increase in minutes watched (which seems obvious, but is not always the case!).  </li></ul><p>See which <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/nfl-takes-its-place-atop-inscapes-most-watched-program-rankingnbsp"">programs dominated TV watch-time here</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug7-13.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug7-13.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug7-13.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug7-13.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",64db791721f2b100011da8b3,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for August 7-13 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and insights about the top shows by watch-time.

CBS leads for network watch-time, capturing a 6.57% viewership share fueled in part by The Price Is Right, CBS Mornings and PGA Tour golf. NBC slips from first to second place week-over-week with 6.30% of minutes watched, while ABC holds steady in third (6.13% of watch-time).

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from August 7-13:

 * NFL Network — the only network that will broadcast the entire slate of preseason games — jumps into the top ten with a 2.01% viewership share.
 * Oxygen is the only additional week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 25 with 1.01% of watch-time driven largely by Dateline: Secrets Uncovered and Killer Relationship With Faith Jenkins.
 * All of the networks that maintain their ranking positions week-over-week saw a decrease in watch-time, while each of the networks that move up the chart had an increase in minutes watched (which seems obvious, but is not always the case!).

the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/the-rise-and-sort-of-fall-of-binge-watching""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""]"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png"",""width"":2500,""height"":3387,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/the-rise-and-sort-of-fall-of-binge-watching""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of <a href=""http://parrotanalytics.com/?ref=themeasure.net""><em>Parrot Analytics</em></a>.</em></p><p>From the start of 2020 through July 30, 2023, Parrot Analytics examined the changes in both supply and demand shares for various release strategies among the 50 most popular streaming original series in the U.S. What they found is that neither binge nor episodic releases are foolproof approaches, and perhaps the hybrid (periodic) release strategy could be the way to go.</p><ul><li>The supply share, representing the number of series with a binge release that made the top 50, has decreased by 14% (versus a 15% decline in demand share).</li><li>In that same span, episodic weekly releases saw a 2% decline in supply share and a 3% decline in demand share. </li><li>Periodic releases, which still often release the majority of its episodes one at a time, rose 16% in supply share and 18% in demand share. </li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/the-rise-and-sort-of-fall-of-binge-watching"">read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV</a>]</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/the-rise-and-sort-of-fall-of-binge-watching""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""2710"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w2400/2023/08/PP_12_6--1-.png 2400w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",64e4f03bcddf040001292bc2,"The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of Parrot Analytics.

From the start of 2020 through July 30, 2023, Parrot Analytics examined the changes in both supply and demand shares for various release strategies among the 50 most popular streaming original series in the U.S. What they found is that neither binge nor episodic releases are foolproof approaches, and perhaps the hybrid (periodic) release strategy could be the way to go.

 * The supply share, representing the number of series with a binge release that made the top 50, has decreased by 14% (versus a 15% decline in demand share).
 * In that same span, episodic weekly releases saw a 2% decline in supply share and a 3% decline in demand share.
 * Periodic releases, which still often release the majority of its episodes one at a time, rose 16% in supply share and 18% in demand share.

[read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV]",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1586899028174-e7098604235b?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDV8fG5ldGZsaXh8ZW58MHx8fHwxNjkyNzI1OTE4fDA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-22T17:28:27.000Z,2023-10-31T21:38:42.000Z,2023-08-16T04:00:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,64e4f24ecddf040001292bfb,1e05637e-727c-44c2-800e-319a4db06b91,Time Zone Challenges Of The Women's World Cup,time-zone-challenges-of-the-womens-world-cup,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-22-at-10.36.22-AM.png"",""width"":1006,""height"":1224,""href"":""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2023-fifa-womens-world-cup-report/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2023-fifa-womens-world-cup-report/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""With the 2023 Women's World Cup hosted by Australia and New Zealand, time zone issues were a major challenge as Fox had to balance reasonable match times with when U.S. TV audiences could actually tune in. ""],[0,[0],1,""iSpot's new report recapping the event""],[0,[],0,"" shares more.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""While Fox was able to put a priority on primetime, where 20% of TV ad impressions were delivered this year, vs. just 4% for the full 2019 tournament.""]],[[0,[],0,""But plenty of matches also took place virtually overnight, or in the early morning hours""]],[[0,[],0,""Overnight ad impressions jump from 3% to 16% year-over-year, while early morning grows from 1% to 14%. ""]],[[0,[],0,""So while the World Cup certainly had more energy behind it and more brands appearing during matches, the time zone issues also make it more difficult for advertisers to get significant reach like they would with a more feasible location (for reference, the 2019 World Cup took place in France).""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>With the 2023 Women's World Cup hosted by Australia and New Zealand, time zone issues were a major challenge as Fox had to balance reasonable match times with when U.S. TV audiences could actually tune in. <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2023-fifa-womens-world-cup-report/"">iSpot's new report recapping the event</a> shares more.</p><ul><li>While Fox was able to put a priority on primetime, where 20% of TV ad impressions were delivered this year, vs. just 4% for the full 2019 tournament.</li><li>But plenty of matches also took place virtually overnight, or in the early morning hours</li><li>Overnight ad impressions jump from 3% to 16% year-over-year, while early morning grows from 1% to 14%. </li><li>So while the World Cup certainly had more energy behind it and more brands appearing during matches, the time zone issues also make it more difficult for advertisers to get significant reach like they would with a more feasible location (for reference, the 2019 World Cup took place in France).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/2023-fifa-womens-world-cup-report/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-22-at-10.36.22-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1006"" height=""1224"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-22-at-10.36.22-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-22-at-10.36.22-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-22-at-10.36.22-AM.png 1006w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",64e4f24ecddf040001292bfb,"With the 2023 Women's World Cup hosted by Australia and New Zealand, time zone issues were a major challenge as Fox had to balance reasonable match times with when U.S. TV audiences could actually tune in. iSpot's new report recapping the event shares more.

 * While Fox was able to put a priority on primetime, where 20% of TV ad impressions were delivered this year, vs. just 4% for the full 2019 tournament.
 * But plenty of matches also took place virtually overnight, or in the early morning hours
 * Overnight ad impressions jump from 3% to 16% year-over-year, while early morning grows from 1% to 14%.
 * So while the World Cup certainly had more energy behind it and more brands appearing during matches, the time zone issues also make it more difficult for advertisers to get significant reach like they would with a more feasible location (for reference, the 2019 World Cup took place in France).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1520363909542-9f69145ab443?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDV8fHNvY2NlciUyMGJhbGwlMjB3b21lbnxlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTI3MjU5Mzl8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-22T17:37:18.000Z,2023-08-22T17:42:34.000Z,2023-08-16T04:00:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,64e50b1fcddf040001292c2c,2e8a2e20-9688-4f74-b6b9-000a1d34511c,Do Cable News Viewers Still Care About Trump's Indictments?,do-cable-news-viewers-still-care-about-trumps-indictments,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/TrumpIndictmentTimeline.png"",""width"":1375,""height"":847}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""inscape.tv""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://ispot.tv/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/news/4-months-4-indictments-how-much-do-cable-news-viewers-still-carenbsp""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""August brought not one, but two new indictments for Donald Trump. (This Thursday, the former president is set to voluntarily surrender in Georgia and pay the $200,000 bond, checking off arraignment #4). ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""How much of a 'Trump bump' is cable news getting with all this? ""],[0,[0],1,""Inscape""],[0,[],0,"" examined viewership trends for CNN, Fox News and MSNBC over the last few months as all of this has gone down. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Notably, viewership was higher across the board on arraignment days vs. indictment days, perhaps because people were more interested in hearing how Trump would react and plea than learning the nitty gritty details of the charges themselves. ""]],[[0,[],0,""Fox News captured more tune-in than CNN and MSNBC by a wide margin, sometimes with a 2-3x higher viewership share, while MSNBC scored slightly higher viewership than CNN for each of the indictment and arraignment days.""]],[[0,[],0,""Per ""],[0,[1],1,""iSpot.tv""],[0,[],0,"", so far in 2023, CNN’s audience (based on median TV ad impressions) skews just slightly younger: 50 to 54 years old, vs. Fox News and MSNBC which both have a median age range of 55-59 years old.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Read more at ""],[0,[2],1,""TVREV.com""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,"" ""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>August brought not one, but two new indictments for Donald Trump. That makes four in under five months, but who's counting anymore? (This Thursday, the former president is set to voluntarily surrender in Georgia and pay the $200,000 bond, checking off arraignment #4). </p><p>How much of a 'Trump bump' is cable news getting with all this? <a href=""inscape.tv"">Inscape</a> examined viewership trends for CNN, Fox News and MSNBC over the last few months as all of this has gone down. </p><ul><li>Notably, viewership was higher across the board on arraignment days vs. indictment days, perhaps because people were more interested in hearing how Trump would react and plea than learning the nitty gritty details of the charges themselves. </li><li>Fox News captured more tune-in than CNN and MSNBC by a wide margin, sometimes with a 2-3x higher viewership share, while MSNBC scored slightly higher viewership than CNN for each of the indictment and arraignment days.</li><li>Per <a href=""http://ispot.tv/"">iSpot.tv</a>, so far in 2023, CNN’s audience (based on median TV ad impressions) skews just slightly younger: 50 to 54 years old, vs. Fox News and MSNBC which both have a median age range of 55-59 years old.</li></ul><p>Read more at <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/4-months-4-indictments-how-much-do-cable-news-viewers-still-carenbsp"">TVREV.com</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/TrumpIndictmentTimeline.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1375"" height=""847"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/TrumpIndictmentTimeline.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/TrumpIndictmentTimeline.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/TrumpIndictmentTimeline.png 1375w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure><p> </p>",64e50b1fcddf040001292c2c,"August brought not one, but two new indictments for Donald Trump. That makes four in under five months, but who's counting anymore? (This Thursday, the former president is set to voluntarily surrender in Georgia and pay the $200,000 bond, checking off arraignment #4).

How much of a 'Trump bump' is cable news getting with all this? Inscape examined viewership trends for CNN, Fox News and MSNBC over the last few months as all of this has gone down.

 * Notably, viewership was higher across the board on arraignment days vs. indictment days, perhaps because people were more interested in hearing how Trump would react and plea than learning the nitty gritty details of the charges themselves.
 * Fox News captured more tune-in than CNN and MSNBC by a wide margin, sometimes with a 2-3x higher viewership share, while MSNBC scored slightly higher viewership than CNN for each of the indictment and arraignment days.
 * Per iSpot.tv, so far in 2023, CNN’s audience (based on median TV ad impressions) skews just slightly younger: 50 to 54 years old, vs. Fox News and MSNBC which both have a median age range of 55-59 years old.

Read more at TVREV.com.

""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Ram Trucks is squeezing the last bit of fun out of summer with its ad highlighting the features of the Ram 1500 pickup truck. The spot increased national TV ad impressions 16.2% week-over-week, taking first place on <a href=""https://www.wardsauto.com/industry-news/ram-trucks-savors-summer-most-seen-auto-tv-ad"">iSpot's latest ranking of the most-seen auto ads on TV</a>.</p><ul><li>According to <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/products/creative-testing"">iSpot’s Creative Assessment</a>, the Ram Trucks commercial had an 87% brand match (the percentage of survey respondents who remembered it was a Ram Trucks ad after watching it), above the recent automaker industry norm of 77%.</li><li>Chevrolet took second place with ""Build,"" which received 305.2 million national TV ad impressions. Much of that was driven by news programming: CNN (29.7 million) and MSNBC (28.7 million) led for impression-driving networks, while top programs included <em>Good Morning America</em> (9.1 million), <em>Dateline</em> (8.7 million), <em>CNN News Central </em>(6.3 million) and <em>CNN Primetime</em> (6 million).</li><li>Hyundai was the only week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 3 with 216.5 million national TV ad impressions for a ""Getaway Sales Event"" spot. </li></ul><!--kg-card-begin: html-->                    <div style=""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;""><iframe src=""https://www.ispot.tv/share/14aU"" style=""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;"" frameborder=""0"" scrolling=""no"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe></div>
                    <!--kg-card-end: html-->",64e8a2f570850b0001bd1af0,"Ram Trucks is squeezing the last bit of fun out of summer with its ad highlighting the features of the Ram 1500 pickup truck. The spot increased national TV ad impressions 16.2% week-over-week, taking first place on iSpot's latest ranking of the most-seen auto ads on TV.

 * According to iSpot’s Creative Assessment, the Ram Trucks commercial had an 87% brand match (the percentage of survey respondents who remembered it was a Ram Trucks ad after watching it), above the recent automaker industry norm of 77%.
 * Chevrolet took second place with ""Build,"" which received 305.2 million national TV ad impressions. Much of that was driven by news programming: CNN (29.7 million) and MSNBC (28.7 million) led for impression-driving networks, while top programs included Good Morning America (9.1 million), Dateline (8.7 million), CNN News Central (6.3 million) and CNN Primetime (6 million).
 * Hyundai was the only week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 3 with 216.5 million national TV ad impressions for a ""Getaway Sales Event"" spot.

For U.S. videos earning at least 1 million views, 0-1 minute videos have accounted for 74.3% of uploads so far in Q3 2023, and 81.2% of views. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""For uploads, that’s about even with Q2 (74.3% as well), but is up significantly compared to Q1 2023 (70.5%) and Q1 2022 (53.8%).""]],[[0,[],0,""Since Q1 2022, videos from 1-2 minutes in length steadily increased from 6.7% of uploads (of U.S. videos with at least 1 million views), to 10.0% so far this quarter. Similarly, share of views rose from 6.8% in Q1 2022 to 10.4% this quarter so far.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""[""],[0,[1],1,""Read more at TVREV""],[0,[],0,""]""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>New data from <a href=""http://tubularlabs.com/"">Tubular Labs</a> shows just how much YouTube’s most successful U.S. videos are leaning on shorter formats in recent quarters. For U.S. videos earning at least 1 million views, 0-1 minute videos have accounted for 74.3% of uploads so far in Q3 2023, and 81.2% of views. </p><ul><li>For uploads, that’s about even with Q2 (74.3% as well), but is up significantly compared to Q1 2023 (70.5%) and Q1 2022 (53.8%).</li><li>Since Q1 2022, videos from 1-2 minutes in length steadily increased from 6.7% of uploads (of U.S. videos with at least 1 million views), to 10.0% so far this quarter. Similarly, share of views rose from 6.8% in Q1 2022 to 10.4% this quarter so far.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/youtube-tubular-labs-longer-on-shorts-videos-data"">Read more at TVREV</a>]</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Tubular-Shorts-SOV.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1375"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Tubular-Shorts-SOV.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Tubular-Shorts-SOV.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Tubular-Shorts-SOV.jpg 1375w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",64e920de70850b0001bd1b3c,"New data from Tubular Labs shows just how much YouTube’s most successful U.S. videos are leaning on shorter formats in recent quarters. For U.S. videos earning at least 1 million views, 0-1 minute videos have accounted for 74.3% of uploads so far in Q3 2023, and 81.2% of views.

 * For uploads, that’s about even with Q2 (74.3% as well), but is up significantly compared to Q1 2023 (70.5%) and Q1 2022 (53.8%).
 * Since Q1 2022, videos from 1-2 minutes in length steadily increased from 6.7% of uploads (of U.S. videos with at least 1 million views), to 10.0% so far this quarter. Similarly, share of views rose from 6.8% in Q1 2022 to 10.4% this quarter so far.

This approach has recently expanded from just rock music, now spanning various genres.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[1],1,""Songtradr""],[0,[],0,"" examined what these song choices have in common – despite genre differences – and how they help to create a uniform brand identity for Taco Bell and its intended audience.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[2,2],2,""Bludnymph – “FEAST”""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Used in ad herself on social media""],[0,[],0,"")""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[2,2],2,""Meet Me @ The Altar: “Say It (To My Face)”""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Another song choice that aligns with Taco Bell's goals, the pop-punk track appeals to younger consumers with high energy (90/100) and danceability (51/100) for their ""],[0,[6],1,""$2 grilled chicken burrito ad""],[0,[],0,"".""]],[[0,[],0,""Taco Bell also capitalized on the song's rising popularity, featuring it in ads shortly before the band's performance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, highlighting the strategy of synchronizing music promotion with emerging social trends and moments in culture.""]]]],[10,1],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Taco Bell is known for its iconic sonic logo (the “bong” sound) in ads, but the brand also uses a <a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/blog/posts/fast-food-industry-music-in-advertising/?utm_campaign=taco_bell&amp;utm_source=fabric&amp;utm_medium=article"">range of upbeat songs</a> in its spots that align with the product being advertised. This approach has recently expanded from just rock music, now spanning various genres.</p><p><a href=""Songtradr.com"">Songtradr</a> examined what these song choices have in common – despite genre differences – and how they help to create a uniform brand identity for Taco Bell and its intended audience.</p><p><strong><strong>Bludnymph – “FEAST”</strong></strong></p><ul><li>Used in <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1IvI/taco-bell-double-steak-grilled-cheese-burrito-lets-eat"">Taco Bell's top ad of 2023</a>, the 2021 release gained popularity after being used in an episode of Netflix's <em>Heartbreak High, </em>and another bump on TikTok after the Taco Bell commercial aired.</li><li>The song's TikTok popularity appeals to younger audiences, aligning with Taco Bell's brand goals by using a socially endemic artist and vibrant sonic characteristics.</li><li>Limited use of the song elsewhere also let the brand carve out a unique association with both the song and artist (who has also <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/p/Cp_IOViPBb4/"">pushed the ad herself on social media</a>)</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><a href=""Songtradr.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-11.53.39-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1640"" height=""818"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-11.53.39-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-11.53.39-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-11.53.39-AM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-11.53.39-AM.png 1640w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a><figcaption><em>Data provided by Songtradr</em></figcaption></figure><p><strong><strong>Meet Me @ The Altar: “Say It (To My Face)”</strong></strong></p><ul><li>Another song choice that aligns with Taco Bell's goals, the pop-punk track appeals to younger consumers with high energy (90/100) and danceability (51/100) for their <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/2XHS/taco-bell-2-grilled-chicken-burritos-drones-song-by-meet-me-the-altar"">$2 grilled chicken burrito ad</a>.</li><li>Taco Bell also capitalized on the song's rising popularity, featuring it in ads shortly before the band's performance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, highlighting the strategy of synchronizing music promotion with emerging social trends and moments in culture.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-12.12.16-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""745"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-12.12.16-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-12.12.16-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-12.12.16-PM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-07-25-at-12.12.16-PM.png 2048w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""><figcaption><em>Data provided by Songtradr</em></figcaption></figure><p><br></p>",64eceb1870850b0001bd1b6c,"Taco Bell is known for its iconic sonic logo (the “bong” sound) in ads, but the brand also uses a range of upbeat songs in its spots that align with the product being advertised. This approach has recently expanded from just rock music, now spanning various genres.

Songtradr examined what these song choices have in common – despite genre differences – and how they help to create a uniform brand identity for Taco Bell and its intended audience.

Bludnymph – “FEAST”

 * Used in Taco Bell's top ad of 2023, the 2021 release gained popularity after being used in an episode of Netflix's Heartbreak High, and another bump on TikTok after the Taco Bell commercial aired.
 * The song's TikTok popularity appeals to younger audiences, aligning with Taco Bell's brand goals by using a socially endemic artist and vibrant sonic characteristics.
 * Limited use of the song elsewhere also let the brand carve out a unique association with both the song and artist (who has also pushed the ad herself on social media)

Meet Me @ The Altar: “Say It (To My Face)”

 * Another song choice that aligns with Taco Bell's goals, the pop-punk track appeals to younger consumers with high energy (90/100) and danceability (51/100) for their $2 grilled chicken burrito ad.
 * Taco Bell also capitalized on the song's rising popularity, featuring it in ads shortly before the band's performance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, highlighting the strategy of synchronizing music promotion with emerging social trends and moments in culture.

Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for August 21-27 — head over to <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/tv-viewership-data-sports-season-is-officially-here"">TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time</a>.</em></p><p>Remarkably, 20 of the top 25 networks maintain their ranking positions week-over-week, a dearth of movement that we haven’t seen in a long time. But that being said, nine of the networks had slight increases in viewership share compared to the previous week, including the top six networks.</p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from August 21-27:</p><ul><li>In first place is CBS, which captured 6.69% of all minutes watched, up from 6.49%, fueled in part by the 2023 Tour Championship.  </li><li>ABC took second place with 6.46% of watch-time, with top contributing programs including <em>Good Morning America</em>, the 2023 Little League World Series and <em>ABC News Tonight With David Muir</em>.</li><li>At No. 3 is NBC, with its 6.43% viewership share driven in part by <em>Today</em>, <em>America’s Got Talent</em> and <em>NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt</em>.</li><li>HGTV (No. 10) and History (No. 22) were the only two networks to increase ranking position week-over-week, but HGTV’s viewership share actually decreased while History’s went up a tad. </li></ul><p>See which programs <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/tv-viewership-data-sports-season-is-officially-here"">dominated TV watch-time for Aug. 21-27 here</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug21-27.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug21-27.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug21-27.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/InscapeTopNetworksAug21-27.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",64ee01abd360bf00019ad95e,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for August 21-27 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

Remarkably, 20 of the top 25 networks maintain their ranking positions week-over-week, a dearth of movement that we haven’t seen in a long time. But that being said, nine of the networks had slight increases in viewership share compared to the previous week, including the top six networks.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from August 21-27:

 * In first place is CBS, which captured 6.69% of all minutes watched, up from 6.49%, fueled in part by the 2023 Tour Championship.  
 * ABC took second place with 6.46% of watch-time, with top contributing programs including Good Morning America, the 2023 Little League World Series and ABC News Tonight With David Muir.
 * At No. 3 is NBC, with its 6.43% viewership share driven in part by Today, America’s Got Talent and NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt.
 * HGTV (No. 10) and History (No. 22) were the only two networks to increase ranking position week-over-week, but HGTV’s viewership share actually decreased while History’s went up a tad.
