",,,,,,1,64efa2aead98010001011f15,c66151b7-0a9f-4b50-af15-d4e5346f6353,Betting On 'Friends': How Sportsbook TV Ads Are Evolving,betting-on-friends-how-sportsbook-tv-ads-are-evolving,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-29-at-12.46.58-PM.png"",""width"":1238,""height"":1188,""href"":""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/sports-betting-tv-ad-transparency-report/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/sports-betting-tv-ad-transparency-report/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2023/04/the-sports-betting-ads-are-awful-and-theyre-not-going-away.html""]],[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/news/betting-tv-advertising-expanding-reach-sports-audiences-ispot""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""iSpot’s ""],[0,[0],1,""new report on sportsbook TV advertising""],[0,[],0,"" shows that the industry has managed to grow TV ad impressions, while also expanding its footprint beyond one that was decidedly focused on football to-date. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""From Jan. 1-Aug. 15, 2023, sportsbook household TV ad impressions were up 25% vs. the same stretch in 2022. Importantly, “just” 58% of those impressions were delivered by sports programming. By contrast, that figure was 74% the year before.""]],[[0,[],0,""Perhaps as a response to repeated calls of there being ""],[0,[1],1,""too many betting ads""],[0,[],0,"" — particularly during games — top brands in the space have aimed to diversify the programming where ad buys occur. ""]],[[0,[],0,""For instance, while the NBA and NFL have still led the way for sportsbook TV ad impressions so far, you’ll also find programs like ""],[0,[2],1,""Friends""],[0,[],0,"", ""],[0,[2],1,""On Patrol: Live""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[2],1,""South Park""],[0,[],0,"" high on the list, with considerable jumps compared to last year.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""[""],[0,[3],1,""Read more at TVREV""],[0,[],0,""]""]]],[10,0]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>iSpot’s <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/sports-betting-tv-ad-transparency-report/"">new report on sportsbook TV advertising</a> shows that the industry has managed to grow TV ad impressions, while also expanding its footprint beyond one that was decidedly focused on football to-date. </p><ul><li>From Jan. 1-Aug. 15, 2023, sportsbook household TV ad impressions were up 25% vs. the same stretch in 2022. Importantly, “just” 58% of those impressions were delivered by sports programming. By contrast, that figure was 74% the year before.</li><li>Perhaps as a response to repeated calls of there being <a href=""https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2023/04/the-sports-betting-ads-are-awful-and-theyre-not-going-away.html"">too many betting ads</a> — particularly during games — top brands in the space have aimed to diversify the programming where ad buys occur. </li><li>For instance, while the NBA and NFL have still led the way for sportsbook TV ad impressions so far, you’ll also find programs like <em>Friends</em>, <em>On Patrol: Live</em> and <em>South Park</em> high on the list, with considerable jumps compared to last year.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/betting-tv-advertising-expanding-reach-sports-audiences-ispot"">Read more at TVREV</a>]</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/sports-betting-tv-ad-transparency-report/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-29-at-12.46.58-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1238"" height=""1188"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-29-at-12.46.58-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-29-at-12.46.58-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/Screen-Shot-2023-08-29-at-12.46.58-PM.png 1238w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",64efa2aead98010001011f15,"iSpot’s new report on sportsbook TV advertising shows that the industry has managed to grow TV ad impressions, while also expanding its footprint beyond one that was decidedly focused on football to-date.

 * From Jan. 1-Aug. 15, 2023, sportsbook household TV ad impressions were up 25% vs. the same stretch in 2022. Importantly, “just” 58% of those impressions were delivered by sports programming. By contrast, that figure was 74% the year before.
 * Perhaps as a response to repeated calls of there being too many betting ads — particularly during games — top brands in the space have aimed to diversify the programming where ad buys occur.
 * For instance, while the NBA and NFL have still led the way for sportsbook TV ad impressions so far, you’ll also find programs like Friends, On Patrol: Live and South Park high on the list, with considerable jumps compared to last year.

"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""In other words, the streaming industry isn’t pumping out as many new shows per quarter as it once did."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""["",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/streamings-double-edged-sword-rising-numbers-slowing-momentum""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""]"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of <a href=""http://parrotanalytics.com/?ref=themeasure.net""><em>Parrot Analytics</em></a>.</em></p><p>Two things can be true at once: The streaming bubble has popped and audiences will likely never again enjoy the same levels of consistent mountainous volume of content as they once did. AND... Streaming is still a growing medium overall.</p><ul><li>In this chart from Parrot Analytics, the blue vertical bars represent the total number of streaming original series that have premiered in their respective quarters (or earlier), indexed to the total number that premiered prior to 2020 (represented as 100). </li><li>The red line represents the percentage growth in the number of streaming originals each quarter vs the previous quarter. What it shows is that while the number of new streaming exclusive series is still going up, the rate of growth has slowed considerably since 2022 compared to the two years prior. </li><li>In other words, the streaming industry isn’t pumping out as many new shows per quarter as it once did.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/streamings-double-edged-sword-rising-numbers-slowing-momentum"">read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV</a>]</p>",64efa3a5ad98010001011f44,"The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of Parrot Analytics.

Two things can be true at once: The streaming bubble has popped and audiences will likely never again enjoy the same levels of consistent mountainous volume of content as they once did. AND... Streaming is still a growing medium overall.

 * In this chart from Parrot Analytics, the blue vertical bars represent the total number of streaming original series that have premiered in their respective quarters (or earlier), indexed to the total number that premiered prior to 2020 (represented as 100).
 * The red line represents the percentage growth in the number of streaming originals each quarter vs the previous quarter. What it shows is that while the number of new streaming exclusive series is still going up, the rate of growth has slowed considerably since 2022 compared to the two years prior.
 * In other words, the streaming industry isn’t pumping out as many new shows per quarter as it once did.

[read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV]",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/digital_originals_growth.png,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-30T20:16:37.000Z,2023-10-31T21:38:28.000Z,2023-08-29T10:00:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,64efa56dad98010001011f69,421d5147-c5e1-435c-9de5-6e6ad6e0b432,A+E’s Unscripted Hot American Summer,a-es-hot-unscripted-american-summer-social-video-tv,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg"",""width"":1347,""height"":787}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://tubularlabs.com""]],[""em""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""A+E’s slate of evergreen unscripted content has been paying major dividends this summer. ""],[0,[0],1,""Tubular Audience Ratings""],[0,[],0,"" data shows A+E was the No. 4 U.S. media property by domestic minutes watched (across YouTube and Facebook) in July, jumping 29% month-over-month.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Most-viewed videos came from unscripted shows like ""],[0,[1],1,""How The Earth Was Made""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[1],1,""Little Women: Atlanta""],[0,[],0,"" from History Channel and Lifetime, respectively. ""]],[[0,[],0,""By comparison, other media companies (largely more reliant on scripted shows and/or live sports) saw more modest increases or slight dips for the month of July.""]],[[0,[],0,""This dynamic is one to follow for major media properties heading into the fall, as there's less scripted programming given the writers' and actors' strikes, and more unscripted content across TV networks (though streaming services like Apple TV+ seem to have larger banks of content in waiting).""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>A+E’s slate of evergreen unscripted content has been paying major dividends this summer. <a href=""http://tubularlabs.com"">Tubular Audience Ratings</a> data shows A+E was the No. 4 U.S. media property by domestic minutes watched (across YouTube and Facebook) in July, jumping 29% month-over-month.</p><ul><li>Most-viewed videos came from unscripted shows like <em>How The Earth Was Made</em> and <em>Little Women: Atlanta</em> from History Channel and Lifetime, respectively. </li><li>By comparison, other media companies (largely more reliant on scripted shows and/or live sports) saw more modest increases or slight dips for the month of July.</li><li>This dynamic is one to follow for major media properties heading into the fall, as there's less scripted programming given the writers' and actors' strikes, and more unscripted content across TV networks (though streaming services like Apple TV+ seem to have larger banks of content in waiting).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1347"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/08/tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/08/tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/08/tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 1347w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",64efa56dad98010001011f69,"A+E’s slate of evergreen unscripted content has been paying major dividends this summer. Tubular Audience Ratings data shows A+E was the No. 4 U.S. media property by domestic minutes watched (across YouTube and Facebook) in July, jumping 29% month-over-month.

 * Most-viewed videos came from unscripted shows like How The Earth Was Made and Little Women: Atlanta from History Channel and Lifetime, respectively.
 * By comparison, other media companies (largely more reliant on scripted shows and/or live sports) saw more modest increases or slight dips for the month of July.
 * This dynamic is one to follow for major media properties heading into the fall, as there's less scripted programming given the writers' and actors' strikes, and more unscripted content across TV networks (though streaming services like Apple TV+ seem to have larger banks of content in waiting).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1473496169904-658ba7c44d8a?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDJ8fHN1bW1lcnxlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTM0MjcyNDJ8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-08-30T20:24:13.000Z,2023-08-30T20:30:20.000Z,2023-08-30T20:28:14.000Z,,,,,,,1,64f1d95ead98010001011f9a,28492cac-096a-498b-89e2-84eb68ac95de,Chevy Back on Top of Most-Seen Auto TV Ads Chart,chevy-back-on-top-of-most-seen-auto-tv-ads,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""html"",{""html"":""                    <div style=\""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;\""><iframe src=\""https://www.ispot.tv/share/1X2T\"" style=\""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;\"" frameborder=\""0\"" scrolling=\""no\"" allowfullscreen=\""\""></iframe></div>\n                    ""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.wardsauto.com/industry-news/four-top-five-most-seen-auto-ads-aired-during-little-league-world-series""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/products/creative-testing""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""With 310.7 million national TV ad impressions, a commercial for the Chevrolet Silverado takes first place on ""],[0,[0],1,""iSpot's latest ranking of the most-seen auto ads on TV.""],[0,[],0,"" It had 44% more impressions than the No. 2 spot, a promotion for a Hyundai sales events. Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for August 28 through September 3 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

Following a week that saw minimal movement on the network ranking, things have shuffled about and there are a few new faces that make the top 25. Driven by coverage of Hurricane Idalia, The Weather Channel jumps to No. 15, up from No. 47 previously, with 1.55% of watch-time, while ESPN2 lands at No. 20 (up from No. 45) thanks in part to the 2023. U.S. Open tennis tournament.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from August 28 through September 3:

 * ABC takes first place with a 7.19% viewership share thanks in part to college football games, Good Morning America and ABC World News Tonight With David Muir.
 * Fox’s week-over-week viewership increase (up to 4.47% to 5.34%) is due in part to college football and MLB games.
 * Fueled by reruns of Yellowstone, Paramount Network moves from No. 41 to No. 21 with a 1.01% viewership share.

Examining Q2 over the past three years, streaming’s share of viewing has increased from 44.1% to 53.8% in Q2 since 2021. Meanwhile, cable/satellite’s share has fallen from 46.9% to 37.1%.</p><p>Free ad-support streaming TV (FASTs) are also gaining traction, with viewing time increasing by 70% in Q2 2023 compared to Q2 2022. </p><p>Get more viewership insights by downloading <a href=""https://www.inscape.tv/resources/insights/2023/market-trends-report-q2-2023"">Inscape’s Q2 report for free here</a>. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""https://lh4.googleusercontent.com/xT32ZRAL-nmGwigJBRVnVXHAhvABA04g-dY6id364n70MSVE8356Xsvq8pg4EftGdg4cwCkBJ9AZXWhPBhqhcGwRKbGCycgH_rnP483_NzXMs9DPCwB0HY85FcxVaQ5hZUgDe5IkkKX9-GkpXD_owIM"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""499"" height=""281""></figure>",64f882106dac2c00014c84ed,"According to a recently-released report by Inscape, streaming has officially become the preferred viewing source of content for consumers. TVREV"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/decoding-tv-demand""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""]"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of <a href=""http://parrotanalytics.com/?ref=themeasure.net""><em>Parrot Analytics</em></a>.</em></p><p>The chart above displays the percentage of shows accounting for 50% of the total demand for each genre in the U.S., according to Parrot Analytics. This metric gauges how demand is spread across various titles.</p><ul><li>The higher the percentage, the more evenly distributed demand is among a greater number of titles. </li><li>Essentially, this chart illuminates which genres are top heavy, relying on a select few mega hits to carry the load, and which genres are more likely to produce a reliably in-demand title.</li><li>Documentaries has the most title diversification among these genres, and global share of documentary content among unscripted programming has risen from 32% in 2018 to 54% in 2022, per Parrot Analytics.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/decoding-tv-demand"">read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV</a>]</p>",64f900e4cffa740001b12854,"The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of Parrot Analytics.

The chart above displays the percentage of shows accounting for 50% of the total demand for each genre in the U.S., according to Parrot Analytics. This metric gauges how demand is spread across various titles.

 * The higher the percentage, the more evenly distributed demand is among a greater number of titles.
 * Essentially, this chart illuminates which genres are top heavy, relying on a select few mega hits to carry the load, and which genres are more likely to produce a reliably in-demand title.
 * Documentaries has the most title diversification among these genres, and global share of documentary content among unscripted programming has risen from 32% in 2018 to 54% in 2022, per Parrot Analytics.

""],[0,[0],1,""TVNewsCheck recently featured data from iSpot""],[0,[],0,"" detailing just how much the league's network partners lean on live NFL games for ad impression ""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Although overall watch-time for the full 2023 U.S. Open tennis tournament saw a slight decrease year-over-year, viewership for the days of the women's and men's singles final both saw increases vs. 2022. </p><p>According to data from <a href=""inscape.tv"">Inscape</a>, the tournament accounted for 1.86% of all live, linear minutes watched Aug. 28 through Sept. 10, 2023, down from the 2.06% share captured by the 2022 tournament. Both years it ranked third among all programs on TV by watch-time, behind college football and the NFL. </p><p>For the day of the women's singles final (Sept. 9), the U.S. Open captured a 1.39% viewership share, almost double that of the 2022 women's final day (0.76%). Both years it ranked third among all programs on TV by watch-time, behind college football and the NFL.

"",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""value"":3,""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""tag"":""ul"",""type"":""list"",""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""version"":1},{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""See which programs dominated TV watch-time for Sept. 4-10 here."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/football-us-open-lead-for-tv-watch-time"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept4-10.png"",""width"":1018,""height"":1219},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 4-10 — <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/football-us-open-lead-for-tv-watch-time"">head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time</a>.</em></p><p>Thanks largely to NFL games, NBC moves from third to first place week-over-week, capturing a 9.24% viewership share. Other programs fueling watch-time on the network include <em>Today</em>, <em>America’s Got Talent</em> and <em>NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt</em>. CBS, meanwhile, remains in second place but increased its share from 6.62% to 7.35%, driven in part by NFL and college football. </p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 4-10:</p><ul><li>Football (both college and NFL) helped drive an increase in Fox’s 7.10% share, with the network rising from fourth to third place week-over-week.</li><li>Of the top 25 networks, Oxygen had the largest week-over-week ranking increase, moving from No. 28 to No. 25 with 0.86% of minutes watched.</li><li>Additional week-over-week ranking newcomers include TNT (No. 23) and Discovery (No. 25). </li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/football-us-open-lead-for-tv-watch-time"">See which programs dominated TV watch-time for Sept. 4-10 here.</a></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept4-10.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept4-10.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept4-10.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept4-10.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",65007068183903000180de2a,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 4-10 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

Thanks largely to NFL games, NBC moves from third to first place week-over-week, capturing a 9.24% viewership share. Other programs fueling watch-time on the network include Today, America’s Got Talent and NBC Nightly News With Lester Holt. CBS, meanwhile, remains in second place but increased its share from 6.62% to 7.35%, driven in part by NFL and college football.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 4-10:

 * Football (both college and NFL) helped drive an increase in Fox’s 7.10% share, with the network rising from fourth to third place week-over-week.
 * Of the top 25 networks, Oxygen had the largest week-over-week ranking increase, moving from No. 28 to No. 25 with 0.86% of minutes watched.
 * Additional week-over-week ranking newcomers include TNT (No. 23) and Discovery (No. 25).

Collectively, they published 1.2 million posts, resulting in 75.4 billion impressions and 3 billion engagements, generating $4.8 billion in Earned Media Value (EMV) for the industry.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The top five brands — McDonald’s, Starbucks, Red Bull, Celsius and Oreo — accounted for 15.3% of the overall Share of Influence (as measured by EMV) in the food and beverage category.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Of these brands, Red Bull has the most engaged community, averaging six to seven posts per creator and $36.9K EMV each.""]],[[0,[],0,""One of the most effective posts was ""],[0,[1],1,""Supercar Blondie’s""],[0,[],0,"" exciting Meta video documenting the world’s first helipad plane landing, featuring a Red Bull-branded plane, which generated $313.1K EMV for the brand.""]],[[0,[],0,""Although it doesn’t make the top five brands, Naked Juice is one food and beverage brand making tremendous gains in 2023.""],[0,[2],1,"" ""],[0,[],0,""This includes a notable 770% HoH increase in EMV, a 23,339% increase in impressions and an 883% increase in engagement. Top creators include the ""],[0,[3],1,""Younes Family""],[0,[],0,"", ""],[0,[4],1,""Camila Langley""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[5],1,""Nicki Unplugged""],[0,[],0,"".""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The food and beverage vertical as a whole has posted notable year-over-year growth: Compared to the same time frame in 2022, EMV is up 55%, impressions have increased by 219% and engagements skyrocketed an impressive 505%.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Get ""],[0,[6],1,""more insights here""],[0,[],0,"".""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Since its beginning, social media has provided a simple and fun way for people to share what they're eating and drinking, and this year it's been no different: According to data from <a href=""http://creatoriq.com"">CreatorIQ</a>, over 437,000 creators posted on social media about food and beverage brands in the first half of 2023. Collectively, they published 1.2 million posts, resulting in 75.4 billion impressions and 3 billion engagements, generating $4.8 billion in Earned Media Value (EMV) for the industry.</p><p>The top five brands — McDonald’s, Starbucks, Red Bull, Celsius and Oreo — accounted for 15.3% of the overall Share of Influence (as measured by EMV) in the food and beverage category.</p><ul><li>Of these brands, Red Bull has the most engaged community, averaging six to seven posts per creator and $36.9K EMV each.</li><li>One of the most effective posts was <a href=""https://www.facebook.com/supercarblondie/videos/8995584280515238/"">Supercar Blondie’s</a> exciting Meta video documenting the world’s first helipad plane landing, featuring a Red Bull-branded plane, which generated $313.1K EMV for the brand.</li><li>Although it doesn’t make the top five brands, Naked Juice is one food and beverage brand making tremendous gains in 2023.<strong> </strong>This includes a notable 770% HoH increase in EMV, a 23,339% increase in impressions and an 883% increase in engagement. Top creators include the <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/@younesfamily/video/7233841363576556846"">Younes Family</a>, <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/@camila.langley/video/7233832052255247658"">Camila Langley</a> and <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/@nickiunplugged/video/7239841689979063598"">Nicki Unplugged</a>.</li></ul><p>The food and beverage vertical as a whole has posted notable year-over-year growth: Compared to the same time frame in 2022, EMV is up 55%, impressions have increased by 219% and engagements skyrocketed an impressive 505%.</p><p>Get <a href=""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/mcdonalds-starbucks-lead-food-beverage-brands-for-earned-media-value-in-h1-2023/"">more insights here</a>.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/copy-ciq-qsr-leaderboard-2022.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1366"" height=""862"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/copy-ciq-qsr-leaderboard-2022.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/copy-ciq-qsr-leaderboard-2022.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/copy-ciq-qsr-leaderboard-2022.png 1366w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",650323f0ef24770001d8160b,"Since its beginning, social media has provided a simple and fun way for people to share what they're eating and drinking, and this year it's been no different: According to data from CreatorIQ, over 437,000 creators posted on social media about food and beverage brands in the first half of 2023. Collectively, they published 1.2 million posts, resulting in 75.4 billion impressions and 3 billion engagements, generating $4.8 billion in Earned Media Value (EMV) for the industry.

The top five brands — McDonald’s, Starbucks, Red Bull, Celsius and Oreo — accounted for 15.3% of the overall Share of Influence (as measured by EMV) in the food and beverage category.

 * Of these brands, Red Bull has the most engaged community, averaging six to seven posts per creator and $36.9K EMV each.
 * One of the most effective posts was Supercar Blondie’s exciting Meta video documenting the world’s first helipad plane landing, featuring a Red Bull-branded plane, which generated $313.1K EMV for the brand.
 * Although it doesn’t make the top five brands, Naked Juice is one food and beverage brand making tremendous gains in 2023. This includes a notable 770% HoH increase in EMV, a 23,339% increase in impressions and an 883% increase in engagement. Top creators include the Younes Family, Camila Langley and Nicki Unplugged.

The food and beverage vertical as a whole has posted notable year-over-year growth: Compared to the same time frame in 2022, EMV is up 55%, impressions have increased by 219% and engagements skyrocketed an impressive 505%.

Colorado football coach Deion Sanders got Fox’s Big Noon college football slot off to a roaring start in week one of the season. According to <a href=""http://ispot.tv"">iSpot</a> data, the Buffaloes’ upset win over TCU had over 2.4 million out-of-home (OOH) viewers for a noon Saturday start – No. 2 among all college games during Labor Day weekend.</p><p>In the weeks following, eyeballs also stayed on the Buffaloes...</p><ul><li>Despite a blowout score of 42-6 in favor of Oregon, Colorado's loss to the Ducks drew an average minute audience of nearly 3.6 million OOH viewers – the top football game (NFL or college) by OOH audience for the week of Sept. 18-24, and again, the game didn't air in primetime.</li><li>Colorado hosted three of the first five Big Noon Kickoff events for Fox ths year, and played in four of the first five, while Boulder was also home to ESPN's College Gameday in week three.</li><li>Coach Prime is in front of audiences during commercial breaks as well. iSpot data shows one Alfac spot featuring Sanders and Alabama coach Nick Saban – ""<a most-seen ad during college football games this season.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://ispot.tv""><img of the season. According to iSpot data, the Buffaloes’ upset win over TCU had over 2.4 million out-of-home (OOH) viewers for a noon Saturday start – No. 2 among all college games during Labor Day weekend.

In the weeks following, eyeballs also stayed on the Buffaloes...

 * Despite a blowout score of 42-6 in favor of Oregon, Colorado's loss to the Ducks drew an average minute audience of nearly 3.6 million OOH viewers – the top football game (NFL or college) by OOH audience for the week of Sept. 18-24, and again, the game didn't air in primetime.
 * Colorado hosted three of the first five Big Noon Kickoff events for Fox ths year, and played in four of the first five, while Boulder was also home to ESPN's College Gameday in week three.
 * Coach Prime is in front of audiences during commercial breaks as well. iSpot data shows one Alfac spot featuring Sanders and Alabama coach Nick Saban – ""Coach Prime and Coach Saban Walk Into An Office Takeover"" – is the No. 8 most-seen ad during college football games this season.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/Screen-Shot-2023-09-14-at-9.47.54-AM.png,1,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-14T16:34:17.000Z,2023-10-11T04:41:53.000Z,2023-10-10T16:48:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,6503715be7deb200013e143f,2850f10f-4fb4-4526-9092-61f839b8dbb7,Los Angeles Chargers Own NFL Offseason On YouTube,l-a-chargers-own-nfl-offseason-on-youtube-tubular,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/copy-tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg"",""width"":1347,""height"":787}]],""markups"":[],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The NFL is a year-round league at this point, even if games only take place from Septemeber through early February. With that in mind, franchises need to find ways to engage with fans throughout the year – and many do, especially on social video channels like YouTube.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Tubular Labs data reveals the top NFL teams by YouTube views from Feb. 13 (the day afer the Super Bowl) through Aug. 30. While's correlation between team success and the number of views, there's also a case to be made here that fans simply want engaging content – and giving it to them is also to the club's benefit.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""The Los Angeles Chargers uploaded the most videos of any team (881) and had the most YouTube views in the timeframe (51.0 million).""]],[[0,[],0,""Super Bowl participants the Phiadelphia Eagles and Kansas City Chiefs were No. 2 and No. 3, respectively, by offseason YouTube views.""]],[[0,[],0,""Just two teams managed fewer than 2 million views for the offseason – the Arizona Cardinals (1.8 million) and Tennessee Titans (1.3 million).""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>The NFL is a year-round league at this point, even if games only take place from Septemeber through early February. With that in mind, franchises need to find ways to engage with fans throughout the year – and many do, especially on social video channels like YouTube.</p><p>Tubular Labs data reveals the top NFL teams by YouTube views from Feb. 13 (the day afer the Super Bowl) through Aug. 30. While's correlation between team success and the number of views, there's also a case to be made here that fans simply want engaging content – and giving it to them is also to the club's benefit.</p><ul><li>The Los Angeles Chargers uploaded the most videos of any team (881) and had the most YouTube views in the timeframe (51.0 million).</li><li>Super Bowl participants the Phiadelphia Eagles and Kansas City Chiefs were No. 2 and No. 3, respectively, by offseason YouTube views.</li><li>Just two teams managed fewer than 2 million views for the offseason – the Arizona Cardinals (1.8 million) and Tennessee Titans (1.3 million).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/copy-tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1347"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/copy-tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/copy-tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/copy-tubular-july-tar-ae.jpg 1347w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6503715be7deb200013e143f,"The NFL is a year-round league at this point, even if games only take place from Septemeber through early February. With that in mind, franchises need to find ways to engage with fans throughout the year – and many do, especially on social video channels like YouTube.

Tubular Labs data reveals the top NFL teams by YouTube views from Feb. 13 (the day afer the Super Bowl) through Aug. 30. While's correlation between team success and the number of views, there's also a case to be made here that fans simply want engaging content – and giving it to them is also to the club's benefit.

 * The Los Angeles Chargers uploaded the most videos of any team (881) and had the most YouTube views in the timeframe (51.0 million).
 * Super Bowl participants the Phiadelphia Eagles and Kansas City Chiefs were No. 2 and No. 3, respectively, by offseason YouTube views.
 * Just two teams managed fewer than 2 million views for the offseason – the Arizona Cardinals (1.8 million) and Tennessee Titans (1.3 million).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1559134951-7e580b9d5fe4?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDM3fHxjaGFyZ2Vyc3xlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTQ3MjUwNzV8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-14T20:47:23.000Z,2023-09-14T20:58:21.000Z,2023-09-01T20:56:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,650374cde7deb200013e1476,52d8e579-e749-4cf1-9026-b1ae30ecb219,Video Insights Help Brands During Football Season,how-consumer-video-insights-help-brands-during-football-season-tubular,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/bengals-consumer-insights.jpg"",""width"":1172,""height"":652,""href"":""http://tubularlabs.com""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://tubularlabs.com""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Football is the most popular sport in the country, so it makes sense that brands want to activate around that content – whether it’s on TV or social media platforms. But NFL and college football ad buys are expensive, and it’s ideal to know that you’re putting messaging in front of an audience that’s likely to complete a purchase.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""That’s where understanding the customer journey comes in. Consumer Insights data from ""],[0,[0],1,""Tubular Labs""],[0,[],0,"" shows advertisers determine existing affinity for product types and even specific brands, while also understanding how search and website visit behaviors may create new partnership opportunities (or opportunities with better ROI).""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""If a golf club brand wants to advertise with ESPN around college football social video content, they’ll find high Amazon shopping affinity there (130x higher than the norm for golf club shafts), but also a high affinity for Georgia football.""]],[[0,[],0,""Cincinnati Bengals social video viewers are actually far more likely to visit blog Cincy Jungle (5182x higher affinity than the norm) vs. the teams’ official website (2529x higher than the norm).""]],[[0,[],0,""Consumer Insights can also showcase unexpected shopping behaviors. For instance, San Francisco 49ers’ video viewers have a high affinity for shopping for power lifting cages on Amazon (73x more likely than the norm), while Kansas City Chiefs viewers are 78x more likely to shop for POHL SCHMITT kitchen appliances.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Football is the most popular sport in the country, so it makes sense that brands want to activate around that content – whether it’s on TV or social media platforms. But NFL and college football ad buys are expensive, and it’s ideal to know that you’re putting messaging in front of an audience that’s likely to complete a purchase.</p><p>That’s where understanding the customer journey comes in. Consumer Insights data from <a href=""http://tubularlabs.com"">Tubular Labs</a> shows advertisers determine existing affinity for product types and even specific brands, while also understanding how search and website visit behaviors may create new partnership opportunities (or opportunities with better ROI).</p><ul><li>If a golf club brand wants to advertise with ESPN around college football social video content, they’ll find high Amazon shopping affinity there (130x higher than the norm for golf club shafts), but also a high affinity for Georgia football.</li><li>Cincinnati Bengals social video viewers are actually far more likely to visit blog Cincy Jungle (5182x higher affinity than the norm) vs. the teams’ official website (2529x higher than the norm).</li><li>Consumer Insights can also showcase unexpected shopping behaviors. For instance, San Francisco 49ers’ video viewers have a high affinity for shopping for power lifting cages on Amazon (73x more likely than the norm), while Kansas City Chiefs viewers are 78x more likely to shop for POHL SCHMITT kitchen appliances.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/bengals-consumer-insights.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1172"" height=""652"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/bengals-consumer-insights.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/bengals-consumer-insights.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/bengals-consumer-insights.jpg 1172w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",650374cde7deb200013e1476,"Football is the most popular sport in the country, so it makes sense that brands want to activate around that content – whether it’s on TV or social media platforms. But NFL and college football ad buys are expensive, and it’s ideal to know that you’re putting messaging in front of an audience that’s likely to complete a purchase.

That’s where understanding the customer journey comes in. Consumer Insights data from Tubular Labs shows advertisers determine existing affinity for product types and even specific brands, while also understanding how search and website visit behaviors may create new partnership opportunities (or opportunities with better ROI).

 * If a golf club brand wants to advertise with ESPN around college football social video content, they’ll find high Amazon shopping affinity there (130x higher than the norm for golf club shafts), but also a high affinity for Georgia football.
 * Cincinnati Bengals social video viewers are actually far more likely to visit blog Cincy Jungle (5182x higher affinity than the norm) vs. the teams’ official website (2529x higher than the norm).
 * Consumer Insights can also showcase unexpected shopping behaviors. For instance, San Francisco 49ers’ video viewers have a high affinity for shopping for power lifting cages on Amazon (73x more likely than the norm), while Kansas City Chiefs viewers are 78x more likely to shop for POHL SCHMITT kitchen appliances.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1501386761578-eac5c94b800a?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDMwfHxuZmwlMjBmYW5zfGVufDB8fHx8MTY5NDcyNjM0M3ww&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-14T21:02:05.000Z,2023-09-14T21:19:25.000Z,2023-09-14T21:16:54.000Z,,,,,,,1,65045cdae7deb200013e14ce,57acb156-2d6c-4d36-9735-0e8bae79cb4b,Subaru Snags Top Spot of Most-Seen Auto TV Ads,subaru-snags-top-spot-of-most-seen-auto-tv-ads,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""html"",{""html"":""                    <div style=\""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;\""><iframe src=\""https://www.ispot.tv/share/5wYR\"" style=\""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;\"" frameborder=\""0\"" scrolling=\""no\"" allowfullscreen=\""\""></iframe></div>\n                    ""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.wardsauto.com/industry-news/subaru-pushes-limits-most-seen-auto-tv-ad""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/products/creative-testing""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""A Crosstrek Wilderness commercial racked up 232.5 million national TV ad impressions, making it the most-seen automotive ad on TV for Sept. 4-10, ""],[0,[0],1,""according to iSpot.tv data shared with WardsAuto""],[0,[],0,"". Broadcast networks (NBC< CBS and ABC) delivered top impression counts for the ad. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""A Chevrolet Silverado spot with 228.2 million national TV ad impressions slips from first to second place, with Fox News as the top impressions-generating network (34.7 million, 2x the No. 2 network, ION).""]],[[0,[],0,""82% of the impressions for the third-place Hyundai Kona commercial came from primetime ad airings, particularly NFL and college football. ""]],[[0,[],0,""The No. 4 spot from Ram had an 88% brand match (the percentage of survey respondents who remembered it was a Ram Trucks ad after watching it), above the recent automaker industry norm of 78%, per ""],[0,[1],1,""iSpot’s Creative Assessment""],[0,[],0,"".""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>A Crosstrek Wilderness commercial racked up 232.5 million national TV ad impressions, making it the most-seen automotive ad on TV for Sept. 4-10, <a href=""https://www.wardsauto.com/industry-news/subaru-pushes-limits-most-seen-auto-tv-ad"">according to iSpot.tv data shared with WardsAuto</a>. Broadcast networks (NBC< CBS and ABC) delivered top impression counts for the ad.

 * A Chevrolet Silverado spot with 228.2 million national TV ad impressions slips from first to second place, with Fox News as the top impressions-generating network (34.7 million, 2x the No. 2 network, ION).
 * 82% of the impressions for the third-place Hyundai Kona commercial came from primetime ad airings, particularly NFL and college football.
 * The No. 4 spot from Ram had an 88% brand match (the percentage of survey respondents who remembered it was a Ram Trucks ad after watching it), above the recent automaker industry norm of 78%, per iSpot’s Creative Assessment.

""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Automakers made a big end-of-summer push, spending an estimated $113.3 million on national TV ads, <a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/389216/automotive-tv-spending-rises-uaw-strike-unlikely.html"">according to iSpot data recently shared with MediaPost.</a> That's a 15.3% increase from industry spend in August 2022. National TV ad impressions were up as well: Automotive ads racked up 28.6 billion impressions, a 16% increase from August 2022. </p><ul><li>Ram Trucks was the top-spending auto brand, shelling out an estimated $12.5 million in August. Subaru ($10.5 million), Chevrolet ($8.8 million), Kia ($8.1 million) and Jeep ($8 million) round out the top five. </li><li>Mazda led for biggest estimated spend increase among the top 15 brands by spend, with an outlay 48x more this August compared to last August. Much of that is due to a heavier focus on NFL, which accounted for 90% of the automaker's spend (Mazda did not advertise during NFL in August 2022).</li><li>The top programs for automakers by share of household TV ad impressions in August 2023 were NFL (1.99%), MLB (0.72%), House Hunters (0.61%), Today (0.58%) and SportsCenter (0.54%).</li></ul><p>Get more insights around August's automotive TV advertising <a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/389216/automotive-tv-spending-rises-uaw-strike-unlikely.html"">here</a>. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/ispot-autos-aug-2023-1.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1646"" height=""900"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/ispot-autos-aug-2023-1.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/ispot-autos-aug-2023-1.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/09/ispot-autos-aug-2023-1.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/ispot-autos-aug-2023-1.png 1646w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",650858a072b4bf00015bc29f,"Automakers made a big end-of-summer push, spending an estimated $113.3 million on national TV ads, according to iSpot data recently shared with MediaPost. That's a 15.3% increase from industry spend in August 2022. National TV ad impressions were up as well: Automotive ads racked up 28.6 billion impressions, a 16% increase from August 2022.

 * Ram Trucks was the top-spending auto brand, shelling out an estimated $12.5 million in August. Subaru ($10.5 million), Chevrolet ($8.8 million), Kia ($8.1 million) and Jeep ($8 million) round out the top five.
 * Mazda led for biggest estimated spend increase among the top 15 brands by spend, with an outlay 48x more this August compared to last August. Much of that is due to a heavier focus on NFL, which accounted for 90% of the automaker's spend (Mazda did not advertise during NFL in August 2022).
 * The top programs for automakers by share of household TV ad impressions in August 2023 were NFL (1.99%), MLB (0.72%), House Hunters (0.61%), Today (0.58%) and SportsCenter (0.54%).

The current TikTok music trends include continued influences from the Barbie movie, a crossover from a video gamer, and buzz around ""Taylor's Version.""</p><p><strong><strong>Track:</strong></strong> <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/music/I%E2%80%99m-Just-Ken-7257261352532051969"">“I’m Just Ken” — Mark Ronson</a><br><strong><strong>Trend:</strong></strong> Barbie movie moments<br>TikTok is abuzz with Barbie Movie trends like the ""I'm Just Ken"" song, sung by Ryan Gosling, showcasing ""Barbie Personas,"" #myken partner habits, and lip-sync renditions of other songs from the film.</p><p><strong><strong>Track:</strong></strong> <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/music/original-sound-7255817840909290245"">“Never Back Down” — Nick Eh 30</a><br><strong>Trend:</strong> Never Back Down<br>“Never Back Down” is a song, as well as a catchphrase created from a soundbite from the gamer Nick Eh 30 – The trend features TikTokers adopting it as a motivational quote for comical skits and ironic meme videos.</p><p><strong><strong>Track:</strong></strong> <a href=""https://www.tiktok.com/music/cruel-summer-sped-up-7080293587786763013"">Cruel Summer Sped Up – Bia (Taylor’s version)</a><br><strong><strong>Trend:</strong></strong> Various<br>Taylor Swift’s extension of her record-breaking Eras Tour has kept her trending through August. TikTokers are using this track to show daily vlogs, recipe videos, and beauty routines.</p><p>Discover creative ways brands use music on TikTok via <a href=""https://www.songtradr.com/landing/tiktok-sound-partner"">Songtradr's Official TikTok Sound Partner</a> page, and learn how to enhance your brand's impact and connect with your audience in new ways.</p><p><br></p><p></p><p></p>",6508c52172b4bf00015bc2e2,"As summer comes to an end, B2B music company Songtradr spotlights the standout tracks and emerging trends on TikTok.

Notable songs like Doechii's ""What It Is"" and Myke Towers' ""LALA"" experienced rapid popularity on the platform, while TikTok catapulted individuals like Mae Stephens, a supermarket worker, to viral fame with her track ""If We Ever Broke Up."" The current TikTok music trends include continued influences from the Barbie movie, a crossover from a video gamer, and buzz around ""Taylor's Version.""

Track: “I’m Just Ken” — Mark Ronson
Trend: Barbie movie moments
TikTok is abuzz with Barbie Movie trends like the ""I'm Just Ken"" song, sung by Ryan Gosling, showcasing ""Barbie Personas,"" #myken partner habits, and lip-sync renditions of other songs from the film.

Track: “Never Back Down” — Nick Eh 30
Trend: Never Back Down
“Never Back Down” is a song, as well as a catchphrase created from a soundbite from the gamer Nick Eh 30 – The trend features TikTokers adopting it as a motivational quote for comical skits and ironic meme videos.

Track: Cruel Summer Sped Up – Bia (Taylor’s version)
Trend: Various
Taylor Swift’s extension of her record-breaking Eras Tour has kept her trending through August. TikTokers are using this track to show daily vlogs, recipe videos, and beauty routines.

Discover creative ways brands use music on TikTok via Songtradr's Official TikTok Sound Partner page, and learn how to enhance your brand's impact and connect with your audience in new ways.

""]]],[10,0],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Target used the NOTD song “AM:PM” for its “""],[0,[2],1,""Back to School Anthem""],[0,[],0,""” ad. A <a href=""http://songtradr.com"">Songtradr</a> analysis of some of this year’s new back-to-school ads reveals exactly how brands attempt to connect with audiences using music. Using AI, Songtradr pinpoints how likely a given song will appeal to various age groups, and highlights where there’s the most overlap across generations. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><a href=""http://songtradr.com/""><img src=""https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/1sTLGOC_TrO423xXmKkNK34u5zRFEOVJVY-_kgSXAhHIL6I-N3GQJ0iFryBtKmsGtNzMoLlF1ZrVF8qrufQeR0xpXjxTp0NHk0YcYGzLfyVgfMtSofOLGrycgRAwLJzZKdggPEDD0nRp9UsZj_7QV8U"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" title=""Chart"" width=""624"" height=""385""></a><figcaption><em>Data provided by Songtradr</em></figcaption></figure><ul><li>Target used the NOTD song “AM:PM” for its “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f8wZWjbO3xE"">Back to School Anthem</a>” ad. The track appeals best with consumers aged 18 to 34, but also aligns with teens (13-17) and young parents (35-44)</li><li>Walmart takes a similar approach with “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4NF5xuj9UhU"">Back to School - Mom Chat</a>” — one of three ads featured in its back-to-school campaign — which features “Shut Down” by BLACKPINK.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><a href=""http://songtradr.com/""><img src=""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/BpQLLYd3Y58EswIiENS2pnsD2HJORAucG1Q6_q4z0T8UHkL5WZt4eS1gCiXdeW6BPrcR6_sPUvg0J-qsuzSF0h_vOHyHsKm7RrgCWoeuJWIn4oGaOVbxZhiNBMmFvh3BWtjk29B-aOKpYKTbrWs_pzI"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" title=""Chart"" width=""624"" height=""385""></a><figcaption><em>Data provided by Songtradr</em></figcaption></figure><ul><li>Walmart also doubled down on advertising for parents with “<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MyZ606YnxPM"">That's A Wrap</a>” — featuring ""This Is What Love Looks Like"" by Carlton Jumel Smith, Cold Diamond &amp; Mink — which shows overwhelmingly higher confidence levels with listeners aged 35 to 65</li><li>Both JCPenney and Kohl’s took a similar tack with their campaigns.</li></ul><p>More and more, advertisers are recognizing the significant influence of sonic branding, emphasizing the role of music in ads to create stronger connections with audiences, boost brand affinity, and drive purchase intent.</p><p><br></p>",6508c86f72b4bf00015bc32c,"With back-to-school shopping season in full effect, major retailers are challenged with finding the right balance between tailoring ads to kids who wear the clothes, or to parents/guardians who ultimately buy the items.

One way to tackle this is through music choices. A Songtradr analysis of some of this year’s new back-to-school ads reveals exactly how brands attempt to connect with audiences using music. Using AI, Songtradr pinpoints how likely a given song will appeal to various age groups, and highlights where there’s the most overlap across generations.

 * Target used the NOTD song “AM:PM” for its “Back to School Anthem” ad. The track appeals best with consumers aged 18 to 34, but also aligns with teens (13-17) and young parents (35-44)
 * Walmart takes a similar approach with “Back to School - Mom Chat” — one of three ads featured in its back-to-school campaign — which features “Shut Down” by BLACKPINK.

 * Walmart also doubled down on advertising for parents with “That's A Wrap” — featuring ""This Is What Love Looks Like"" by Carlton Jumel Smith, Cold Diamond & Mink — which shows overwhelmingly higher confidence levels with listeners aged 35 to 65
 * Both JCPenney and Kohl’s took a similar tack with their campaigns.

More and more, advertisers are recognizing the significant influence of sonic branding, emphasizing the role of music in ads to create stronger connections with audiences, boost brand affinity, and drive purchase intent.

Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 11-17 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

NFL games fueled nearly a third of CBS watch-time for the week, driving the network into first place with a 9.01% total viewership share. ABC, which benefited from both NFL and college football, rises to second place from fourth previously with 7.39% of minutes watched.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 11-17:

 * Bravo moves up from No. 22 to No. 17, with its 1.09% viewership share fueled in part by Southern Charm, Below Deck and The Real Housewives of Orange County.
 * Although they retain their ranking positions, MSNBC, HGTV, Hallmark Channel, CNN, and Investigation Discovery each saw increases in watch-time compared to the previous week.
 * History was the sole week-over-week newcomer to the chart, landing at No. 23 with 0.88% of watch-time.

 * ""Life"" promoting Ram Truck models, saw a 36% week-over-week increase in TV ad impressions and moved from fourth to second place.
 * Subaru's third-place spot harnessed primetime ad airings, which accounted for over a third of the commercial's total 222.6 million national TV ad impressions.
 * NFL games delivered top impression counts for the No. 4 ad (Nissan's ""All In"") and the No. 5 ad (Chevrolet's ""For All of Life's Firsts"").

",,,,,,1,651085d1e6e3d1000168e378,63cfbf38-b4ce-49cd-88aa-59d138159ba6,Data Industry Included Just 58% Of U.S. Hispanic Audiences In Q2,data-industry-included-58-us-hispanic-audiences-truthset,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/truthset-hispanic-audience.jpg"",""width"":1172,""height"":652,""href"":""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/truthset-reveals-underrepresentation-for-hispanic-audiences-in-consumer-data-sets/""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://truthset.io""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.census.gov/newsroom/facts-for-features/2023/hispanic-heritage-month.html""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""A Q2 2023 study from ""],[0,[0],1,""Truthset""],[0,[],0,"" revealed that the data industry includes just 58% of Hispanic audiences in the U.S. With 42% of Hispanic audiences not recorded in data sets, advertisers can’t properly allocate targeted ad spend, while content owners are missing opportunities to develop more programming for Hispanic viewers.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""In 2022, ""],[0,[1],1,""U.S. Census results indicated""],[0,[],0,"" that 19% of the adult population was Hispanic, equating to about 50 million people. Missing over 40% of that audience means data sets are not accounting for at least 20 million people.""]],[[0,[],0,""Over the past eight quarters, Truthset found that the overall data industry never accounted for more than 62% of this audience (in Q2 2022), though has shown marginal improvements since a low of 53% in Q3 2021.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>A Q2 2023 study from <a href=""http://truthset.io"">Truthset</a> revealed that the data industry includes just 58% of Hispanic audiences in the U.S. With 42% of Hispanic audiences not recorded in data sets, advertisers can’t properly allocate targeted ad spend, while content owners are missing opportunities to develop more programming for Hispanic viewers.</p><ul><li>In 2022, <a href=""https://www.census.gov/newsroom/facts-for-features/2023/hispanic-heritage-month.html"">U.S. Census results indicated</a> that 19% of the adult population was Hispanic, equating to about 50 million people. Missing over 40% of that audience means data sets are not accounting for at least 20 million people.</li><li>Over the past eight quarters, Truthset found that the overall data industry never accounted for more than 62% of this audience (in Q2 2022), though has shown marginal improvements since a low of 53% in Q3 2021.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/truthset-reveals-underrepresentation-for-hispanic-audiences-in-consumer-data-sets/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/truthset-hispanic-audience.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1172"" height=""652"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/truthset-hispanic-audience.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/truthset-hispanic-audience.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/truthset-hispanic-audience.jpg 1172w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",651085d1e6e3d1000168e378,"A Q2 2023 study from Truthset revealed that the data industry includes just 58% of Hispanic audiences in the U.S. With 42% of Hispanic audiences not recorded in data sets, advertisers can’t properly allocate targeted ad spend, while content owners are missing opportunities to develop more programming for Hispanic viewers.

 * In 2022, U.S. Census results indicated that 19% of the adult population was Hispanic, equating to about 50 million people. Missing over 40% of that audience means data sets are not accounting for at least 20 million people.
 * Over the past eight quarters, Truthset found that the overall data industry never accounted for more than 62% of this audience (in Q2 2022), though has shown marginal improvements since a low of 53% in Q3 2021.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1435686858161-59da32dfd4b4?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDJ8fGF1ZGllbmNlfGVufDB8fHx8MTY5NTU4MjEzMHww&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-24T18:54:09.000Z,2023-09-24T19:03:10.000Z,2023-09-20T19:02:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,651089b1e6e3d1000168e3a3,6e650b16-dc63-4e74-b204-90224bac20bb,Beer Advertising Battlegrounds,beer-advertising-battlegrounds-tv-ad-data-ispot,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/ispot-beer-brands.jpg"",""width"":1375,""height"":787,""href"":""http://ispot.tv""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://ispot.tv/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-disciplined-marketing-strategy-that-helped-modelo-beat-bud-light-b662d938""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Modelo's rise to the top of the U.S. beer market is partly due to marketing strategy.  * This is relevant given Modelo's recent rise to the top of the U.S. beer market (as detailed in the WSJ this week).
 * Notably, just 6.3% of Bud Light's TV ad impressions this year have been in Spanish (No. 10 among brands with at least 1 billion household ad impressions).",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1672192976393-21e9f8dd50bc?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDEyfHxidWQlMjBsaWdodHxlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTU1ODI5NTF8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-24T19:10:41.000Z,2023-09-24T19:16:13.000Z,2023-09-21T19:14:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,65108b4be6e3d1000168e3dd,12a92da0-bad9-4fda-9297-e40fb068f9c0,Who Is Watching Local Broadcast TV?,who-is-watching-local-broadcast-tv-tvrev-report,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""After surveying more than 60K Americans aged 25 and older, TVREV's new report – ""],[0,[0],1,""Local TV: Perils & Promise In The Age Of Streaming""],[0,[],0,"" -- confirms some conventional thinking, while also providing some surprising findings.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Nearly two-thirds (63%) of those over 65 report watching local broadcast every day, with another 13% saying they watch a couple of times a week.""]],[[0,[],0,""While 55% of those aged 25 to 34 either never or hardly ever watch local broadcast, 21% watch every dayand 14% watch a few times per week.""]],[[0,[],0,""Income levels did not have significant impact on daily local broadcast viewing, as somewhere between 39% and 44% of respondents watched daily at all income levels.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""[""],[0,[0],1,""READ MORE IN THE FULL REPORT""],[0,[],0,""]""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>After surveying more than 60K Americans aged 25 and older, TVREV's new report – <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming"">Local TV: Perils &amp; Promise In The Age Of Streaming</a> -- confirms some conventional thinking, while also providing some surprising findings.</p><ul><li>Nearly two-thirds (63%) of those over 65 report watching local broadcast every day, with another 13% saying they watch a couple of times a week.</li><li>While 55% of those aged 25 to 34 either never or hardly ever watch local broadcast, 21% watch every dayand 14% watch a few times per week.</li><li>Income levels did not have significant impact on daily local broadcast viewing, as somewhere between 39% and 44% of respondents watched daily at all income levels.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming"">READ MORE IN THE FULL REPORT</a>]</p>",65108b4be6e3d1000168e3dd,"After surveying more than 60K Americans aged 25 and older, TVREV's new report – Local TV: Perils & Promise In The Age Of Streaming -- confirms some conventional thinking, while also providing some surprising findings.

 * Nearly two-thirds (63%) of those over 65 report watching local broadcast every day, with another 13% saying they watch a couple of times a week.
 * While 55% of those aged 25 to 34 either never or hardly ever watch local broadcast, 21% watch every dayand 14% watch a few times per week.
 * Income levels did not have significant impact on daily local broadcast viewing, as somewhere between 39% and 44% of respondents watched daily at all income levels.

week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from <a href=""http://inscape.tv""><em>Inscape</em></a>, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 18-24 — head over to TVREV to <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/nfl-and-college-football-dominate-weekly-tv-watch-time""><em>see the program ranking</em></a> and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.</em></p><p>Thanks in large part to NFL and college football, ABC takes first place on the ranking with 8.75% of minutes watched, up from No. 2 (7.39%) previously. Other programming fueling watch-time on the network include <em>Good Morning America</em>, <em>ABC World News Tonight With Dvid Muir</em> and <em>College Football Studio</em>. </p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 18-24:</p><ul><li>NBC also made gains week-over-week, taking second place with a 7.82% viewership share, up from No. 3 (6.94%) previously. Football and news programming aside, its top shows included <em>America’s Got Talent</em> and <em>American Ninja Warrior</em>.</li><li>Of the six networks that retained ranking positions week-over-week, only two (ION, HGTV) had an increase in watch-time.</li><li>Food Network (No. 23) and Paramount Network (No. 25) were the two week-over-week ranking newcomers. <em>Halloween Baking Championship</em> was a big viewership driver for the former, while <em>Bar Rescue</em> and <em>Two and a Half Men</em> were tops for the latter.</li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/nfl-and-college-football-dominate-weekly-tv-watch-time"">See which TV programs (aside from football, of course!) captured the most watch-time over at TVREV.</a></p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept18-24.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept18-24.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept18-24.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/InscapeTopNetworksSept18-24.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6512ea4665b2a70001ede567,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 18-24 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

Thanks in large part to NFL and college football, ABC takes first place on the ranking with 8.75% of minutes watched, up from No. 2 (7.39%) previously. Other programming fueling watch-time on the network include Good Morning America, ABC World News Tonight With Dvid Muir and College Football Studio.

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 18-24:

 * NBC also made gains week-over-week, taking second place with a 7.82% viewership share, up from No. 3 (6.94%) previously. Football and news programming aside, its top shows included America’s Got Talent and American Ninja Warrior.
 * Of the six networks that retained ranking positions week-over-week, only two (ION, HGTV) had an increase in watch-time.
 * Food Network (No. 23) and Paramount Network (No. 25) were the two week-over-week ranking newcomers. Halloween Baking Championship was a big viewership driver for the former, while Bar Rescue and Two and a Half Men were tops for the latter.

In this case, a prominent video game manufacturer was promoting the release of a new title, leveraging VIZIO’s CTV ads, as well as Home Screen placement and off-platform retargeting to mobile devices, tablets, and laptops.

Among the campaign's results:

 * a 21.9% incremental reach among game console owners
 * an overall audience incremental reach of 13.5%
 * 93% of the devices reached through this campaign were incremental compared to the linear-only campaign.

One point that stood out, in particular, was Tegna’s rapid growth in viewership in the last month of summer. Tubular found: </p><ul><li>In Aug. 2023, Tubular Audience Ratings show Tegna’s U.S. unique viewers grew by 43% month-over-month across Facebook and YouTube, in part due to an emphasis on crime-related content (many of the most-watched videos across networks).</li><li>The summer surge took Tegna all the way up to No. 9 among all U.S. media and entertainment properties, just shy of Warner Music at No. 8.</li><li>Tegna also saw U.S. minutes watched climb significantly month-over-month, increasing 62% across Facebook and YouTube.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/Unique-Viewers--8-.jpeg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1200"" height=""800"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/Unique-Viewers--8-.jpeg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/Unique-Viewers--8-.jpeg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/Unique-Viewers--8-.jpeg 1200w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",65145addc70a8e000187e12f,"Tubular Labs recently announced its findings from last month of top trends among media companies, brands and creators across YouTube and Facebook. One point that stood out, in particular, was Tegna’s rapid growth in viewership in the last month of summer. Tubular found:

 * In Aug. 2023, Tubular Audience Ratings show Tegna’s U.S. unique viewers grew by 43% month-over-month across Facebook and YouTube, in part due to an emphasis on crime-related content (many of the most-watched videos across networks).
 * The summer surge took Tegna all the way up to No. 9 among all U.S. media and entertainment properties, just shy of Warner Music at No. 8.
