The report also uncovered these major findings:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Auto & general insurance brands saw a YoY increase share of TV ad impressions delivered during daytime, from 16.56% to 19.43% — the shift is part of a larger advertising trend toward more impressions during that daypart.""]],[[0,[],0,""While insurance TV ad impressions decreased YoY across all categories, life insurance actually jumped by 16.8%, in part due to growth during reality programming, drama & action series and TV movies.""]],[[0,[],0,""Insurance brands reduced TV ad impressions during men's college basketball games by 29% YoY, though brands like New York Life and Humana (among others) still saw increases during the sport compared to the same period in 2022.""]]]],[10,0]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/insurance-industry-tv-ad-transparency-report/"">iSpot’s new insurance industry report</a> includes this major takeaway: Insurance brand TV ad impressions declined by 17% YoY from Jan. 1-Aug. 31. The report also uncovered these major findings:</p><ul><li>Auto &amp; general insurance brands saw a YoY increase share of TV ad impressions delivered during daytime, from 16.56% to 19.43% — the shift is part of a larger advertising trend toward more impressions during that daypart.</li><li>While insurance TV ad impressions decreased YoY across all categories, life insurance actually jumped by 16.8%, in part due to growth during reality programming, drama &amp; action series and TV movies.</li><li>Insurance brands reduced TV ad impressions during men's college basketball games by 29% YoY, though brands like New York Life and Humana (among others) still saw increases during the sport compared to the same period in 2022.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/insurance-industry-tv-ad-transparency-report/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/Screen-Shot-2023-09-19-at-11.10.36-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1232"" height=""680"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/Screen-Shot-2023-09-19-at-11.10.36-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/Screen-Shot-2023-09-19-at-11.10.36-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/Screen-Shot-2023-09-19-at-11.10.36-AM.png 1232w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",65148187c70a8e000187e157,"iSpot’s new insurance industry report includes this major takeaway: Insurance brand TV ad impressions declined by 17% YoY from Jan. 1-Aug. 31. The report also uncovered these major findings:

 * Auto & general insurance brands saw a YoY increase share of TV ad impressions delivered during daytime, from 16.56% to 19.43% — the shift is part of a larger advertising trend toward more impressions during that daypart.
 * While insurance TV ad impressions decreased YoY across all categories, life insurance actually jumped by 16.8%, in part due to growth during reality programming, drama & action series and TV movies.
 * Insurance brands reduced TV ad impressions during men's college basketball games by 29% YoY, though brands like New York Life and Humana (among others) still saw increases during the sport compared to the same period in 2022.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1633158829585-23ba8f7c8caf?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDN8fGluc3VyYW5jZXxlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTU4NDI4MzB8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-27T19:24:55.000Z,2023-09-27T19:28:29.000Z,2023-09-21T04:00:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,6515c0a1c70a8e000187e18a,d8962336-a8a0-4048-89eb-1358eb3f0ad4,Wireless Brands Are Singing Older Tunes,wireless-brands-are-singing-older-tunes,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/chart--1-.png"",""width"":682,""height"":421,""caption"":""<em>Data provided by Songtradr</em>"",""href"":""songtradr.com""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://songtradr.com/""]],[""strong""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GC5E8ie2pdM""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vp0a2TCHcx4""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Ads for wireless companies are everywhere on TV, but it takes more than just a lot of ad airings to stand out. Using music to capture viewers' attention and create brand affinity is a common tactic - The key to success is picking the right song.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""Songtradr""],[0,[],0,"" recently used its AI sonic analysis technology to evaluate the songs licensed by some of the most-seen wireless ads on TV since the start of 2022, honing in on some key trends:""]]],[10,0],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""The music choices of wireless ads were ""],[0,[1],1,""most favorable to older millennials and Gen X audiences""],[0,[],0,""; \""""],[0,[2],1,""The Best""],[0,[],0,""\"" by Tina Turner (used in a T-Mobile spot) scored 80% favorability among older millennials, and \""""],[0,[3],1,""Go Where You Wanna Go""],[0,[],0,""\"" by The Mamas & the Papas (used in a Lively spot) earned a 90% favorability rating among Gen X viewers.""]],[[0,[1],1,""T-Mobile licensed the most music of all wireless brands""],[0,[],0,"", accounting for six of the nine spots examined; leaning on songs most favorable to older millennials.""]],[[0,[],0,""Of the songs studied, ""],[0,[1],1,""just three had over 50% favorability for women""],[0,[],0,"", yet five of the nine songs had favorability of 67% or higher for men… something that makes less sense considering how much more women guide consumer purchase decisions.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Ads for wireless companies are everywhere on TV, but it takes more than just a lot of ad airings to stand out. Using music to capture viewers' attention and create brand affinity is a common tactic - The key to success is picking the right song.</p><p><a href=""http://songtradr.com/"">Songtradr</a> recently used its AI sonic analysis technology to evaluate the songs licensed by some of the most-seen wireless ads on TV since the start of 2022, honing in on some key trends:</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card kg-card-hascaption""><a href=""songtradr.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/chart--1-.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""682"" height=""421"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/chart--1-.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/chart--1-.png 682w""></a><figcaption><em>Data provided by Songtradr</em></figcaption></figure><ul><li>The music choices of wireless ads were <strong>most favorable to older millennials and Gen X audiences</strong>; ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GC5E8ie2pdM"">The Best</a>"" by Tina Turner (used in a T-Mobile spot) scored 80% favorability among older millennials, and ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vp0a2TCHcx4"">Go Where You Wanna Go</a>"" by The Mamas &amp; the Papas (used in a Lively spot) earned a 90% favorability rating among Gen X viewers.</li><li><strong>T-Mobile licensed the most music of all wireless brands</strong>, accounting for six of the nine spots examined; leaning on songs most favorable to older millennials.</li><li>Of the songs studied, <strong>just three had over 50% favorability for women</strong>, yet five of the nine songs had favorability of 67% or higher for men… something that makes less sense considering how much more women guide consumer purchase decisions.</li></ul>",6515c0a1c70a8e000187e18a,"Ads for wireless companies are everywhere on TV, but it takes more than just a lot of ad airings to stand out. Using music to capture viewers' attention and create brand affinity is a common tactic - The key to success is picking the right song.

Songtradr recently used its AI sonic analysis technology to evaluate the songs licensed by some of the most-seen wireless ads on TV since the start of 2022, honing in on some key trends:

 * The music choices of wireless ads were most favorable to older millennials and Gen X audiences; ""The Best"" by Tina Turner (used in a T-Mobile spot) scored 80% favorability among older millennials, and ""Go Where You Wanna Go"" by The Mamas & the Papas (used in a Lively spot) earned a 90% favorability rating among Gen X viewers.
 * T-Mobile licensed the most music of all wireless brands, accounting for six of the nine spots examined; leaning on songs most favorable to older millennials.
 * Of the songs studied, just three had over 50% favorability for women, yet five of the nine songs had favorability of 67% or higher for men… something that makes less sense considering how much more women guide consumer purchase decisions.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/t-mobile-5g-interstate-song-by-tina-turner-large-9.jpeg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-28T18:06:25.000Z,2023-09-28T18:34:15.000Z,2023-09-21T18:06:00.000Z,Songtradr used its AI sonic analysis technology to evaluate the songs licensed in some of the most-seen wireless ads on TV,,,,,,1,6515c1aec70a8e000187e19e,ff164ae9-dee6-45d4-a954-c9f19cd9464f,Bashing TikTok: Sponsored By TikTok,bashing-tiktok-sponsored-by-tiktok-fox-news-tv-advertising-ispot,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""html"",{""html"":""<div style=\""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;\""><iframe src=\""https://www.ispot.tv/share/1nQT\"" style=\""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;\"" frameborder=\""0\"" scrolling=\""no\"" allowfullscreen=\""\""></iframe></div>""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1nQT/tiktok-meet-jessie-whittington""]],[""a"",[""href"",""http://ispot.tv""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1z5u/tiktok-patriotic-kenny-and-amanda""]],[""strong""]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Audiences that tuned into Wednesday night’s Republican Primary Debate on Fox News heard many familiar talk tracks, including back-and-forth around the societal and security issues with TikTok.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Entertainingly, that conversation was followed directly – at 10:29 p.m. – by an ad for the social video app, “""],[0,[0],1,""Meet Jessie Whittington""],[0,[],0,"".” The spot doesn’t address the debate, but plays as a spot geared toward the Fox News audience, revolving around a soap entrepreneur in Mississippi. Data from ""],[0,[1],1,""iSpot""],[0,[],0,"" shows that over 23% of household TV ad impressions for the ad, since it debuted in August 2023, have been delivered on Fox News.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Since TikTok was banned on U.S. federal government devices in June, the app has focused spots primarily on individual creators – and in many cases, business owners that utilize TikTok. iSpot shows that almost 48% of TikTok household TV ad impressions since June 1 were accounted for by “""],[0,[2],1,""Patriotic Kenny and Amanda""],[0,[],0,"",” another spot that aired during the debate. The Whittington ad accounts for nearly 38% of ad impressions in the timeframe.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""TikTok has focused heavily on cable news networks and broadcast in that timeframe as well. Fox News is the No. 1 network by share of TikTok TV ad impressions since June 1, with 18.9%, while CNN is No. 2 at 15.2%. CBS, Fox, ABC and MSNBC are all among the top 10 as well.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Given the nature of the U.S. news discourse around TikTok right now, perhaps the app figures the ads move toward “setting the record straight” immediately after on-air critiques. If audiences are most likely to retain the last thing they hear about TikTok, that could be the entrepreneurship-focused ads.""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[3],1,""Audiences Respond Well to the Ads, Too""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""iSpot Creative Assessment data shows the spots are finding some success around narrative, too. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""The top emotional response from survey respondents around the Whittington spot was for its narrative, and 29% of respondents said the message was the single best thing. ""]],[[0,[],0,""“Patriotic Kenny and Amanda” came off as both heartfelt and inspired to survey respondents, and the single best thing was the message there as well, according to 36% of those surveyed. ""]],[[0,[],0,""The ad was also 19% more likeable than other technology ads since June 1.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""So for now, at least, it seems that TikTok is fine with the extra publicity, as it successfully finds ways to spin that toward more positive attention through its ads.""],[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>Audiences that tuned into Wednesday night’s Republican Primary Debate on Fox News heard many familiar talk tracks, including back-and-forth around the societal and security issues with TikTok.</p><p>Entertainingly, that conversation was followed directly – at 10:29 p.m. – by an ad for the social video app, “<a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1nQT/tiktok-meet-jessie-whittington"">Meet Jessie Whittington</a>.” The spot doesn’t address the debate, but plays as a spot geared toward the Fox News audience, revolving around a soap entrepreneur in Mississippi. Data from <a href=""http://ispot.tv"">iSpot</a> shows that over 23% of household TV ad impressions for the ad, since it debuted in August 2023, have been delivered on Fox News.</p><!--kg-card-begin: html--><div style=""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;""><iframe src=""https://www.ispot.tv/share/1nQT"" style=""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;"" frameborder=""0"" scrolling=""no"" allowfullscreen=""""></iframe></div><!--kg-card-end: html--><p>Since TikTok was banned on U.S. federal government devices in June, the app has focused spots primarily on individual creators – and in many cases, business owners that utilize TikTok. iSpot shows that almost 48% of TikTok household TV ad impressions since June 1 were accounted for by “<a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1z5u/tiktok-patriotic-kenny-and-amanda"">Patriotic Kenny and Amanda</a>,” another spot that aired during the debate. The Whittington ad accounts for nearly 38% of ad impressions in the timeframe.</p><p>TikTok has focused heavily on cable news networks and broadcast in that timeframe as well. Fox News is the No. 1 network by share of TikTok TV ad impressions since June 1, with 18.9%, while CNN is No. 2 at 15.2%. CBS, Fox, ABC and MSNBC are all among the top 10 as well.</p><p>Given the nature of the U.S. news discourse around TikTok right now, perhaps the app figures the ads move toward “setting the record straight” immediately after on-air critiques. If audiences are most likely to retain the last thing they hear about TikTok, that could be the entrepreneurship-focused ads.</p><p><strong>Audiences Respond Well to the Ads, Too</strong></p><p>iSpot Creative Assessment data shows the spots are finding some success around narrative, too. </p><ul><li>The top emotional response from survey respondents around the Whittington spot was for its narrative, and 29% of respondents said the message was the single best thing. </li><li>“Patriotic Kenny and Amanda” came off as both heartfelt and inspired to survey respondents, and the single best thing was the message there as well, according to 36% of those surveyed. </li><li>The ad was also 19% more likeable than other technology ads since June 1.</li></ul><p>So for now, at least, it seems that TikTok is fine with the extra publicity, as it successfully finds ways to spin that toward more positive attention through its ads.<br></p>",6515c1aec70a8e000187e19e,"Audiences that tuned into Wednesday night’s Republican Primary Debate on Fox News heard many familiar talk tracks, including back-and-forth around the societal and security issues with TikTok.

Entertainingly, that conversation was followed directly – at 10:29 p.m. – by an ad for the social video app, “Meet Jessie Whittington.” The spot doesn’t address the debate, but plays as a spot geared toward the Fox News audience, revolving around a soap entrepreneur in Mississippi. Data from iSpot shows that over 23% of household TV ad impressions for the ad, since it debuted in August 2023, have been delivered on Fox News.

Since TikTok was banned on U.S. federal government devices in June, the app has focused spots primarily on individual creators – and in many cases, business owners that utilize TikTok. iSpot shows that almost 48% of TikTok household TV ad impressions since June 1 were accounted for by “Patriotic Kenny and Amanda,” another spot that aired during the debate. The Whittington ad accounts for nearly 38% of ad impressions in the timeframe.

TikTok has focused heavily on cable news networks and broadcast in that timeframe as well. Fox News is the No. 1 network by share of TikTok TV ad impressions since June 1, with 18.9%, while CNN is No. 2 at 15.2%. CBS, Fox, ABC and MSNBC are all among the top 10 as well.

Given the nature of the U.S. news discourse around TikTok right now, perhaps the app figures the ads move toward “setting the record straight” immediately after on-air critiques. If audiences are most likely to retain the last thing they hear about TikTok, that could be the entrepreneurship-focused ads.

Audiences Respond Well to the Ads, Too

iSpot Creative Assessment data shows the spots are finding some success around narrative, too.

 * The top emotional response from survey respondents around the Whittington spot was for its narrative, and 29% of respondents said the message was the single best thing.
 * “Patriotic Kenny and Amanda” came off as both heartfelt and inspired to survey respondents, and the single best thing was the message there as well, according to 36% of those surveyed.
 * The ad was also 19% more likeable than other technology ads since June 1.

So for now, at least, it seems that TikTok is fine with the extra publicity, as it successfully finds ways to spin that toward more positive attention through its ads.

Destiny""],[0,[],0,"".""]],[[0,[],0,"" Hyundai and GMC veered away from country and rock, with Hyundai using the highly danceable \""""],[0,[8],1,""Make Me Feel Good (Alright With Me)""],[0,[],0,""\"" the song wasn't new – and those who chose recognizable tracks found that energy still remained a crucial factor in generating positive momentum for purchase interest.""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>For brands, picking the right soundtrack for their summer ads takes precise calculation, helping to resonate with key demographics and potential customers.</p><p>Data from <a href=""songtradr.com"">Songtradr</a> dives into the song choices of the top automative brand spots, from 2023's summer ad season:</p><ul><li>Ram's ""Opportunity"" spot, featuring the song ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oGKxXG2ONog"">Sun Ain't Even Gone Down Yet</a>"" by Brothers Osborne, gained substantial airplay during the summer and the brand capitalized on the song's rising popularity, as its Spotify popularity score increased from 0 to 58 after the ad's release.</li><li>Chevrolet featured a diverse range of music in its top TV commercials, including songs like ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NgER7DgoOZI"">Step On Out</a>"" by Pigeon John &amp; Spencer Ludwig and ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KPv976KmM44"">Live For Days</a>"" by Cal Dodds, both of which are recent releases, aiding the brand with exclusive associations to these songs.</li><li>Chevy then deviated from its usual approach in the ""Your Road to Happiness"" ad by using the 1999 pop hit ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E1fzJ_AYajA"">Steal My Sunshine</a>,"" a high-energy song also featured in several recent movies and shows (along with a T-Pain version of the track being <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/ad/1XKc/lipton-peach-iced-tea-open-summer-featuring-t-pain"">used by Lipton</a> right now).</li><li>Ford's ""Get Out There"" commercial featured the 1970 hit ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DX3o1O8ZsTw"">Up Around the Bend</a>"" by Creedence Clearwater Revival, a high-energy track that had not been used in TV, movies, or console titles since 2018, but was recently utilized in a co-branded spot by Applebee's and Lucasfilm for <em>Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny</em>.</li><li> Hyundai and GMC veered away from country and rock, with Hyundai using the highly danceable ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8EMSO2l4nFw"">Make Me Feel Good (Alright With Me)</a>"" by Todd Carey, La Felix &amp; Kash'd Out, while GMC chose ""<a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ojC0mg2hJCc"">The Seed 2.0</a>"" by The Roots, a highly positive and energetic track that, despite being 21 years old, had no recent use in ads or media, allowing GMC to establish unique brand affinity with its popularity.</li></ul><p>In 2023, numerous brands aimed to distinguish themselves with music –even if the song wasn't new – and those who chose recognizable tracks found that energy still remained a crucial factor in generating positive momentum for purchase interest.</p>",6515c81cc70a8e000187e1de,"For brands, picking the right soundtrack for their summer ads takes precise calculation, helping to resonate with key demographics and potential customers.

Data from Songtradr dives into the song choices of the top automative brand spots, from 2023's summer ad season:

 * Ram's ""Opportunity"" spot, featuring the song ""Sun Ain't Even Gone Down Yet"" by Brothers Osborne, gained substantial airplay during the summer and the brand capitalized on the song's rising popularity, as its Spotify popularity score increased from 0 to 58 after the ad's release.
 * Chevrolet featured a diverse range of music in its top TV commercials, including songs like ""Step On Out"" by Pigeon John & Spencer Ludwig and ""Live For Days"" by Cal Dodds, both of which are recent releases, aiding the brand with exclusive associations to these songs.
 * Chevy then deviated from its usual approach in the ""Your Road to Happiness"" ad by using the 1999 pop hit ""Steal My Sunshine,"" a high-energy song also featured in several recent movies and shows (along with a T-Pain version of the track being used by Lipton right now).
 * Ford's ""Get Out There"" commercial featured the 1970 hit ""Up Around the Bend"" by Creedence Clearwater Revival, a high-energy track that had not been used in TV, movies, or console titles since 2018, but was recently utilized in a co-branded spot by Applebee's and Lucasfilm for Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny.
 * Hyundai and GMC veered away from country and rock, with Hyundai using the highly danceable ""Make Me Feel Good (Alright With Me)"" by Todd Carey, La Felix & Kash'd Out, while GMC chose ""The Seed 2.0"" by The Roots, a highly positive and energetic track that, despite being 21 years old, had no recent use in ads or media, allowing GMC to establish unique brand affinity with its popularity.

In 2023, numerous brands aimed to distinguish themselves with music –even if the song wasn't new – and those who chose recognizable tracks found that energy still remained a crucial factor in generating positive momentum for purchase interest.",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/ram-trucks-make-this-the-summer-event-opportunity-song-by-brothers-osborne-t2-large-2.jpeg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-28T18:38:20.000Z,2023-09-28T18:58:00.000Z,2023-09-20T18:38:00.000Z,Data from Songtradr shows how automakers drive brand affinity through music.,,,,,,1,6515d9ffc70a8e000187e26d,7c84ee75-c8b5-4440-928c-21fdae6f70c0,MrBeast Minutes Watched Hit New High For 2023,mrbeast-minutes-hit-new-high-for-2023-tubular-data,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/mrbeast-minutes-watched-2023-tubular.jpg"",""width"":1347,""height"":787,""href"":""http://tubularlabs.com""}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://tubularlabs.com""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3YVBJ2n5xg""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://youtu.be/yhB3BgJyGl8""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jObOjhUkf50""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[0],1,""Tubular Labs""],[0,[],0,"" recently announced its findings from last month of top trends among media companies, brands and creators across YouTube and Facebook. When taking a closer look at YouTuber MrBeast, Tubular found that in August: ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""MrBeast videos scored over 1.4 billion U.S. minutes watched across YouTube and Facebook in August – up 55% compared to where he was in July. That’s his highest monthly total of the year so far, and the most he’s had since hitting 1.8 billion in December 2022.""]],[[0,[],0,""Six of MrBeast’s August video uploads have topped 100 million views so far, led by ""],[0,[1],1,""I Ate the World’s Most Poisonous Fish""],[0,[],0,"", with 189 million. ""]],[[0,[],0,""Other popular videos included being ""],[0,[2],1,""stranded at sea""],[0,[],0,"", and another about a ""],[0,[3],1,""$250K vacation giveaway""],[0,[],0,"". All three of those videos are already among his 15 most-watched of this year so far.""]]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com"">Tubular Labs</a> recently announced its findings from last month of top trends among media companies, brands and creators across YouTube and Facebook. When taking a closer look at YouTuber MrBeast, Tubular found that in August: </p><ul><li>MrBeast videos scored over 1.4 billion U.S. minutes watched across YouTube and Facebook in August – up 55% compared to where he was in July. That’s his highest monthly total of the year so far, and the most he’s had since hitting 1.8 billion in December 2022.</li><li>Six of MrBeast’s August video uploads have topped 100 million views so far, led by <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O3YVBJ2n5xg"">I Ate the World’s Most Poisonous Fish</a>, with 189 million. </li><li>Other popular videos included being <a href=""https://youtu.be/yhB3BgJyGl8"">stranded at sea</a>, and another about a <a href=""https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jObOjhUkf50"">$250K vacation giveaway</a>. All three of those videos are already among his 15 most-watched of this year so far.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/mrbeast-minutes-watched-2023-tubular.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1347"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/09/mrbeast-minutes-watched-2023-tubular.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/09/mrbeast-minutes-watched-2023-tubular.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/09/mrbeast-minutes-watched-2023-tubular.jpg 1347w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",6515d9ffc70a8e000187e26d,"Tubular Labs recently announced its findings from last month of top trends among media companies, brands and creators across YouTube and Facebook. When taking a closer look at YouTuber MrBeast, Tubular found that in August:

 * MrBeast videos scored over 1.4 billion U.S. minutes watched across YouTube and Facebook in August – up 55% compared to where he was in July. That’s his highest monthly total of the year so far, and the most he’s had since hitting 1.8 billion in December 2022.
 * Six of MrBeast’s August video uploads have topped 100 million views so far, led by I Ate the World’s Most Poisonous Fish, with 189 million.
 * Other popular videos included being stranded at sea, and another about a $250K vacation giveaway. "",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""html"",""version"":1,""html"":""                    <div style=\""position:relative; width:100%; padding-top:56.25%; padding-bottom:40px;\""><iframe src=\""https://www.ispot.tv/share/5tTD\"" style=\""position:absolute; top:0; right:0; left:0; bottom:0; width:100%; height:100%;\"" frameborder=\""0\"" scrolling=\""no\"" allowfullscreen=\""\""></iframe></div>\n                    ""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Although it had a 13.6% decrease in national TV ad impressions week-over-week, Lexus again takes first place on <a href=""https://www.wardsauto.com/industry-news/lexus-again-leads-ranking-most-seen-auto-tv-ads"">iSpot's weekly ranking of the most-seen auto TV ads</a>, scoring 295.2 million impressions from Sept. 18-24.                     ",6516c2dec70a8e000187e290,"Although it had a 13.6% decrease in national TV ad impressions week-over-week, Lexus again takes first place on iSpot's weekly ranking of the most-seen auto TV ads, scoring 295.2 million impressions from Sept. 18-24. According to iSpot’s Creative Assessment, 38% of surveyed viewers considered the product itself to be the single best thing about the Lexus commercial.

 * ""Life"" from Ram Trucks takes second place with 261.9 million national TV ad impressions, over 20% of which came from sports commentary programming.
 * With 211.6 million imprssions, Chevrolet's ""For All of Life's Firsts"" moves from fifth place the previous week up to third. NFL games delivered a total of 34.4 million impressions for the spot.
 * Volkswagen enters the ranking in fifth place with ""Carpool Chaos"" (176.2 million national TV ad impressiosn). HGTV delivered 27.6 million impressions, with 7.5 million coming from House Hunters.

",,,,,,1,6516d8e1c70a8e000187e2c3,895a5ab8-89d0-41bc-8216-24515f9c91f4,1 Hispanic-Owned Beauty Brand. $410 Million in Earned Media Value.,1-hispanic-owned-beauty-brand-410-million-in-earned-media-value,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[[""soft-return"","""",{}]],""cards"":[[""image"",{""src"":""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/66nqc-q1cUzYeh58nHAqiXM5ansuqcI4WgWDhQlZV2Fcxj6XzoE46JXxc1J2H5IwckL7jUEVpbt0DAnwDXhRaOx38kuH8XEBawahTBZ3jvtveYKuQZMeqOGKciAkXGdRjq7UroaV7vLVBRs0W3i3VoI"",""width"":586,""height"":370}]],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""http://creatoriq.com""]],[""em""],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cqb9jJUObbu/""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/rare-beauty-dominates-hispanic-owned-beauty-brands-for-earned-media-value-so-far-in-2023/""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""The cosmetics industry, with its vibrant, visual nature, is ripe for influencer marketing — and creators continually flock to give demos, share tips and promote their favorite products. But one subset of this market that often doesn’t get as much mainstream attention is Hispanic-owned beauty brands. ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""For its latest Share of Influence report, ""],[0,[0],1,""CreatorIQ""],[0,[],0,"" analyzed this sector of the cosmetics market and found that so far in 2023, over 8K creators have posted about Hispanic-owned beauty brands more than 190K times, driving an estimated 7 billion impressions, 425 million engagements, and $650 million in Earned Media Value (EMV). That constitutes a 13% year-over-year EMV increase, with a 67% increase in impression and a 64% increase in engagements compared to 2022.  ""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Leading the pack for EMV — by an astounding amount — is Selena Gomez’s Rare Beauty, for which creators have generated a massive $410.5 million EMV this year. ""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Rare Beauty was also the No. 1 U.S. cosmetics brand by EMV ($42.0 million) across the ""],[0,[1],1,""entire""],[0,[],0,"" industry in August, beating out Charlotte Tilbury ($35.3 million EMV in August) and MAC ($31.7 million).""]],[[0,[],0,""One of Rare Beauty’s most effective posts came from social media star Jooshica, who shared an ""],[0,[2],1,""Instagram Reel""],[0,[],0,"" of herself bonding with brand founder Selena Gomez at the product’s launch party for Soft Pinch Tinted Lip Oil, inspiring $205.8K EMV.""]],[[0,[],0,""While it didn’t rank among the top five Hispanic-owned beauty brands, Reina Rebelde ($1.9M EMV) sported the cohort’s most impressive year-over-year increase in EMV, rising 288% compared to January through August 2022. ""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Get more insights around Hispanic-owned beauty brands ""],[0,[3],1,""here""],[0,[],0,"".  ""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[[1,[],0,0]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>The cosmetics industry, with its vibrant, visual nature, is ripe for influencer marketing — and creators continually flock to give demos, share tips and promote their favorite products. But one subset of this market that often doesn’t get as much mainstream attention is Hispanic-owned beauty brands. </p><p>For its latest Share of Influence report, <a href=""http://creatoriq.com"">CreatorIQ</a> analyzed this sector of the cosmetics market and found that so far in 2023, over 8K creators have posted about Hispanic-owned beauty brands more than 190K times, driving an estimated 7 billion impressions, 425 million engagements, and $650 million in Earned Media Value (EMV). That constitutes a 13% year-over-year EMV increase, with a 67% increase in impression and a 64% increase in engagements compared to 2022.  </p><p>Leading the pack for EMV — by an astounding amount — is Selena Gomez’s Rare Beauty, for which creators have generated a massive $410.5 million EMV this year. </p><ul><li>Rare Beauty was also the No. 1 U.S. cosmetics brand by EMV ($42.0 million) across the <em>entire</em> industry in August, beating out Charlotte Tilbury ($35.3 million EMV in August) and MAC ($31.7 million).</li><li>One of Rare Beauty’s most effective posts came from social media star Jooshica, who shared an <a href=""https://www.instagram.com/reel/Cqb9jJUObbu/"">Instagram Reel</a> of herself bonding with brand founder Selena Gomez at the product’s launch party for Soft Pinch Tinted Lip Oil, inspiring $205.8K EMV.</li><li>While it didn’t rank among the top five Hispanic-owned beauty brands, Reina Rebelde ($1.9M EMV) sported the cohort’s most impressive year-over-year increase in EMV, rising 288% compared to January through August 2022. </li></ul><p>Get more insights around Hispanic-owned beauty brands <a href=""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/rare-beauty-dominates-hispanic-owned-beauty-brands-for-earned-media-value-so-far-in-2023/"">here</a>.  </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/66nqc-q1cUzYeh58nHAqiXM5ansuqcI4WgWDhQlZV2Fcxj6XzoE46JXxc1J2H5IwckL7jUEVpbt0DAnwDXhRaOx38kuH8XEBawahTBZ3jvtveYKuQZMeqOGKciAkXGdRjq7UroaV7vLVBRs0W3i3VoI"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""586"" height=""370""></figure>",6516d8e1c70a8e000187e2c3,"The cosmetics industry, with its vibrant, visual nature, is ripe for influencer marketing — and creators continually flock to give demos, share tips and promote their favorite products. But one subset of this market that often doesn’t get as much mainstream attention is Hispanic-owned beauty brands.

For its latest Share of Influence report, CreatorIQ analyzed this sector of the cosmetics market and found that so far in 2023, over 8K creators have posted about Hispanic-owned beauty brands more than 190K times, driving an estimated 7 billion impressions, 425 million engagements, and $650 million in Earned Media Value (EMV). That constitutes a 13% year-over-year EMV increase, with a 67% increase in impression and a 64% increase in engagements compared to 2022.  

Leading the pack for EMV — by an astounding amount — is Selena Gomez’s Rare Beauty, for which creators have generated a massive $410.5 million EMV this year.

 * Rare Beauty was also the No. 1 U.S. cosmetics brand by EMV ($42.0 million) across the entire industry in August, beating out Charlotte Tilbury ($35.3 million EMV in August) and MAC ($31.7 million).
 * One of Rare Beauty’s most effective posts came from social media star Jooshica, who shared an Instagram Reel of herself bonding with brand founder Selena Gomez at the product’s launch party for Soft Pinch Tinted Lip Oil, inspiring $205.8K EMV.
 * While it didn’t rank among the top five Hispanic-owned beauty brands, Reina Rebelde ($1.9M EMV) sported the cohort’s most impressive year-over-year increase in EMV, rising 288% compared to January through August 2022.

Get more insights around Hispanic-owned beauty brands here.  ",__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/freestocks-AFvUO61NlOU-unsplash.jpg,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-09-29T14:02:09.000Z,2023-10-04T15:35:14.000Z,2023-10-04T15:32:51.000Z,CreatorIQ’s Share of Influence report reveals that Rare Beauty dominates Hispanic-owned beauty brands for EMV so far in 2023.,,,,,,1,6516f95bc70a8e000187e2c7,c20e7621-6fd8-46de-b316-1e7bcee57d5e,News Is Still The Local Favorite,news-is-still-the-local-favorite-tv-broadcast-report,"{""version"":""0.3.1"",""atoms"":[],""cards"":[],""markups"":[[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming""]],[""a"",[""href"",""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming?ref=themeasure.net""]]],""sections"":[[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""TVREV’s latest report – ""],[0,[0],1,""Local TV: Perils & Promise In the Age of Streaming""],[0,[],0,"" – reveals that local broadcast audiences of all ages are still tuning in primarily for the evening news, despite conventional thinking around sports driving broadcast viewership.""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""News viewership for those over 65 (59%) is almost double what it is for those 25-34 (30%). Sports is also a draw for those 35 and up, but it is not nearly as popular as local news.""]],[[0,[],0,""Even among older demos, prime time broadcast is not a major reason to watch local TV, with only 34% of those over 65 reporting they watch prime time. One potential reason may be that viewers associate primetime with the network rather than the affiliate that runs it.""]],[[0,[],0,""Alan Wolk posits that local news is still a major draw and local broadcasters are smart in making it the focus of their streaming efforts.""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""[""],[0,[1],1,""READ MORE IN THE FULL REPORT""],[0,[],0,""]""]]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p>TVREV’s latest report – <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming"">Local TV: Perils &amp; Promise In the Age of Streaming</a> – reveals that local broadcast audiences of all ages are still tuning in primarily for the evening news, despite conventional thinking around sports driving broadcast viewership.</p><ul><li>News viewership for those over 65 (59%) is almost double what it is for those 25-34 (30%). Sports is also a draw for those 35 and up, but it is not nearly as popular as local news.</li><li>Even among older demos, prime time broadcast is not a major reason to watch local TV, with only 34% of those over 65 reporting they watch prime time. One potential reason may be that viewers associate primetime with the network rather than the affiliate that runs it.</li><li>Alan Wolk posits that local news is still a major draw and local broadcasters are smart in making it the focus of their streaming efforts.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming?ref=themeasure.net"">READ MORE IN THE FULL REPORT</a>]</p>",6516f95bc70a8e000187e2c7,"TVREV’s latest report – Local TV: Perils & Promise In the Age of Streaming – reveals that local broadcast audiences of all ages are still tuning in primarily for the evening news, despite conventional thinking around sports driving broadcast viewership.

 * News viewership for those over 65 (59%) is almost double what it is for those 25-34 (30%). Sports is also a draw for those 35 and up, but it is not nearly as popular as local news.
 * Even among older demos, prime time broadcast is not a major reason to watch local TV, with only 34% of those over 65 reporting they watch prime time. One potential reason may be that viewers associate primetime with the network rather than the affiliate that runs it.
 * Alan Wolk posits that local news is still a major draw and local broadcasters are smart in making it the focus of their streaming efforts.

""]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 25 through October 1:""]]],[3,""ul"",[[[0,[],0,""Fox takes third place with 7.41% of watch-time, up from No. 4 and 7.30% last week. CNN had the largest position increase among the networks in the top 25, moving to No. 11 from No. 14 previously.""]],[[0,[],0,""Lifetime was the sole week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 25 with a 0.79% viewership share fueled by reruns of ""],[0,[0],1,""Castle""],[0,[],0,"" and ""],[0,[0],1,""Rizzoli & Isles""],[0,[],0,"".""]]]],[1,""p"",[[0,[],0,""There were a few week-over-week newcomers to the ""],[0,[2],1,""top 25 program ranking""],[0,[],0,"" — check it out over at TVREV.""]]],[10,0],[1,""p"",[]]],""ghostVersion"":""4.0""}",,"<p><em>Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from </em><a href=""http://inscape.tv""><em>Inscape</em></a><em>, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 25 through October 1 — <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/ryder-cup-agt-break-into-top-ten-most-watched-tv-programs"">head over to TVREV</a> to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.</em></p><p>With a 8.80% viewership share, NBC squarely takes first place on the network ranking. NFL games, the Ryder Cup and two of NBC’s flagship reality shows — <em>America’s Got Talent</em> and <em>The Voice</em> — helped the network assume the throne over ABC (7.70% of watch-time). </p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 25 through October 1:</p><ul><li>Fox takes third place with 7.41% of watch-time, up from No. 4 and 7.30% last week. NFL, college football and <em>The OT</em> were three of its top programs.</li><li>Cable news networks made gains week-over-week, with both Fox News and MSNBC moving up one chart position. CNN had the largest position increase among the networks in the top 25, moving to No. 11 from No. 14 previously.</li><li>Lifetime was the sole week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 25 with a 0.79% viewership share fueled by reruns of <em>Castle</em> and <em>Rizzoli &amp; Isles</em>.</li></ul><p>There were a few week-over-week newcomers to the <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/ryder-cup-agt-break-into-top-ten-most-watched-tv-programs"">top 25 program ranking</a> — check it out over at TVREV.</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksSept25-Oct1.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksSept25-Oct1.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksSept25-Oct1.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksSept25-Oct1.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",651c1c1f054b080001a86a95,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for September 25 through October 1 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

With a 8.80% viewership share, NBC squarely takes first place on the network ranking. NFL games, the Ryder Cup and two of NBC’s flagship reality shows — America’s Got Talent and The Voice — helped the network assume the throne over ABC (7.70% of watch-time).

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from September 25 through October 1:

 * Fox takes third place with 7.41% of watch-time, up from No. 4 and 7.30% last week. NFL, college football and The OT were three of its top programs.
 * Cable news networks made gains week-over-week, with both Fox News and MSNBC moving up one chart position. CNN had the largest position increase among the networks in the top 25, moving to No. 11 from No. 14 previously.
 * Lifetime was the sole week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 25 with a 0.79% viewership share fueled by reruns of Castle and Rizzoli & Isles.

new <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/resources/free-reports/spanish-language-tv-advertising-report/"">Spanish-language TV advertising report</a> shows major gains year-over-year, with household ad impressions jumping by over 26% from Q1 through Q3. For the brands paying attention to these trends, there's a major opportunity to reach a growing audience in the U.S. (as the number of Hispanic Americans have grown by 26% since 2010 according to Pew Research).</p><ul><li><strong><strong>Dialing Up Daytime</strong></strong>: On Univision, daytime TV ad impressions through Q3 increased by 21.5% YoY (vs. the same stretch in 2022), helping pace daytime impressions increases across TV as more brands put focus on that daypart.</li><li><strong><strong>Beer Bubble</strong></strong>: Major beer brands put significant emphasis on Spanish-language TV ad impressions — 29% of Modelo’s 2023 TV ad impressions were in Spanish, and that number was even higher (31.8%) for Michelob Ultra.</li><li><strong><strong>QSR Delivers</strong>: </strong>Not only did quick-serve restaurants account for the highest impressions SOV (8.90%) for Spanish-language advertising, the industry also owned 35 of the top 50 Spanish-language ads by Likeability, based on iSpot’s Creative Assessment data.</li></ul>",651dc1c5054b080001a86ac4,"iSpot’s new Spanish-language TV advertising report shows major gains year-over-year, with household ad impressions jumping by over 26% from Q1 through Q3. For the brands paying attention to these trends, there's a major opportunity to reach a growing audience in the U.S. (as the number of Hispanic Americans have grown by 26% since 2010 according to Pew Research).

 * Dialing Up Daytime: On Univision, daytime TV ad impressions through Q3 increased by 21.5% YoY (vs. the same stretch in 2022), helping pace daytime impressions increases across TV as more brands put focus on that daypart.
 * Beer Bubble: Major beer brands put significant emphasis on Spanish-language TV ad impressions — 29% of Modelo’s 2023 TV ad impressions were in Spanish, and that number was even higher (31.8%) for Michelob Ultra.

Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""TVREV has the ranking"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":""noreferrer"",""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/mlb-slides-into-third-place-for-most-watched-tv-programming""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"". "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct2-8.png"",""width"":1018,""height"":1219,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from <a href=""http://inscape.tv""><em><u>Inscape</u></em></a>, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 2-8 — head over to TVREV to see the <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/mlb-slides-into-third-place-for-most-watched-tv-programming"" rel=""noreferrer""><em>program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time</em></a>.</em></p><p>NBC takes first place for the second week in a row, but saw watch-time decrease slightly, from 8.80% to 8.33%. NFL games, <em>Today</em> and <em>The Voice</em> were three of the programs fueling viewership on the network.&nbsp;</p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 2-8:</p><ul><li>CBS jumps from fourth to second place week-over-week with a 8.22% viewership share, driven by NFL and college football games.&nbsp;</li><li>Cable news networks (Fox News, MSNBC, CNN) each saw increases in watch-time compared to the previous week. While Fox News and MSNBC maintain their chart positions, CNN moves up from No. 11 to No. 9.&nbsp;</li><li>Both of the week-over-week ranking newcomers were sports networks: NFL Network jumps from No. 32 to No. 15 with a 1.16% viewership share, while Fox Sports 1 lands at No. 19, up from No. 34 previously (1.07% of minutes watched).&nbsp;</li></ul><p>What were the most-watched TV programs (aside from football, of course) last week? <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/mlb-slides-into-third-place-for-most-watched-tv-programming"" rel=""noreferrer"">TVREV has the ranking</a>.&nbsp;</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct2-8.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct2-8.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct2-8.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct2-8.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",65255b73e9b05d0001c98a1b,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 2-8 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

NBC takes first place for the second week in a row, but saw watch-time decrease slightly, from 8.80% to 8.33%. NFL games, Today and The Voice were three of the programs fueling viewership on the network. 

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 2-8:

 * CBS jumps from fourth to second place week-over-week with a 8.22% viewership share, driven by NFL and college football games. 
 * Cable news networks (Fox News, MSNBC, CNN) each saw increases in watch-time compared to the previous week. While Fox News and MSNBC maintain their chart positions, CNN moves up from No. 11 to No. 9. 
 * Both of the week-over-week ranking newcomers were sports networks: NFL Network jumps from No. 32 to No. 15 with a 1.16% viewership share, while Fox Sports 1 lands at No. 19, up from No. 34 previously (1.07% of minutes watched).

"",""type"":""text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""new study from ("",""type"":""text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""CIMM"",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":""noreferrer"",""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://cimm-us.org/""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"") revealed major findings around data accuracy – or lack thereof – that impacts billions of dollars in marketing there are opportunities for improvement. For example, the report analyzes the average CPG campaign, demonstrating how these advertisers could improve its returns from $1.08 to $1.54 per dollar invested, by improving the quality of the identity data and match rates utilized in support of the campaign."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Truthset ingested data from 15 leading data companies, consisting of more than 3.9 billion hashed emails (HEMs) and postal linkages from every zip code in America. Truthset then validated the information against the U.S. Census Bureau, Pew Research Center, and a variety of other independent, self-reported, and declared data from more than 20 million records for the period 2005-2023."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png"",""width"":1846,""height"":954,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>A <a href=""https://www.adweek.com/adweek-wire/massive-study-on-matching-households-and-email-addresses-finds-range-of-inaccuracies/"" rel=""noreferrer"">new study from Truthset</a>, in partnership with the Coalition for Innovative Media Measurement (<a href=""https://cimm-us.org/"" rel=""noreferrer"">CIMM</a>) revealed major findings around data accuracy – or lack thereof – that impacts billions of dollars in marketing spend.</p><ul><li>The study found large-scale accuracy variations for matches between email addresses and household postal addresses across the data industry, ranging from 32% up to 69% – a reflection of different data capture processes and update rules.</li><li>But there are opportunities for improvement. For example, the report analyzes the average CPG campaign, demonstrating how these advertisers could improve its returns from $1.08 to $1.54 per dollar invested, by improving the quality of the identity data and match rates utilized in support of the campaign.</li><li>Truthset ingested data from 15 leading data companies, consisting of more than 3.9 billion hashed emails (HEMs) and postal linkages from every zip code in America. Truthset then validated the information against the U.S. Census Bureau, Pew Research Center, and a variety of other independent, self-reported, and declared data from more than 20 million records for the period 2005-2023.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1846"" height=""954"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-10-at-7.40.24-AM.png 1846w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",65256543e9b05d0001c98a33,"A new study from Truthset, in partnership with the Coalition for Innovative Media Measurement (CIMM) revealed major findings around data accuracy – or lack thereof – that impacts billions of dollars in marketing spend.

 * The study found large-scale accuracy variations for matches between email addresses and household postal addresses across the data industry, ranging from 32% up to 69% – a reflection of different data capture processes and update rules.
 * But there are opportunities for improvement. For example, the report analyzes the average CPG campaign, demonstrating how these advertisers could improve its returns from $1.08 to $1.54 per dollar invested, by improving the quality of the identity data and match rates utilized in support of the campaign.
 * Truthset ingested data from 15 leading data companies, consisting of more than 3.9 billion hashed emails (HEMs) and postal linkages from every zip code in America. Truthset then validated the information against the U.S. Census Bureau, Pew Research Center, and a variety of other independent, self-reported, and declared data from more than 20 million records for the period 2005-2023.",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1524813686514-a57563d77965?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDF8fG5laWdoYm9yaG9vZHxlbnwwfHx8fDE2OTY5NTAxMTN8MA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-10-10T14:52:51.000Z,2023-10-10T15:03:13.000Z,2023-10-10T15:03:13.000Z,,,,,,,1,6526ec47e9b05d0001c98a7b,7108582e-5dfe-41ae-98f6-8d902ecb1a89,Are Whippersnappers Streaming Local News?,who-streams-local-news-tvrev-broadcast-report,,"{""root"":{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources. "",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""But: Younger viewers do stream local news (even if to lesser extents). FAST platforms do seem to have an early advantage here – impressive given the relatively short time local FAST news offerings have been available. However, market share in this category is clearly up for grabs."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources. Yet younger viewers ARE streaming news according to TVREV’s report, <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming""><u>Local TV: Perils &amp; Promise In the Age of Streaming</u></a>. </p><ul><li>Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources.</li><li>But: Younger viewers do stream local news (even if to lesser extents). That two-thirds of Gen Z and Millennials actually stream local news, and do so on so many various platforms, comes as a bit bit of a surprise.</li><li>Local news streaming is very fragmented. FAST platforms do seem to have an early advantage here – impressive given the relatively short time local FAST news offerings have been available. However, market share in this category is clearly up for grabs.</li></ul>",6526ec47e9b05d0001c98a7b,"Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources. Yet younger viewers ARE streaming news according to TVREV’s report, Local TV: Perils & Promise In the Age of Streaming.

 * Older TV viewers don’t stream local news, with 55% of those over 45 reporting that they never stream news from local sources.
 * But: Younger viewers do stream local news (even if to lesser extents). That two-thirds of Gen Z and Millennials actually stream local news, and do so on so many various platforms, comes as a bit bit of a surprise.
 * Local news streaming is very fragmented. FAST platforms do seem to have an early advantage here – impressive given the relatively short time local FAST news offerings have been available. However, market share in this category is clearly up for TV."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-11-at-11.51.50-AM.png"",""width"":1064,""height"":610,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>As part of its latest report, <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/special-reports/p/local-tv-perils-promise-in-the-age-of-streaming""><u>Local TV: Perils &amp; Promise In the Age of Streaming</u></a>, TVREV found that a large share of those surveyed still feel there's a need for local TV stations.</p><ul><li>27% of respondents (all over 25 years old) said they wouldn't feel sufficiently informed by other sources if their local broadcast station shut down, and 38% were unsure if they would feel sufficiently informed.</li><li>60% of audiences over 65 and 52% of those aged 55-64 would feel ""very/fairly upset"" if streaming apps was the only way to access local broadcast.</li><li>Meanwhile, 51% of those aged 25-34 indicated they would not be upset at all if they had to rely on streaming apps over local broadcast TV.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/Screen-Shot-2023-10-11-at-11.51.50-AM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" surveyed still feel there's a need for local TV stations.

 * 27% of respondents (all over 25 years old) said they wouldn't feel sufficiently informed by other sources if their local broadcast station shut down, and 38% were unsure if they would feel sufficiently informed.
 * 60% of audiences over 65 and 52% of those aged 55-64 would feel ""very/fairly upset"" if streaming apps was the only way to access local broadcast.

started."",""type"":""text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/tubular-reality-big-year-social.jpg"",""width"":1347,""height"":787,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Entertainment work stoppages helped give reality content a boost this summer – both on TV and on YouTube. <a href=""http://tubularlabs.com""><u>Tubular Labs</u></a> data shows U.S. reality content hitting a high in August, and nearing 14 billion YouTube views on the year already.</p><ul><li>Interestingly, while reality show <em>Vanderpump Rules</em> seemed to be everywhere during the first half of 2023, that didn’t necessarily translate to an explosion of views on YouTube. The show accounted for a little over 100 million views this year, while<em> America’s Got Talent </em>generated over 800 million.</li><li><em>AGT</em> was also a big part of reality's surge to 2.09 billion views in August as the show shared highlights and spawned various accounts sharing clips as well.</li><li>With some of reality's younger audiences back at school, and with the NFL season starting in September, you already saw reality content cooling off a little last month – though views were still higher than every month before summer started.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/tubular-reality-big-year-social.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1347"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/10/tubular-reality-big-year-social.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/10/tubular-reality-big-year-social.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/tubular-reality-big-year-social.jpg 1347w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",6526f4f2e9b05d0001c98ac1,"Entertainment work stoppages helped give reality content a boost this summer – both on TV and on YouTube. Tubular Labs data shows U.S. reality content hitting a high in August, and nearing 14 billion YouTube views on the year already.

 * Interestingly, while reality show Vanderpump Rules seemed to be everywhere during the first half of 2023, that didn’t necessarily translate to an explosion of views on YouTube. The show accounted for a little over 100 million views this year, while America’s Got Talent generated over 800 million.
 * AGT was also a big part of reality's surge to 2.09 billion views in August as the show shared highlights and spawned various accounts sharing clips as well.

demographics."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":4}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-michelob-data-dose.jpg"",""width"":1375,""height"":787,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/beer-brands-bubble-up-on-tv-in-q3/""},{""children"":[],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Beer advertising may be most associated with sports, but some brands are changing that. For instance, <a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/beer-brands-bubble-up-on-tv-in-q3/"" rel=""noreferrer"">iSpot data shows that in Q3</a>, 23% of Michelob Ultra’s TV ad impressions were delivered by telenovelas (No. 1 among all show genres for the brand).</p><ul><li>Michelob is the No. 8 advertiser during telenovelas in 2023, by household TV ad impressions.</li><li>The brand has also been focusing on a bigger push with Spanish-language advertising all year, as nearly 33% of its ad impressions come from Spanish-language spots.</li><li>Comparatively, just 15% of the beer industry's TV ad impressions have been attributable to Spanish-language ads in 2023.</li><li>Understanding impression delivery and audience trends helps advertisers optimize ad buys to strengthen affinity in a target market, or expand into previously untapped demographics.</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.ispot.tv/hub/beer-brands-bubble-up-on-tv-in-q3/""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-michelob-data-dose.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1375"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/ispot-michelob-data-dose.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/ispot-michelob-data-dose.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-michelob-data-dose.jpg 1375w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",65270c55e9b05d0001c98afc,"Beer advertising may be most associated with sports, but some brands are changing that. For instance, iSpot data shows that in Q3, 23% of Michelob Ultra’s TV ad impressions were delivered by telenovelas (No. 1 among all show genres for the brand).

 * Michelob is the No. 8 advertiser during telenovelas in 2023, by household TV ad impressions.
 * The brand has also been focusing on a bigger push with Spanish-language advertising all year, as nearly 33% of its ad impressions come from Spanish-language spots.
 * Comparatively, just 15% of the beer industry's TV ad impressions have been attributable to Spanish-language ads in 2023.

TVREV"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":""noreferrer"",""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/college-football-mlb-see-week-over-week-gains-for-tv-viewership-share""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"". "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct9-15.png"",""width"":1018,""height"":1219,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from <a href=""http://inscape.tv""><em>Inscape</em></a>, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 9-15 — head over to TVREV to see the <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/college-football-mlb-see-week-over-week-gains-for-tv-viewership-share"" rel=""noreferrer""><em>program ranking </em></a>and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.</em></p><p>NBC takes first place for the third week in a row, but saw watch-time decrease slightly, from 8.33% to 8.02%. <em>The Voice</em>, <em>Today</em> and college football were three of the programs fueling viewership on the network.&nbsp;</p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 9-15:</p><ul><li>Thanks to NFL, college football and MLB games, Fox jumps into second place with a 7.49% viewership share, while ABC remains in third week-over-week with a slight decrease in minutes watched (down to 7.32% from 7.82% previously).&nbsp;</li><li>TruTV rockets into the ranking at No. 19, with its viewership increase driven primarily by MLB games.&nbsp;</li><li>Additional week-over-week ranking newcomers include TNT (No. 24) and Lifetime (No. 25).&nbsp;</li></ul><p><a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/college-football-mlb-see-week-over-week-gains-for-tv-viewership-share"" rel=""noreferrer"">Check out the latest ranking of most-watched TV programs at TVREV</a>.&nbsp;</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct9-15.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct9-15.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct9-15.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/10/InscapeTopNetworksOct9-15.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",652e97aadb5a71000120615a,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 9-15 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

NBC takes first place for the third week in a row, but saw watch-time decrease slightly, from 8.33% to 8.02%. The Voice, Today and college football were three of the programs fueling viewership on the network. 

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 9-15:

 * Thanks to NFL, college football and MLB games, Fox jumps into second place with a 7.49% viewership share, while ABC remains in third week-over-week with a slight decrease in minutes watched (down to 7.32% from 7.82% previously). 
 * TruTV rockets into the ranking at No. 19, with its viewership increase driven primarily by MLB games. 
 * Additional week-over-week ranking newcomers include TNT (No. 24) and Lifetime (No. 25).

out the FULL report: "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""HERE"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.inscape.tv/resources/insights/2023/market-trends-report-q2-2023""}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Cord-cutting may get the headlines, but there’s another audience trend making inroads: “Quiet quitting,” which is the focus of part of <a href=""https://www.inscape.tv/resources/insights/2023/market-trends-report-q2-2023"" rel=""noreferrer"">Inscape’s latest TV viewership trends report</a>.&nbsp;</p><p><a href=""http://inscape.tv"" rel=""noreferrer"">Inscape</a> examined U.S. households with a cable/satellite subscription and found that these “quiet quitters” were actually more prevalent than full quitters in Q2 2023. Looking at U.S. cable/satellite households, Inscape noted that 9% reduced their cable/satellite viewing by 75% or more from Q2 2022 to Q2 2023 (to account for viewing seasonality), but didn’t fully quit. Additionally, 8.4% of U.S. cable/satellite households had a drop of 50-75% in cable/satellite viewing time in Q2 2023 from Q2 2022.</p><p>But that being said, there are two genres that continue to draw audiences in with cable/satellite: sports and news programming.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>According to Inscape data, while streaming commands 56.5% of overall TV viewing time, that drops to 23.1% for sports and 14.7% for news.&nbsp;</li><li>Cable/satellite/antenna, meanwhile, accounts for 43.5% of overall TV viewing time, but dominates in sports (76.9%) and news (85.3%).</li><li>Just 5% of U.S. cable/satellite households quit viewing entirely on those sources in Q2 2023.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Check out the FULL report: <a href=""https://www.inscape.tv/resources/insights/2023/market-trends-report-q2-2023"">HERE</a></p>",65301058108ae80001abba65,"Cord-cutting may get the headlines, but there’s another audience trend making inroads: “Quiet quitting,” which is the focus of part of Inscape’s latest TV viewership trends report. 

Inscape examined U.S. households with a cable/satellite subscription and found that these “quiet quitters” were actually more prevalent than full quitters in Q2 2023. Looking at U.S. cable/satellite households, Inscape noted that 9% reduced their cable/satellite viewing by 75% or more from Q2 2022 to Q2 2023 (to account for viewing seasonality), but didn’t fully quit. Additionally, 8.4% of U.S. cable/satellite households had a drop of 50-75% in cable/satellite viewing time in Q2 2023 from Q2 2022.

But that being said, there are two genres that continue to draw audiences in with cable/satellite: sports and news programming. 

 * According to Inscape data, while streaming commands 56.5% of overall TV viewing time, that drops to 23.1% for sports and 14.7% for news. 
 * Cable/satellite/antenna, meanwhile, accounts for 43.5% of overall TV viewing time, but dominates in sports (76.9%) and news (85.3%).
 * Just 5% of U.S. cable/satellite households quit viewing entirely on those sources in Q2 2023.
