week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from <a href=""http://inscape.tv""><em>Inscape</em></a>, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 30 through November 5 — head over to <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/football-scores-yellowstone-gallops-into-ranking-of-most-watched-tv-programs"" rel=""noreferrer""><em>TVREV to see the program ranking</em></a> and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.</em></p><p>Fox jumps from third to first place week-over-week, accounting for 8.31% of TV watch-time. Viewership was largely driven by NFL and college football, plus the MLB World Series, which wrapped up on Nov. 1 with the Texas Rangers emerging victorious over the Arizona Diamondbacks after four games.&nbsp;</p><p>Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 30 through November 5:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>NFL Network scored 1.51% of watch-time, jumping from No. 37 to No. 13 week-over-week. Its increased viewership share was fueled in part by the NFL Sunday morning matchup between the Miami Dolphins and Kansas City Chiefs that took place in Frankfurt, Germany as part of the league’s five-game international series.</li><li>Paramount Network was another week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 19 with a 1.09% viewership share. <em>Yellowstone</em> episodes accounted for over 68% of the network’s watch-time.&nbsp;</li><li>Holiday programming on Hallmark Channel and Hallmark Movies &amp; Mysteries continues to fuel increased viewership on both networks, which move up to No. 7 and No. 15, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li></ul><p>Check out the latest ranking of <a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/football-scores-yellowstone-gallops-into-ranking-of-most-watched-tv-programs"" rel=""noreferrer"">most-watched programs on TV</a> at TVREV.&nbsp;</p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/InscapeTopNetworksOct30-Nov5.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1018"" height=""1219"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/InscapeTopNetworksOct30-Nov5.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/InscapeTopNetworksOct30-Nov5.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/InscapeTopNetworksOct30-Nov5.png 1018w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",654a52c93b6d610001c53eee,"Each week, we highlight the most-watched shows and networks using insights from Inscape, the currency-grade smart TV ACR data provider and data technology division of Vizio. Data is linear, live TV only and includes all episode types (new and reruns). Rankings are by percent share duration (i.e., time spent watching). Here's a look at the top 25 networks by viewership share for October 30 through November 5 — head over to TVREV to see the program ranking and get insights about the top shows by watch-time.

Fox jumps from third to first place week-over-week, accounting for 8.31% of TV watch-time. Viewership was largely driven by NFL and college football, plus the MLB World Series, which wrapped up on Nov. 1 with the Texas Rangers emerging victorious over the Arizona Diamondbacks after four games. 

Additional insights around the most-watched networks from October 30 through November 5: 

 * NFL Network scored 1.51% of watch-time, jumping from No. 37 to No. 13 week-over-week. Its increased viewership share was fueled in part by the NFL Sunday morning matchup between the Miami Dolphins and Kansas City Chiefs that took place in Frankfurt, Germany as part of the league’s five-game international series.
 * Paramount Network was another week-over-week ranking newcomer, landing at No. 19 with a 1.09% viewership share. Yellowstone episodes accounted for over 68% of the network’s watch-time. 
 * Holiday programming on Hallmark Channel and Hallmark Movies & Mysteries continues to fuel increased viewership on both networks, which move up to No. 7 and No. 15, respectively.

"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""NBCU already clawed back next-day air capability from Hulu for Peacock last year. But Hulu's remaining NBCU catalog accounts for 4% of the streaming library’s demand, the second largest share behind Disney owned networks."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Hulu is considered by many to be the gold standard in AVOD, with a whopping 57% of its subscribers paying for the ad-supported tier, per Antenna."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""["",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":""noreferrer"",""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.tvrev.com/news/are-hulus-linear-leanings""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""]"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p><em>The following is</em>&nbsp;<em>a selection</em>&nbsp;<em>from Brandon Katz of</em>&nbsp;<a href=""http://parrotanalytics.com/?ref=themeasure.net""><em>Parrot Analytics</em></a><em>.</em></p><p>The Walt Disney Company is acquiring Comcast’s remaining 33% stake in Hul. But what exactly is Disney getting with this deal? Data from Parrot Analytics looked at demand shares to shed light on how Hulu is still very focused on linear TV via the MVPD side of its business, and a catalog that still (for now) includes some NBCU programs as well.</p><ul><li>Hulu remains a very linear-reliant streaming service with 70% of its audience demand being driven by programming that originally aired on broadcast and cable, according to Parrot Analytics. </li><li>NBCU already clawed back next-day air capability from Hulu for Peacock last year. But Hulu's remaining NBCU catalog accounts for 4% of the streaming library’s demand, the second largest share behind Disney owned networks.</li><li>Hulu is considered by many to be the gold standard in AVOD, with a whopping 57% of its subscribers paying for the ad-supported tier, per Antenna.</li></ul><p>[<a href=""https://www.tvrev.com/news/are-hulus-linear-leanings"" rel=""noreferrer"">read the rest of Brandon Katz's post on TVREV</a>]</p>",654be2473b6d610001c53f0e,"The following is a selection from Brandon Katz of Parrot Analytics.

The Walt Disney Company is acquiring Comcast’s remaining 33% stake in Hul. But what exactly is Disney getting with this deal? Data from Parrot Analytics looked at demand shares to shed light on how Hulu is still very focused on linear TV via the MVPD side of its business, and a catalog that still (for now) includes some NBCU programs as well.

 * Hulu remains a very linear-reliant streaming service with 70% of its audience demand being driven by programming that originally aired on broadcast and cable, according to Parrot Analytics.
 * NBCU already clawed back next-day air capability from Hulu for Peacock last year. But Hulu's remaining NBCU catalog accounts for 4% of the streaming library’s demand, the second largest share behind Disney owned networks.
 * Hulu is considered by many to be the gold standard in AVOD, with a whopping 57% of its subscribers paying for the ad-supported tier, per Antenna.

"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Auto & general insurance and automakers each accounted for more than 8% of household TV ad impressions during the postseason, led by brands like GEICO, Liberty Mutual, Jeep and Genesis (among many more)."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"" MLB games accounted for more than 62% of New Balance's TV ad impressions during the timeframe."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Perhaps surprisingly, the beer industry is less focused on MLB Playoffs. Beer was not among the top 10 industries by TV ad impressions during this postseason (No. 12), and was even lower last year (No. 15)."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-mlb-postseason-brands.jpg"",""width"":1375,""height"":787,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>There was much hand-wringing about the 2023 MLB postseason TV audience (even by your author). But the news wasn't ALL doom and gloom on the TV front. This year’s MLB Playoffs delivered over 18 billion household TV ad impressions – a 21% increase YoY, according to data from <a href=""http://ispot.tv"">iSpot</a>. </p><ul><li>Auto &amp; general insurance and automakers each accounted for more than 8% of household TV ad impressions during the postseason, led by brands like GEICO, Liberty Mutual, Jeep and Genesis (among many more).</li><li> MLB games accounted for more than 62% of New Balance's TV ad impressions during the timeframe.</li><li>Perhaps surprisingly, the beer industry is less focused on MLB Playoffs. Beer was not among the top 10 industries by TV ad impressions during this postseason (No. 12), and was even lower last year (No. 15).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-mlb-postseason-brands.jpg"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1375"" height=""787"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/ispot-mlb-postseason-brands.jpg 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/ispot-mlb-postseason-brands.jpg 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-mlb-postseason-brands.jpg 1375w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",654c5a913b6d610001c53fa9,"There was much hand-wringing about the 2023 MLB postseason TV audience (even by your author). But the news wasn't ALL doom and gloom on the TV front. This year’s MLB Playoffs delivered over 18 billion household TV ad impressions – a 21% increase YoY, according to data from iSpot.

 * Auto & general insurance and automakers each accounted for more than 8% of household TV ad impressions during the postseason, led by brands like GEICO, Liberty Mutual, Jeep and Genesis (among many more).
 * MLB games accounted for more than 62% of New Balance's TV ad impressions during the timeframe.
 * Perhaps surprisingly, the beer industry is less focused on MLB Playoffs. December. "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screen-Shot-2023-11-09-at-3.27.21-PM.png"",""width"":1180,""height"":1106,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/2023-holiday-content-trends-unwrapped/?cid=C02124""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>As shoppers prepare for the busiest season of the year, brands and agencies are looking to find the best way to find consumers looking for the right deal at the right time. <a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/2023-holiday-content-trends-unwrapped/?cid=C02124"">According to a new report </a>from Tubular Labs and Chartbeat, shoppers are looking up deals on mobile post-turkey dinners.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Chartbeat shows that in 2022, mobile traffic increased 59% from 11a.m.-noon and then peaked at 3 p.m. Search traffic peaked at 9 p.m. on Thanksgiving – just as people were finishing their pie, shoo-ing their relatives out the door, and looking for early deals.</li><li>While search around Cyber Monday and Black Friday surged through Thanksgiving, the focus shifted to social from Black Friday on.</li><li>Through Tubular's Consumer Insights product, it was revealed that audiences that are looking for Black Friday deals across social video and Amazon, are more likely to plan out expensive purchases like tech products and gaming consoles in the fall months leading into the holidays. Smaller purchases like makeup and fashion were found to be researched closer to the holidays in December.&nbsp;</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://tubularlabs.com/research-guides/2023-holiday-content-trends-unwrapped/?cid=C02124""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screen-Shot-2023-11-09-at-3.27.21-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""1180"" height=""1106"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/Screen-Shot-2023-11-09-at-3.27.21-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/Screen-Shot-2023-11-09-at-3.27.21-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screen-Shot-2023-11-09-at-3.27.21-PM.png 1180w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",654d69513b6d610001c53fdd,"As shoppers prepare for the busiest season of the year, brands and agencies are looking to find the best way to find consumers looking for the right deal at the right time. According to a new report from Tubular Labs and Chartbeat, shoppers are looking up deals on mobile post-turkey dinners. 

 * Chartbeat shows that in 2022, mobile traffic increased 59% from 11a.m.-noon and then peaked at 3 p.m. Search traffic peaked at 9 p.m. on Thanksgiving – just as people were finishing their pie, shoo-ing their relatives out the door, and looking for early deals.
 * While search around Cyber Monday and Black Friday surged through Thanksgiving, the focus shifted to social from Black Friday on.
 * Through Tubular's Consumer Insights product, it was revealed that audiences that are looking for Black Friday deals across social video and Amazon, are more likely to plan out expensive purchases like tech products and gaming consoles in the fall months leading into the holidays. Smaller purchases like makeup and fashion were found to be researched closer to the holidays in December. ",https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1472851294608-062f824d29cc?crop=entropy&cs=tinysrgb&fit=max&fm=jpg&ixid=M3wxMTc3M3wwfDF8c2VhcmNofDE2fHxlY29tbWVyY2V8ZW58MHx8fHwxNjk5NTcyNTEyfDA&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&q=80&w=2000,0,post,published,,public,all,2023-11-09T23:20:49.000Z,2023-11-09T23:29:59.000Z,2023-11-09T13:28:00.000Z,,,,,,,1,654d6bb33b6d610001c54005,e5ca9266-d706-4a81-a4c1-2df3c024d356,What's The Impact Of Merging MarTech And Adtech?,whats-the-impact-of-merging-martech-and-adtech,,"{""root"":{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Recently,  cross-channel performance marketing and advertising software company "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Wunderkind"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.wunderkind.co/""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"" rolled out its "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Publisher Growth Suite"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""link"",""version"":1,""rel"":null,""target"":null,""title"":null,""url"":""https://www.wunderkind.co/solutions/multichannel-for-publishers/""},{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":"", alleviating what are often competing advertising and marketing strategies operating in silos and competing for reader attention. "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Since their integration, TMB has seen year-over-year increases in magazine subscriptions (up 6%), and newsletter signups (up 46%), all while increasing ad impressions served (up 84%)."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""These days, considering the increasingly fragmented consumer landscape, it’s mission-critical that publishers have tools working together to identify audience and extract the optimal value."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Recently,  cross-channel performance marketing and advertising software company <a href=""https://www.wunderkind.co/"">Wunderkind</a> rolled out its <a href=""https://www.wunderkind.co/solutions/multichannel-for-publishers/"">Publisher Growth Suite</a>, alleviating what are often competing advertising and marketing strategies operating in silos and competing for reader attention. The solution enables publishers to meet their audience where they are in their lifecycle, with relevant content.</p><ul><li>Some brands are already seeing the benefit. Among the early beta customers of Wunderkinds’s Publisher Growth Suite is Trusted Media Brands (TMB), which includes properties like Reader’s Digest, Taste of Home, and Family Handyman. </li><li>Since their integration, TMB has seen year-over-year increases in magazine subscriptions (up 6%), and newsletter signups (up 46%), all while increasing ad impressions served (up 84%).</li><li>These days, considering the increasingly fragmented consumer landscape, it’s mission-critical that publishers have tools working together to identify audience and extract the optimal value.</li></ul><p></p>",654d6bb33b6d610001c54005,"Recently, cross-channel performance marketing and advertising software company Wunderkind rolled out its Publisher Growth Suite, alleviating what are often competing advertising and marketing strategies operating in silos and competing for reader attention. The solution enables publishers to meet their audience where they are in their lifecycle, with relevant content.

 * Some brands are already seeing the benefit. Among the early beta customers of Wunderkinds’s Publisher Growth Suite is Trusted Media Brands (TMB), which includes properties like Reader’s Digest, Taste of Home, and Family Handyman.
 * Since their integration, TMB has seen year-over-year increases in magazine subscriptions (up 6%), and newsletter signups (up 46%), all while increasing ad impressions served (up 84%).
 * These days, considering the increasingly fragmented consumer landscape, it’s mission-critical that publishers have tools working together to identify audience and extract the optimal value.

And while that may remain a reason why people say they stay subscribed to pay TV in studies, from a TV ad stand point, you may be surprised."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Below is a ranking of TV genres by ad impressions delivered from Oct 1st through yesterday Nov 9th, according to iSpot.tv "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""The sports part is correct, football (NFL + College) are 55% of all ad impressions News? It's 9th with less than 2% of all ad reach on national linear TV. Throw in sports commentary and baseball and you're at 66% mas or menos."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""News– the stuff that attempts to deliver facts so we can make educated decisions? 1.57%. But I digress. "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png"",""width"":2124,""height"":1646,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Everywhere you look people are talking about how news and sports are holding up linear.  And while that may remain a reason why people say they stay subscribed to pay TV in studies, from a TV ad stand point, you may be surprised.</p><p>Below is a ranking of TV genres by ad impressions delivered from Oct 1st through yesterday Nov 9th, according to iSpot.tv </p><p>The sports part is correct, football (NFL + College) are 55% of all ad impressions News? It's 9th with less than 2% of all ad reach on national linear TV. Throw in sports commentary and baseball and you're at 66% mas or menos.</p><p>News– the stuff that attempts to deliver facts so we can make educated decisions? 1.57%. Now to be fair, that doesn't include entertainment news, business news or the stuff on news networks that is anything but news. </p><p>Also to be fair, Lester Holt accounts is the 5th largest show to deliver ad reach and Muir clocks in at 9th (.025% of all TV).</p><p>Also, C-SPAN doesn't have ads, and that's the only place that isn't saddled with the burden of ratings, and can give it to you straight. But I digress. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""2000"" height=""1550"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png 1000w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1600/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png 1600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/Screenshot-2023-11-09-at-4.38.27-PM.png 2124w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></figure>",654d7b983b6d610001c5405b,"Everywhere you look people are talking about how news and sports are holding up linear. And while that may remain a reason why people say they stay subscribed to pay TV in studies, from a TV ad stand point, you may be surprised.

Below is a ranking of TV genres by ad impressions delivered from Oct 1st through yesterday Nov 9th, according to iSpot.tv

The sports part is correct, football (NFL + College) are 55% of all ad impressions News? It's 9th with less than 2% of all ad reach on national linear TV. Throw in sports commentary and baseball and you're at 66% mas or menos.

News– the stuff that attempts to deliver facts so we can make educated decisions? 1.57%. Now to be fair, that doesn't include entertainment news, business news or the stuff on news networks that is anything but news.

Also to be fair, Lester Holt accounts is the 5th largest show to deliver ad reach and Muir clocks in at 9th (.025% of all TV).

Also, C-SPAN doesn't have ads, and that's the only place that isn't saddled with the burden of ratings, and can give it to you straight. "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""A October:"",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""children"":[{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""The "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":2},{""children"":[{""detail"":0,""format"":0,""mode"":""normal"",""style"":"""",""text"":""Month-over-month newcomers to the top ten include Rexulti ($21.6 million), Veozah ($15.5 million) and Lybalvi ($12.8 million)."",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""listitem"",""version"":1,""value"":3}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""list"",""version"":1,""listType"":""bullet"",""start"":1,""tag"":""ul""},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispotpharmaoct2023.png"",""width"":829,""height"":494,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""https://www.fiercepharma.com/marketing/abbvie-continues-dominance-total-spend-leading-drug-ads-october-jumps-221m""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>AbbVie has been one of the biggest pharmaceutical advertisers on TV this year, and in October it was no different: Its immunology drug Skyrizi topped the list of Rx brands by estimated TV ad spend, with an outlay of $45.6 million — a 52% increase from its September spend, per <a href=""https://www.fiercepharma.com/marketing/abbvie-continues-dominance-total-spend-leading-drug-ads-october-jumps-221m"" rel=""noreferrer"">iSpot data recently shared with FiercePharma.</a> </p><p>A few additional insights about the top-spending Rx brands in October:</p><ul><li>The top ten Rx brands spent an estimated $221.8 million on TV advertising during the month, a notable increase from the $164.8 million shelled out by September's top brands. NFL football and news were key drivers of spend.</li><li>The No. 2 Rx brand by spend was Dupixent ($33.9 million, up from $29.7 million in September), followed by Rinvoq, another AbbVie drug ($28.9 million, up from $22.1 million in September). </li><li>Month-over-month newcomers to the top ten include Rexulti ($21.6 million), Veozah ($15.5 million) and Lybalvi ($12.8 million).</li></ul><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.fiercepharma.com/marketing/abbvie-continues-dominance-total-spend-leading-drug-ads-october-jumps-221m""><img src=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispotpharmaoct2023.png"" class=""kg-image"" alt="""" loading=""lazy"" width=""829"" height=""494"" srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/ispotpharmaoct2023.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispotpharmaoct2023.png 829w"" sizes=""(min-width: 720px) 720px""></a></figure>",654e40b550ddea0001943ea7,"AbbVie has been one of the biggest pharmaceutical advertisers on TV this year, and in October it was no different: Its immunology drug Skyrizi topped the list of Rx brands by estimated TV ad spend, with an outlay of $45.6 million — a 52% increase from its September spend, per iSpot data recently shared with FiercePharma.

A few additional insights about the top-spending Rx brands in October:

 * The top ten Rx brands spent an estimated $221.8 million on TV advertising during the month, a notable increase from the $164.8 million shelled out by September's top brands. NFL football and news were key drivers of spend.
 * The No. 2 Rx brand by spend was Dupixent ($33.9 million, up from $29.7 million in September), followed by Rinvoq, another AbbVie drug ($28.9 million, up from $22.1 million in September).
 * Month-over-month newcomers to the top ten include Rexulti ($21.6 million), Veozah ($15.5 million) and Lybalvi ($12.8 "",""type"":""extended-text"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1},{""type"":""image"",""version"":1,""src"":""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/2023/11/ispot-autos-oct-2023.png"",""width"":1646,""height"":900,""title"":"""",""alt"":"""",""caption"":"""",""cardWidth"":""regular"",""href"":""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/390960/october-automotive-tv-spending-up-11.html""},{""children"":[],""direction"":null,""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""paragraph"",""version"":1}],""direction"":""ltr"",""format"":"""",""indent"":0,""type"":""root"",""version"":1}}","<p>Automakers shelled out an estimated $301 million on national TV advertising in October, an 11% increase year-over-year and a 33% increase from September's estimated outlay, according to <a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/390960/october-automotive-tv-spending-up-11.html"" rel=""noreferrer"">data from iSpot.tv recently shared with MediaPost.</a> </p><p>Fall sports (cough, cough, football), was one of the main drivers of both automaker TV ad spend and TV ad impressions: </p><ul><li>Each of the top five auto brands ranked by spend increased their investment in NFL games compared to October 2022. </li><li>Ford, which upped its estimated TV ad spend by 765.9% year-over-year, was especially focused on football this October, upping spend by 81x on NFL and 66x on college football vs. October 2022. </li><li>The top five programs by shared of household TV ad impressions were NFL (11.30%), college football (7.43%), MLB (5.32%), NBA (0.60%) and <em>The Voice</em> (0.53%).</li></ul><p>Get more TV advertising insights for the automotive insights <a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/390960/october-automotive-tv-spending-up-11.html"" rel=""noreferrer"">here</a>. </p><figure class=""kg-card kg-image-card""><a href=""https://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/390960/october-automotive-tv-spending-up-11.html""><img srcset=""__GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w600/2023/11/ispot-autos-oct-2023.png 600w, __GHOST_URL__/content/images/size/w1000/2023/11/ispot-autos-oct-2023.png 1000w, 720px""></a></figure>",654e45aa50ddea0001943ece,"Automakers shelled out an estimated $301 million on national TV advertising in October, an 11% increase year-over-year and a 33% increase from September's estimated outlay, according to data from iSpot.tv recently shared with MediaPost.

Fall sports (cough, cough, football), was one of the main drivers of both automaker TV ad spend and TV ad impressions:

 * Each of the top five auto brands ranked by spend increased their investment in NFL games compared to October 2022.
 * Ford, which upped its estimated TV ad spend by 765.9% year-over-year, was especially focused on football this October, upping spend by 81x on NFL and 66x on college football vs. October 2022.
 * The top five programs by shared of household TV ad impressions were NFL (11.30%), college football (7.43%), MLB (5.32%), NBA (0.60%) and The Voice (0.53%).
